Below are excerpts from our conversation.
Question: What does "connection" mean?
Answer: It is the experience of the performance that is important, not the performance itself. You must be able to communicate with your audience. If you don't, they won't like you. And if you don't like them, they won't like you either.
Question: How do you plan to communicate with your audience?
A: One of the most important things I've learned over the past 20 years is that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to communicating with people.

input:
Swirling dust devils on Mars have given NASA scientists both a scientific treat and a very welcome power boost.
On 10 March, the rover Spirit captured images of two dust devils in one day. It is the first time any have been seen on Mars
continuation:
.
"It's really exciting to be able to see these things," said Michael Meyer, an astrobiologist at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in Pasadena, California, who was part of the team that made the discovery. "We've never seen anything like this before."
The dust devils, which are caused by winds blowing across the surface of the red planet, were spotted by Spirit as it drove along a ridge in Gale Crater, where the rover has been exploring for more than three years.
Spirit had already found evidence of wind-blown sand dunes in the crater's south-eastern region, but the new images show the dunes are moving northwards.
Meyer told the Associated Press news agency: "I don't know if we're going to get a chance to go back out there [to investigate], but I'm pretty sure we'll get another look at them."
Dust devils are common on Earth, but they can be difficult to study because they move so quickly. The most famous dust devil ever recorded, however, took place in 2003 when a giant dust storm swept across North America.
Spirit's images also revealed that the dust devils are moving away from the rover
translation:
A rotating dust devil on Mars has given NASA scientists both scientific fun and a much-welcomed energy boost.
On March 10, the Spirit spacecraft captured two images of dust devils in one day. This is the first time they have been seen on Mars.
"It's very exciting to see something like this," said Michael Meyer, an astrobiologist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in Pasadena, California, who was part of the team that made the discovery. Ta. "I've never seen anything like this before."
The dust devils, which are caused by winds blowing across the Red Planet's surface, were discovered by Spirit as it traveled along the ridge of Gale Crater, which the rover has been exploring for more than three years.
Spirit has already found evidence of dunes in the southeastern part of the crater, but new images show the dunes are moving north.
"I don't know if I'll ever have a chance to go back there [to investigate], but I'll definitely look at it again," Meyer told The Associated Press.
Dust devils are common on Earth, but they can be difficult to study because they move so fast. But the most famous dust devil ever recorded occurred in 2003, when a huge dust storm hit North America.
Spirit's images also showed the dust devil moving away from the rover.

input: If President Clinton wants to see how activist government can solve social problems with strong public support, he should take a few days to visit Canada. With Toronto's World Series victory, the nationwide referendum on constitutional reform (including the status of Quebec), and the
continuation:
election of a new prime minister in Ottawa, it is clear that Canadians are ready for a change.

Canada is one of the world's most progressive countries when it comes to gay rights. It was the first G7 country to legalize same-sex marriage, and it has recently legalized civil unions for same-sex couples. It also has some of the strongest protections against discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.

But there are still many areas where Canadian society lags behind the U.S. and other developed nations. For example, Canada does not have universal health care or paid family leave. And while the federal government spends more than twice as much per capita on social programs than the U.S., it doesn't do nearly enough to ensure that all Canadians have access to them.

In fact, according to a recent study by the Public Policy Institute of California, Canada ranks dead last among advanced economies in the percentage of its GDP devoted to social programs. The United States spends about 10 percent of its GDP on social programs, while Japan, Germany, and France spend between 20 and 30 percent of their gross domestic product on social programs.

It's no wonder that Canadians feel so strongly about the need to improve social
translation:
If President Clinton wants to see how an activist government can address social issues with strong public support, he should visit Canada for a few days. Toronto's World Series victory, the referendum on constitutional reform (including Quebec's status), and the election of a new prime minister in Ottawa make it clear that Canadians are ready for change.

Canada is one of the most progressive countries in the world on gay rights. It was the first G7 country to legalize same-sex marriage and recently legalized civil unions for same-sex couples. It also has some of the strongest protections against discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.

But there are still many areas in which Canadian society lags behind compared to the United States and other developed countries. For example, Canada does not have universal health care or paid family leave. And while the federal government spends more than twice as much per capita on social programs as the United States, it is not enough to ensure that all Canadians have access to social programs.

In fact, a recent study by the Public Policy Institute of California ranked Canada last among developed countries in the percentage of GDP devoted to social programs. The United States spends about 10 percent of its GDP on social programs, while Japan, Germany and France spend 20 to 30 percent of their gross domestic product on social programs.

It's no wonder that Canadians feel a strong need to improve their social conditions.

input:
Gov. Parris N. Glendening is seriously considering vetoing legislation that would make Maryland the first state to require that all public school students take a gun safety class.
The governor has been besieged with calls from teachers troubled by the measure's
continuation:
potential impact on their classrooms, but he hasn't made up his mind yet.

work with each other) is one of the biggest challenges facing IT today.

translation:
At the AppsWorld developer conference, Oracle President Chuck Phillips spoke to about 10,000 customers and developers about the show's theme: software integration. In his opening remarks, Phillips pointed out that interoperability (making software communicate with each other) is one of the biggest challenges facing IT departments today.

"We're going to talk about ways to make your job easier," he said. Let's talk about how to make your job easier.

Without going into details, Phillips said the company plans to release a new set of APIs (application programming interfaces) in the second half of this year. APIs are designed to allow developers to create applications that can easily communicate with each other.

Phillips also talked about his Oracle cloud-based Application Development Platform (ADP), which allows developers to create applications without writing code. He said ADP is already used by more than 100,000 people around the world.

We want to make it easy for you to get started, says Phillips. It's not just about getting started. It's to make it easier for you to stay there. We have a lot of things that can help.

Atletico Madrid and France forward Antoine Griezmann has taken home the award for the best player in La Liga last season.
But the glitzy awards ceremony in Valencia was overshadowed with no Barcelona players attending after manager Luis Enrique was overlooked
continuation:
in favour of his compatriot Ernesto Valverde.
Valverde's Barca won the Copa del Rey, but were knocked out of the Champions League by Atletico Madrid in the quarter-finals.
Antoine Griezmann (right) won the best player award at the Spanish Football Awards on Tuesday night
Griezmann beat Real Madrid's Cristiano Ronaldo to the prize, which is given annually to the best player in Spain's top flight.
Ronaldo won the Ballon d'Or earlier this month, while Atletico Madrid defender Diego Godin won the Pichichi Trophy for the second year in a row.
Barcelona midfielder Andres Iniesta also finished runner-up to Real Madrid's Luka Modric for the first time since 2013.

input:
A woman sucker punched and stabbed on the subway says the attack was motivated by hate. Wale Aliyu reports.
A woman was punched and stabbed when she got off the subway in Brooklyn by a man yelling racially charged words, her family and
continuation:
law enforcement sources told The New York Times.
The incident occurred at around 6:45 p.m. Tuesday on the No. 2 train at Grand Concourse station in Bedford-Stuyvesant, police said.
According to witnesses, the attacker yelled get out of my country as he approached the victim, who was wearing a headscarf, and punched her in the face several times before stabbing her once in the back.
The assailant then ran away with the victims cell phone, which had been left behind, according to law enforcement sources.
The victim was taken to Kings County Hospital, where she was treated for non-life-threatening injuries. Her condition was not immediately known.
Police are looking for the attacker, described as a black man in his late 20s or early 30s. He is about 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighs between 140 and 160 pounds. He was last seen wearing a blue hooded sweatshirt, black sweatpants and white sneakers.
Submit tips to police by calling Crime Stoppers at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477), visiting www.nypdcrimestoppers.com, or texting 274637 (CRIMES
translation:
The vile woman who was beaten and stabbed on the subway says the attack was motivated by hatred. Reported by Vale Aliyu.
A woman who got off a subway train in Brooklyn was punched and stabbed by a man who yelled racial slurs at her, her family and law enforcement officials told The New York Times.
The incident occurred around 6:45 p.m. Police said it happened Tuesday on the No. 2 train at Grand Concourse Station in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
Witnesses said the gunman approached the victim wearing a headscarf while shouting "get out of the country," punched him several times in the face and then stabbed him in the back.
The suspect then fled with the victim's cell phone, but police said the cell phone was left behind.
The victim was taken to Kings County Hospital and treated for non-life-threatening injuries. Her condition was not immediately known.
Police are searching for the suspect, described as a black man between 20 and 30 years old. He is approximately 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighs between 140 and 160 pounds. He was last seen wearing a blue hoodie, black sweatpants, and white sneakers.
To submit information to police, call Crime Stoppers at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477), visit www.nypdcrimestoppers.com, or text him 274637 (CRIMES) please.

input: Inside Rebel-Held Syria NPR's Kelly McEvers spent a week with anti-government rebels knows as the Free Syrian Army. The government holds the country's cities, but the rebels control considerable territory in rural area near the Turkish border.
continuation:
KELLY MCEVERS, HOST:

This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News. Good morning. I'm Kelly McEvers.

RENEE MONTAGNE, HOST:

And I'm Renee Montagne.

We're joined now by NPR's Kelly McEvers, who has been reporting on the conflict in Syria for more than two years. And she joins us from the rebel-held town of Saraqeb in the northern province of Idlib.

Welcome to the program. How are you doing?

KELLY MCEVERS, BYLINE: Hi, Renee.

MONTAGNE: So what was your first impression of this place when you arrived?

MCEVERS: Well, it's a very small town. It's only about 20,000 people, and there's not much infrastructure here at all. You have a few schools, a few hospitals, a couple of bakeries, a few grocery stores, and that's about it.

You know, we were walking through the streets, and there was no electricity or running water. We saw a lot of abandoned cars. There was a lot of trash everywhere.
translation:
Inside rebel-held Syria, NPR's Kelly McEvers spent a week with an anti-government rebel group known as the Free Syrian Army. The government maintains control of the country's cities, but rebels control vast rural areas near the Turkish border.

KELLY MCVERS, HOST:

This is the morning edition of NPR News. good morning. I'm Kelly McEvers.

Rene Montagne, host:

And I'm Ren Montagne.

Welcome to the program. how are you?

KELLY MCVERS, BYLINE: Hello, Renee.

MONTAGNE: So what was your first impression of this place when you came here?

MCEVERS: Well, it's a very small town. The population here is only about 20,000 people and there is little infrastructure. There are a few schools, a few hospitals, a few bakeries, a few grocery stores, and that's it.

We were walking down the street and there was no electricity or running water. I saw many abandoned cars. There was a lot of trash everywhere.

input:
Today's Millennials could be tomorrow's very sweaty retirees thanks to temperatures and humidity levels that are rising so fast that, by the end of this century, simply going outside could be deadly.
The study's alarming findings put into sharp perspective not just what
continuation:
climate change is doing to our planet, but also how we can do something about it.
In a new paper published in the journal Climatic Change, researchers at the University of Exeter have found that the average global temperature has already risen by 1.1 degrees Celsius since pre-industrial times, and will likely continue to rise for the next 100 years or more.
This means that, if we don't start taking action now, the world will be much hotter than it was before the industrial revolution.
"Climate change is one of the biggest challenges facing humanity," said co-author Dr. Richard Betts from the University of Exeter's Department of Geography. "We need to take urgent action to reduce carbon emissions to limit global warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels."
To get a sense of just how bad things are getting, consider these numbers: In the U.S., the average summer heat wave is expected to get worse over the next few decades, according to a recent report from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
According to the report, the number of heat waves in the U.S. is expected to increase by up to 50 percent between now and 2050.

Sen. Tom Bakk will remain the DFL leader, but this time in the minority.
Sen. Paul Gazelka was elected by his Republican colleagues Thursday to be the new majority leader of the Minnesota Senate.
Gazelka will join
continuation:
Sen. Karin Housley, R-St. Paul, as Democrats' top two leaders when the Legislature reconvenes in January.
Bakk, a St. Paul Democrat, has served as Senate president pro tempore since 2015 and is the longest-serving senator in state history.
He announced earlier this month that he would not seek re-election next year.
"It's been an honor to serve my fellow Minnesotans for more than 30 years," Bakk said in a news release. "I'm proud of the work we've done together and look forward to working with our colleagues on both sides of the aisle to build on the progress we've made over the last four years."

input:
Defensive back K'Waun Williams, shown after making a big play for the Pitt Panthers last season, has signed with the Cleveland Browns.
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- The Browns continue to add to their cornerback pile.
On Tuesday,
continuation:
the team announced that it had signed free-agent defensive back K'Waun Williams, who was released by the Pittsburgh Steelers earlier this month.
Williams played in all 16 games for the Steelers last season, starting five of them. He recorded three passes defensed, two interceptions and one forced fumble.
The 6-foot-2, 190-pound Williams originally entered the NFL as an undrafted free agent out of Texas A&M in 2018.
He spent his rookie season on the Steelers practice squad before being promoted to the 53-man roster during training camp in 2019.
In 2020, Williams appeared in seven games for the Steelers, recording six tackles and one pass defensed. He also started one game at strong safety.
Browns head coach Kevin Stefanski is familiar with Williams from his time with the Minnesota Vikings.
"We are excited to have him join our football team," Stefanski said in a statement. "His versatility will be a great asset to our defense."
Stefanski added: "I know he's been working hard and we're looking forward to seeing what he can do for us."
Williams joins a group of cornerbacks that includes Denzel Ward, Greedy Williams, Andrew Sendejo

input:
As Athens goes to the polls, has the British left fallen out of love with the EU?
In 1874, Karl Marx had an imaginary conversation with Mikhail Bakunin. Nowadays, they would just have had a Twitter spat, but back then
continuation:
Marx and Bakunin were talking about Britain's relationship with the European Union (EU).
"What do you think?" Marx asked his friend. "Should we join the EU or not?"
Bakunin replied that he thought it was a good idea, but added: "I don't know if we will be able to stay in it."
The exchange took place at a time when Britain was on the verge of joining the European Economic Community (EEC)  the forerunner of the European Union. It was the first time Marx had spoken to someone who did not share his views on the future of Europe.
It is now more than 50 years since Marx and Bakunin met. The UK is due to leave the EU on 31 October, and the country's political landscape has changed dramatically over the past few decades.
In the early 1970s, the Labour Party led by Clement Attlee won a landslide victory in the general election. In 1979, Margaret Thatcher became prime minister for the first time. She promised to cut taxes and increase spending on public services such as the National Health Service (NHS) and social housing.
These policies were popular with the British people, who saw them as a way to improve their standard of

This policy was popular among the British, who saw it as a way to improve their standard of living.

input: From the house of ZURB, creators of such apps as Bounce, Notable, Reel and Strike, comes another Web app called Spur. Its a free app that aims to help Web designers return to basics and ensure that they
continuation:
dont get lost in all the bells and whistles of modern web design.

Spur lets you see what your designs would look like if they were printed out on paper. You can use it to make mockups or even print them out for real.

You can also add text, images, links, and other elements to your designs.

The app is currently available for iOS and Android, but will be coming soon to Windows Phone.

If you have any questions, feel free to drop me a line at [email protected]. Id love to hear your thoughts!

ZURB, the maker of apps like Bounce, Notable, Reel, and Strike, has released another web app called Spur. This is a free app that aims to help web designers get back to basics and not get lost in all the bells and whistles of modern web design.

Spur allows you to see how your design will look when printed on paper. You can use it to create designs and even print it out.

You can also add text, images, links, and other elements to your project.

The app is currently available on iOS and Android, and will soon be coming to Windows Phone.

input: What were the politics of abortion like in this country before Roe v. Wade? Different than what I thought in a couple of important ways, Ive learned from a new book, Before Roe v. Wade, by Linda Greenhouse and Rev
continuation:
. William Barber II.

Greenhouse is an associate professor of history at Princeton University, where she teaches courses on U.S. womens history. She has written several books, including The Feminine Mystique, which was made into a movie starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston.

Barber is the president of the North Carolina chapter of the NAACP, and he leads the Moral Monday protests that have been taking place in Raleigh for more than two years. He also serves as pastor of First Baptist Church of Winston-Salem, one of the largest African-American congregations in the state.

Before Roe v. Wade: A History of Abortion in America (Penguin Random House; $27.95) tells the story of the fight to end abortion in the United States, from its beginnings in the 19th century until the Supreme Court ruling in 1973 that legalized it.

The book is divided into three parts. The first part covers the period from the beginning of the 19th century to the Civil War. The second deals with the period from the Civil War through World War II. The third part focuses on the period after the war.

translation:
What was abortion policy like in this country before Roe v. Wade? In some key ways, I learned something different from what I thought I had learned from Linda Greenhouse and Rev. William Barber II's new book, Before Roe v. Wade.

Greenhouse is an assistant professor of history at Princeton University and teaches a course on the history of U.S. women. She has written several books, including The Feminine Mystique, which was adapted into a film starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston.

Barber is president of the North Carolina chapter of the NAACP and has led the Moral Monday protests in Raleigh for more than two years. He also serves as pastor of the First Baptist Church of Winston-Salem, one of the state's largest African-American congregations.

Before Roe v. Wade: A History of Abortion in America (Penguin Random House, $27.95) tells the story of the fight to end abortion in the United States, from its beginnings in the 19th century to the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion.

The book is divided into three parts. The first part covers the period from the early 19th century to the Civil War. The second covers the period from the Civil War to World War II. The third part focuses on the postwar period.

Emaar Hospitality Group has unveiled its new hotel brand, The Address Hotels and Resorts, with three properties slated to open in the next seven months in Dubai.
Planned properties include the 143-room and 57-suite The
continuation:
Address Downtown Dubai, which will be located on Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum International Airports (SMBIA) concourse level, as well as The Address Mall of the Emirates, which is scheduled to open in December 2018.
The Address Downtown Dubai will have a contemporary design inspired by the iconic Burj Khalifa skyscraper. It will also feature an indoor swimming pool, fitness centre, spa and children's play area.
Designed by renowned architect Zaha Hadid Architects, The Address Mall of the Emirates will be situated on the ground floor of SMBIAs main terminal building.
It will be home to more than 100 shops, restaurants and bars offering a wide range of dining options for guests to choose from.
"We are excited to launch our new brand, The Address Hotels and Resorts, and we look forward to working with our partners at Emaar Hospitality to deliver high-quality hotels and resorts across the UAE," said Saeed Mohammed Al Tayer, chief executive officer of Emaar Hospitality.
He added: "We are confident that The Address Hotels and Resorts will become a key player in the hospitality sector in the UAE."

Eyewitness Clifford Goorovadoo said: "It is true that when the first police officers
continuation:

"They had to wait for an ambulance to arrive and then they were allowed to go closer."

Diana, 36, was travelling with Dodi Al Fayed, 42, and their chauffeur Henri Paul in a Jaguar XK120 when the car crashed into a wall.
Mr Goorovadoo told the hearing he saw the car's rear end hit a concrete pillar and burst into flames.

"I thought it was some sort of accident or something like that.
"I didn't really know what was happening

input: Lauren Noland has a love for exotic food. The Eagle River, Alaska native attributes her love of adventurous things to some of the wild meats available growing up, including her favorite dish, caribou sausage lasagna. A veteran herself, and
continuation:
one who served in the U.S. Armys 101st Airborne Division, she now works as a military nutritionist with the Department of Veterans Affairs.

She is also the author of the cookbook The Caribou Cookbook (HarperCollins). In this interview, she talks about how she came to write the book, what it was like to serve in Iraq, and why she believes that eating meat can be good for your health.

Q: What inspired you to write The Caribou Cookbook?

A: I have always loved cooking, but when I moved to Alaska, I realized that there were so many different kinds of foods that could be made from local ingredients. I wanted to share those recipes with others.

Q: How long did it take you to write the book?

A: It took me about two years to write the book. I worked on it every day while I was working at the VA.

Q: Did you find it hard to keep track of everything?

A: Yes, I found it very difficult to keep track of all of the recipes. I kept a notebook next to my computer
translation:
Lauren Noland loves exotic food. The Eagle River, Alaska, native credits her adventurous nature to eating wild meat as a child. That includes her favorite food: caribou sausage and lasagna. A veteran herself, she served in the U.S. Army's 101st Airborne Division and currently works as a military nutritionist for the Department of Veterans Affairs.

She is also the author of the cookbook, The Caribou Cookbook (HarperCollins). In this interview, she talks about how she came to write this book, what her service in Iraq was like, and why she believes eating meat is good for your health. Let's talk about what's going on.

Q: What inspired you to write The Caribou Cookbook?

A: I've always loved to cook, but when I moved to Alaska, I realized there were so many different dishes that could be made using local ingredients. I wanted to share these recipes with others.

Question: How long did it take you to write this book?

Answer: It took me about two years to write this book. I worked on this every day while at the VA.

Question: Was it difficult to keep track of everything?

Answer: Yes, it was very difficult to keep track of all the recipes. I put a notepad next to my computer.

input: DES MOINES, Iowa (AP)  Authorities apprehended a man Wednesday suspected in the early morning killings of two Des Moines area police officers who were shot to death while sitting in their patrol cars in what authorities described as separate ambush-style attacks.
continuation:
Des Moines Police Chief Paul Parizek said during a news conference that the suspect was taken into custody without incident at his home and is being held on first-degree murder charges. He did not release any other details about the suspects identity or where he was arrested.

Parizek said the suspect was identified after an extensive investigation involving multiple law enforcement agencies, including the FBI and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

We believe this individual is responsible for these murders, Parizek said.

The shooting happened shortly before 2:30 a.m. Tuesday when the officers responded to a call about a suspicious person near the intersection of North 10th Street and West Locust Avenue in Des Moines. The officers found two people with gunshot wounds and took them to a local hospital, where they later died from their injuries.

Police have not released the names or ages of the officers but said they were both members of the Des Moines Police Departments Special Response Team and had been assigned to the citys East Precinct.

This is a very difficult time for our entire community, Parizek said.
translation:
DES MOINES, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities arrested a man Wednesday on suspicion of killing two Des Moines-area police officers. In what police said were separate ambush attacks, the man shot and killed the two officers as they sat in their patrol car.

Des Moines Police Chief Paul Parizek said at a news conference that the suspect was taken into custody without incident at his home and is being held on charges of first-degree murder. He did not release other details about the suspect's identity or the location of his arrest.

Parizek said the suspect was identified after an extensive investigation involving multiple law enforcement agencies, including the FBI and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

We believe this man is responsible for these murders," Parizek said.

The shooting happened just before 2:30 a.m. Tuesday when officers responded to a call about a suspicious person near the intersection of North 10th Avenue and West Locust Street in Des Moines. Officers found two people with gunshot wounds and transported them to a local hospital, where they later died from their injuries.

Police did not release the officers' names or ages but said both are members of the Des Moines Police Department's Special Response Team and are assigned to the city's East Precinct. 

"This is an extremely difficult time for our entire community," Parizek said.

input:
Thermal emission from erupting volcanoes on the Jupiter's moon Io. A logarithmic scale is used to classify volcanoes on the basis of thermal emission; the larger the spot, the larger the thermal emission.
A new map of
continuation:
volcanic activity on Io has been created by scientists using data from NASAs Galileo spacecraft, which was launched in 1997 and has since orbited Jupiter for more than 13 years. The map reveals a vast array of volcanoes on Io, including some that have not been seen before.
Io is the second-largest planet in our solar system after Earth. It orbits Jupiter at a distance of about 1,200 miles (2,000 kilometers), making it one of the most distant planets in the Solar System. Scientists believe that Io may be an active world, as its surface is covered with numerous craters that were formed by volcanic eruptions. However, there are still many unknowns about Ios geology, such as how much lava flows beneath the surface.
To better understand these mysteries, researchers analyzed data collected by NASAs Galileo spacecraft between 1999 and 2005. The team then used computer models to estimate the amount of volcanic activity on Io over the past few thousand years. They found that volcanic activity increased dramatically during the last ice age, around 12,000 years ago.
Its very difficult to predict what will happen next, said study co-author Michael Gazzaniga
translation:
Heat radiation from erupting volcanoes on Jupiter's moon Io. Logarithmic scales are used to classify volcanoes based on their thermal radiation. The larger the spot, the greater the heat radiation.
The new map of Io's volcanic activity was created by scientists using data from NASA's Galileo spacecraft, which was launched in 1997 and has been orbiting Jupiter for more than 13 years since then. The map shows a huge number of volcanoes on the island of Io, some of which have never been seen before.
Io is her second largest planet in the solar system after Earth. Orbiting around Jupiter at a distance of about 1,200 miles (2,000 kilometers), she is one of the most distant planets in the solar system. Scientists believe that Io's surface may be an active world, as it is covered with numerous craters formed by volcanic eruptions. However, there are still many unknowns about the geology of Ios, such as how much lava flows beneath the surface.
To better understand these mysteries, researchers analyzed data collected by NASA's Galileo spacecraft between 1999 and 2005. The research team then used computer models to estimate the amount of volcanic activity on Io over the past several thousand years. They found that volcanic activity increased dramatically during the last Ice Age, about 12,000 years ago.
It's very difficult to predict what will happen next, said study co-author Michael Gazzaniga.

Hourly workers aren't the only ones who have to track hours worked.
2 What if a Salaried Employee Works More Than 40 Hours?
Ask two workers if they prefer a salary or hourly wage, you will likely get two different answers
continuation:
. But what if one of them works more than 40 hours a week? How does that impact their time off?
The answer is complicated and depends on how many hours the worker actually works each week. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), salaried employees work an average of 37.5 hours per week. That's about the same as non-salaried employees.
But there are some differences between salaried and hourly employees. For instance, salaried employees tend to work longer hours because they are compensated for every hour they work. In other words, they don't get paid for every minute they spend working.
On the other hand, hourly workers do not receive any compensation for every hour they work. This means that they can be paid for every hour they work even if they work less than 40 hours in a given week.
In fact, according to a recent study by the National Employment Law Project (NELP) and the National Association of State Workforce Agencies (NASWA), salaried workers are more likely than hourly workers to work more than 40 hours in a week.

input:
KINSHASA Democratic Republic of Congo's top court on Monday definitively excluded opposition leader Jean-Pierre Bemba from December's presidential election because of a witness tampering conviction at the International Criminal Court.
KINSHASA Congolese
continuation:
President Joseph Kabila, who has been in power since 2001 and is due to step down after 18 years in office next year, was barred from standing for re-election by an electoral commission decision last week.
The Constitutional Court ruled that Bemba could not be allowed to run because he had been found guilty of crimes against humanity by the Hague-based ICC, which is investigating alleged atrocities committed during the country's civil war that ended in 2003.
"We have decided to disqualify Jean-Pierre Bemba from running for president," Chief Justice Felix Tshisekedi told reporters. "He will no longer be able to take part in the elections."
(Reporting by Aaron Ross; Writing by Hereward Holland; Editing by Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Angus MacSwan)

translation:
The Democratic Republic of Congo's Kinshasa Supreme Court on Monday permanently banned opposition leader Jean-Pierre Bemba from the December presidential election for fabricating a witness' conviction at the International Criminal Court.
Kinshasa-Congo President Joseph Kabila, who has held power since 2001 and will step down next year at the end of his 18-year term, has been barred from running for re-election following a decision by the electoral commission last week.
The Constitutional Court said Bembe should not be allowed to run because he had been convicted of crimes against humanity by the Hague-based ICC, which is investigating alleged atrocities committed during the civil war that ended in 2003. handed down a judgment.
"I have decided to disqualify Jean-Pierre Bemba from running for president," Supreme Court Chief Justice Flix Shisekedi told reporters. "He will no longer be able to participate in elections."
(Reporting by Aaron Ross; Writing by Heward Holland; Editing by Matthew Mpoka Bigg and Angus McSwan)

input: The dominant position that Microsoft software occupies on the desktop has long been a major source of competitive advantage to Microsoft. Not only does it ensure that users of Microsoft software are familiar with the look and feel of the Microsoft interface but it also has provided a launch
continuation:
pad for new products, such as Internet Explorer.

Microsoft is not alone in its dominance of the desktop operating system market. Apple's Mac OS X remains the most popular desktop operating system in the United States, followed by Windows XP and Linux.

But according to research firm Gartner, which recently released its Worldwide Quarterly Desktop Operating System Tracker (WQDSOT) report, Microsoft's share of the desktop operating system market will decline over the next five years.

Gartner predicts that Microsoft will account for less than half of the worldwide desktop operating system market by 2012, down from more than two-thirds in 2007.

In fact, Gartner predicts that the worldwide desktop operating system market will be dominated by three different operating systems -- Apple's iOS, Google's Android, and Microsoft's Windows 8 -- by 2012.

"This is an important shift," said Michael Ovitz, principal analyst at Gartner. "We've seen this before. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, there was a lot of talk about how Microsoft would dominate the personal computer market. It never materialized. The same thing is happening now."

According to Ovitz, the reasons for the decline

A motorcyclist from Worthing suffered fatal injuries following a collision with two cars on the A286 in Birdham, near Chichester, yesterday.
The 56-year-old motorcyclist from Worthing collided with a Jaguar travelling in
continuation:
the opposite direction at around 12.30pm.
He was taken to Royal Sussex County Hospital in Brighton where he sadly died of his injuries.
His next of kin have been informed and are being supported by specially trained officers.
Anyone with information is asked to call Sussex Police on 101 or Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555111.
You can also contact the independent charity Crimestoppers online via their anonymous online form at: www.crimestoppers-uk.org.

In its answer to Amazon, Google's new umbrella program will extend existing relationships with retailers and enable universal checkout across platforms and devices.
Google has been working on retail challenges for some time. The problems: (1) how to make mobile shopping from
continuation:
your phone as seamless as possible; (2) what to do when you're in a crowded store and want to check out but don't have an Android or iOS device; (3) how to make it easy for customers to buy things online without having to go through the hassle of signing up for multiple accounts.
The company announced last week that it was teaming up with more than 100 retailersincluding Walmart, Target, Best Buy, Kohl's, Macy's, and othersto launch a new service called Google Shopping Express. It'll let shoppers use their phones to scan barcodes at the register and pay for items without having to download any apps or sign up for multiple accounts.
"We are excited to announce our partnership with Google Shopping Express, which will give consumers access to hundreds of thousands of products they can shop quickly and easily," said Brian Huseman, senior vice president and general manager of Google Shopping Express, in a statement. "This is a big step forward for Google Shopping Express, and we look forward to continuing to work with partners around the world to help them improve their customer experiences."
It's unclear exactly how many merchants will be participating in the new service, though Google did say that it expects to

In response to Amazon's proposal, Google's new inclusion program will expand its existing relationships with retailers and offer universal checkout across all platforms and devices.
Google has been tackling retail problems for some time. Issues: (1) How to make shopping from a mobile phone as convenient as possible. (2) What if I want to order in a crowded store but don't have an Android or iOS device? (3) How to enable customers to purchase things online without registering multiple accounts.
Last week, the company announced it was partnering with more than 100 retailers, including Walmart, Target, Best Buy, Kohl's, Macy's and more, to launch a new service called Google Shopping Express. This allows shoppers to use their mobile phones to scan barcodes and pay for items at checkout without having to download an app or register multiple accounts.
Brian Huseman, senior vice president and general manager of Google Shopping Express, said: statement. . This is a huge step forward for Google Shopping Express, and we look forward to continuing to work with our partners around the world to help improve the customer experience.
Google has said it expects to participate, but it's unclear how many merchants will actually participate in the new service.

translation:
J. Walter Thompson today announced a shake-up of its U.S. and global leadership team with several senior-level appointments, including the appointment of Simon Pearce as CEO of North America. Mr. Pierce previously served as Chief Operating Officer of Mcgarrybowens Americas.

Pearce will be based in New York and will report to JWT Chairman and CEO Jonathan Rothwell, who will retire at the end of this year.

"Simon has a track record of building and leading organizations to success, and we are excited to have him join our team," Rothwell said in a statement. His deep understanding of our clients and their needs, as well as his extensive marketing experience, make him the perfect candidate for this new role.

In addition to serving as mccgarrybowen's chief operating officer, Mr. Pearce also served as president of the company's Asia Pacific region from 2012 until 2015. Prior to joining mccgarrybowen, he held senior management positions at Ogilvy & Mather and Publicis Groupe.

"I look forward to working with Jonathan and the rest of the management team to build on the strong foundation that JWT has built over the past few years," Pearce said in his statement. These are exciting times for our company and I look forward to continuing my work.

input: Amazon has announced another twist on the Fire TV in the form of the Fire TV Cube. If you imagine the functionality of the Fire TV, combine it with an Echo Dot and add in a bit of universal remote control, you've arrived at the Fire
continuation:
TV Cube.

The Fire TV Cube is Amazon's answer to Google's Chromecast Ultra, which launched earlier this year for $50 less than the Fire TV Stick 4K. It comes with Alexa built-in, so you can use voice commands to stream content from your phone, tablet, or computer, as well as play music, make video calls, and more. It also includes a USB port for charging other devices like phones, tablets, and computers.

You'll be able to purchase the Fire TV Cube for $99 when it goes on sale later this month. You can pre-order it right now if you want to get a head start on the holiday shopping season.

Update: The Fire TV Cube is now available for pre-order on Amazon.com.

Update 2: Amazon has announced that the Fire TV Cube will be available for pre-order starting today, November 6th, at 12 p.m. PT (3 p.m. ET).

Update 3: The Fire TV Cube is now available for pre-order on Amazon.com. Pre-orders are open until 11:59 p.m. PT on Friday, November 8th.

Editors' Recommend

This is a huge step forward in our countrys history, said U.S. Rep. Jared Polis (D-Colo.), who introduced the Marijuana Opportunity Reinvestment and Expungement (MORE) Act earlier this year. The legalization of marijuana is long overdue and I am proud to have worked with my colleagues in both chambers to make it happen.

Colorado and Washington were the first two states to legalize marijuana for medical use in 1998. Since then, more than a dozen others have followed suit, including California, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Pennsylvania.

In 2013, the National Conference of State Legislatures reported that at least 30 states had legalized some form of medical marijuana.

Gloucester claimed their second win of the season to impose a third defeat of the fledgling campaign on Wasps.
Stephen Jones put Wasps 3-0 ahead before two Freddie Burns penalties and a converted James Simpson-Daniel try gave the hosts a
continuation:
bonus point victory at Franklins Gardens.
The result leaves Gloucester in sixth place, four points behind leaders Saracens, but with a game in hand.
Wasps, who have now lost five of their last six Premiership matches, remain rooted to the bottom of the table.
Gloucester started the brighter of the two sides and were rewarded after just three minutes when they took the lead for the first time.
Simpson-Daniels dummied his way over from close range following a lineout maul.
It was not long before the visitors had a chance to equalise, however, as Willi Heinz was yellow-carded for an off-the-ball incident.
Jones stepped up to take the resulting penalty and made no mistake as he slotted it into the top corner to give Gloucester a 10-3 lead.
But Wasps hit back almost immediately through replacement scrum-half Matt Kvesic.
Kvesic picked up a loose ball and raced away down the left wing before crossing the whitewash to level the scores at 10-10.

Jones came forward to take the penalty and made no mistake, scoring into the top corner to give Gloucester a 10-3 lead.
However, Wasps struck back almost immediately, replacing scrum-half Matt Quebecic.
Kvesic picked up the ball, ran up the left side, and crossed the line to tie the game at 10-10.

input:
Having joined the ranks of perennial college football bowl participants, Northwestern University also now has joined the ranks of schools at which a coach has the highest annual compensation.
Pat Fitzgerald was credited with more than $2.2 million in compensation during the 2011 calendar
continuation:
year, according to figures released by the NCAA on Wednesday.
Fitzgerald's total includes a base salary of $1.5 million and a $500,000 bonus for winning the Big Ten championship game.
The Wildcats finished 9-4 last season and won their first conference title since 1991.
Northwestern is one of three schools -- along with Florida State and Texas A&M -- that have had multiple coaches earn six-figure salaries over the past five years.
Florida State's Willie Taggart, who took over after Jimbo Fisher left to take the head coaching job at Texas A&M, led the Seminoles to a 10-3 record and an appearance in the Citrus Bowl.
Taggart made $2.6 million in 2011, while Texas A&M's Kevin Sumlin made $2.7 million.

Almost three weeks after a primary that wiped out two incumbents, the remaining candidates for Carroll County commissioner are struggling to show voters that they're much different from each other.
Most of the candidates mounted successful primary campaigns by saying they would not be like
continuation:
their predecessors, who have been accused of being too cozy with big business and failing to represent the interests of the people they were elected to serve.
But now that the election is over, it's hard to see how anyone can distinguish themselves from the rest of the field.
"We've got a lot of work to do," said former state Sen. Andy Gipson, who finished third in the race. "I think we all need to look at what we've done and make sure we don't get complacent."
Gipson was one of six candidates vying for three seats on the county's board of commissioners. The top vote-getters will face off in the general election Nov. 5.
In his first run for office, Gipson, a Republican, ran as a moderate who could bridge the gap between Republicans and Democrats. He promised to focus on issues such as education, public safety and economic development.
But he struggled to gain traction in the crowded field. In the end, Gipson came in third place behind incumbent Commissioner John Rafferty and challenger Tim O'Hara.
O'Hara, a real estate agent who has lived in Westminster for more than 20 years, said

input: TUCSON, Ariz. (AP) Arizona was shaky with the ball early, had trouble getting shots to fall from the perimeter. With a roster full of new players and old players in new roles, it was kind of expected.
continuation:
The Wildcats finally got their offense going in the second half and pulled away for an 82-69 victory over Southern California on Thursday night.

We were playing catch-up, Arizona coach Sean Miller said. It wasnt until we started making some shots that we were able to play our brand of basketball. I think thats what weve been trying to do all year. Weve just got to get better at it.

Arizona led by as many as 10 points in the first half before the Trojans went on a 13-0 run to take a 33-31 lead into the locker room. The Wildcats responded with a 19-4 run to take a 41-38 lead into halftime.

I thought they played well, USC coach Andy Enfield said. They did a good job defensively. They made us work for every shot. We didnt have any easy baskets tonight.

After trailing by as many as 11 points in the first half, Arizona scored the final seven points of the half to take a 45-43 lead into the break.

Our guys
translation:
TUCSON, Ariz. (AP) Arizona handled the ball poorly early and struggled to shoot the ball from the perimeter. This was to be expected, with new players and old players on the roster taking on new roles.

The Wildcats finally got their offense back on track in the second half, winning 82-69 over Southern California on Thursday night.

"We were playing catch-up," Arizona coach Sean Miller said. It wasn't until we started making shots that we were able to play our own basketball. I think that's what we've been trying to do all year. I just need to get better.

Arizona led by 10 points at the half, then the Trojans went on a 13-0 run to take a 33-31 lead into the locker room. The Wildcats battled back with a 19-4 run to lead 41-38 at halftime.

"I thought they played well," USC coach Andy Enfield said. They did a good job defensively. They made us work on every shot. There were no easy baskets tonight.

Arizona trailed by as many as 11 points in the first half, but scored the final seven points of the second half to lead 45-43 at halftime.

input:
Former Paterson Mayor Pat Kramer reflects on the crises facing Paterson in the wake of Joey Torres' resignation.
In light of the plea agreement made by now former Paterson Mayor Joey Torres, I was asked to reflect on the future of my beloved
continuation:
city and what it will look like when he is no longer a part of it.
I have been thinking about this issue for some time, but never more so than in the last few days. It's hard to put into words what has happened to our city over the past few weeks, but I can say with confidence that we are not where we need to be at this point in our history.
The events of the past few weeks have exposed the deep divisions in our city, and they have also brought us closer together as a community. The outpouring of love and support from our neighbors, friends and family has been nothing short of amazing.
It has been humbling to see how many people have reached out to me to offer their support, whether through phone calls, texts or emails. Many have offered to help me get back on my feet, while others are offering to help me start a new chapter of my life.
There are still many challenges ahead, but I am confident that Paterson will come out of this stronger and more united than ever before.
My heart goes out to all of those who have been affected by this tragedy, especially the families and loved ones of those who were lost. We will always remember them
translation:
Former Paterson Mayor Pat Kramer reflects on the crisis facing the city following the resignation of Joey Torres.
In light of the plea deal reached by former Paterson Mayor Joey Torres, I was asked to think about the future of our beloved city and what it will look like after he is gone.
I've been thinking about this question for a while, especially the last few days. It is difficult to explain in words what has happened to our city over the past few weeks, but I can confidently say that at this point in our history, we are not where we should be.
The events of the past few weeks have exposed the deep divisions in our city, while also bringing us closer together as a community. The outpouring of love and support from neighbors, friends and family was amazing.
I was horrified to see how many people offered to support me by phone, text, and email. Many people have offered to help me get back on my feet, and some have offered to help me start the next chapter of my life.
There are still many challenges ahead, but I am confident that Paterson will emerge from this situation stronger and more united than ever.
My heart goes out to all those affected by this tragedy, especially the families and loved ones of those who lost their lives. we always remember them

input: Elaine Tieber and the doctor joke back and forth as he examines the small brown spots on her back. The doctor, Thomas Goleman, brims with a folksy, Southern manner, and Tieber has a sense of humor to match
continuation:
. Im not sure if youve noticed, but I dont have any hair on my head, she says. I think its time for me to shave it all off.

Goleman looks up from his computer screen. Thats funny, he says. I was just thinking about that myself.

Tieber is in her mid-60s and has been balding for more than 30 years. Shed like to get rid of her gray hair, too, but shes reluctant to go under the knife because she doesnt want to look like an old lady. Shes also concerned about the possible side effects of the surgery.

I dont know whats going to happen, she says. Will I be able to walk? Will I be able to talk?

Goleman smiles. Ill bet you wont be able to talk, he says. But we can always try.
translation:
Elaine Tybur and her doctor joke as they examine a small brown spot on her back. Dr. Thomas Goleman is full of folksy Southern manners, and Mr. Tyber has a sense of humor to match. "I don't know if you've noticed, but I don't have any hair on my head," she says. I think it's time for her to shave it all off.

Goleman looks up from his computer screen. "It's interesting," he says. I was just thinking about this myself.

Tyber is about 60 years old, but she has been going bald for over 30 years. She also wants to get rid of her gray hair, but she doesn't want to go under the knife because she doesn't want to look like her aunt. She is also concerned about possible side effects from her surgery.

"You never know what's going to happen," she says. Will I be able to walk? Will I be able to speak?

Goleman smiles. "I'm sure you can't talk," he says. But you can always try.

QUEENSLAND'S police minster has said the violent home invasions in Murgon last weekend were not targeted.
Mark Ryan said further police resources were immediately deployed to the area over the weekend after the Murgon police prosecutor
continuation:
's office issued a warrant for the arrest of two men accused of breaking into homes and assaulting residents.
The pair, aged 22 and 24, have been charged with aggravated burglary and assault occasioning actual bodily harm.
They are expected to appear in the Brisbane Magistrates Court on Tuesday.
Mr Ryan told The Courier-Mail he was "shocked" when he heard about the incidents.
He said it was "very concerning" that some of the victims had suffered serious injuries, including broken bones and facial lacerations.
Camera Icon Queensland Police Minister Mark Ryan. Picture: News Corp Australia, NCA NewsWire / Gaye Gerard
"It is very concerning," Mr Ryan said.
"We will be looking at this very closely."
Mr Ryan said the state government would provide more funding to local police forces to help them deal with crime.
"We will be providing additional funding to our police forces to ensure they can continue to respond to these types of crimes," he said.
"We want to make sure that we are doing everything we can to keep our communities safe."
Mr Ryan said he hoped the incident would serve as a wake-up call for people to think twice before committing crimes.
"I

input:
Argentina labor's umbrella organization CGT, has organized a strike for Monday to protest the economic reforms being implemented y the administration of president Mauricio Macri's business friendly administration.
Tens of thousands of people have marched on Saturday in central
continuation:
Buenos Aires and other cities across the country to demand an end to the austerity measures that have been imposed by Macri's government since taking office in December 2015.
The protests were largely peaceful, but some protesters clashed with police, who used tear gas and water cannons to disperse them.
CGT said its members would walk off the job from 9 a.m. (0800 GMT) until 1 p.m. (1200 GMT).
Macri's government has cut public spending and raised taxes on gasoline and diesel as part of efforts to reduce Argentina's $100 billion current account deficit.
(Reporting by Jorge Otaola; Writing by Hugh Bronstein; Editing by Lisa Shumaker)

translation:
Argentina's umbrella trade union organization CGT called for a strike on Monday in protest of economic reforms under President Mauricio Macri's pro-business government.
Tens of thousands of people marched in central Buenos Aires and other cities across the country on Saturday to demand an end to the austerity measures imposed by Macri's government since he took office in December 2015.
The protests were largely peaceful, but some protesters clashed with police, who used tear gas and water cannon to disperse them.
CGT announced that its members will be absent from work from 9 a.m. (8 p.m. Japan time) to 1 p.m. (12:00 Japan time).
Macri's government has cut government spending and increased taxes on gasoline and diesel as part of a bid to reduce Argentina's $100 billion current account deficit.

input:
Julia M. Carpenter, a sophomore in chemical engineering, was found dead in her Random Hall dormitory room early Monday morning. She was 20 years old.
Carpenter was a member of Alpha Chi Sigma (AXE), a professional chemistry
continuation:
honor society, according to an email sent out by the universitys student newspaper, The Daily Pennsylvanian.
The cause of death is still under investigation and no suspects have been identified at this time, but police are not looking for anyone else in connection with the case.
Carpenter was last seen around 2:30 a.m. Monday when she left her room to go to the bathroom. Her roommate reported her missing after she didnt come back home from the bathroom.
Her family has set up a GoFundMe page to help cover funeral costs. As of Tuesday afternoon, it had raised more than $5,000 of its $10,000 goal.
We are heartbroken over the loss of our beautiful daughter, sister, niece, cousin, friend, and all-around wonderful human being, Julia Carpenter, the family said in a statement on the GoFundMe page. She was loved by everyone who knew her and we ask that you please keep us in your thoughts and prayers during this difficult time. We will provide updates as they become available. Thank you for your continued love and support.
A candlelight vigil will be held at 6 p.
translation:
Julia M. Carpenter, a sophomore chemical engineering major, was found dead in her Random Hall dorm room early Monday morning. She was 20 years old.
Carpenter was a member of Alpha Chi Sigma (AXE), a professional honor society for chemists, according to an email sent by the university's student newspaper, the Daily Pennsylvanian.
The cause of death is still under investigation and no suspects have been identified at this time, but police are not searching for anyone else in connection with the incident.
Carpenter was last seen around 2:30 a.m. Monday when she left her room to go to the bathroom. Her roommate reported her missing after she did not return home from the bathroom.
Her family has set up a GoFundMe page for her to help cover her funeral expenses. As of Tuesday afternoon, the company had raised more than $5,000 of its $10,000 goal.
In a statement on the GoFundMe page, the family said they are heartbroken by the loss of Julia Carpenter, a beautiful daughter, sister, niece, cousin, friend, and wonderful person in every way. She was loved by all who knew her. We ask that you please keep us in your thoughts and prayers during this difficult time. We will provide updates as they become available. Thank you for your continued love and support.
A candlelight vigil will be held from 6 p.m.

input: The Dow Jones today projected a 100-point gain in pre-market hours, as investors continue to assess the impact of growing trade tensions between the United States and China. This morning's rally comes after the Dow erased a 700-point loss during Wednesday
continuation:
s trading session. The S&P 500 is up 0.2% while the Nasdaq Composite is up 0.1%.

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said on Tuesday that he would meet with his Chinese counterpart, Vice Premier Liu He, this week in an effort to reach a trade deal by the end of the year. President Donald Trump has threatened to slap additional tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese goods if no progress is made in the talks. Investors have been concerned about the potential economic fallout from the escalating trade war between the two largest economies in the world.

Here are five things you need to know before the market opens:

1. The U.S. dollar is rising against major currencies. The greenback rose against the Japanese yen, the Swiss franc and the British pound. The dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of six other currencies, was up 0.3% at 97.844.

2. Oil prices are higher. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures for November delivery were up 1.6% at $54.16 per barrel. Brent crude oil futures for November delivery were up 1.5% at $61.50
translation:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was expected to rise 100 points in today's premarket hours as investors continue to weigh the impact of escalating U.S.-China trade tensions. This morning's rally came after the Dow Jones Industrial Average recovered a 700-point loss during Wednesday's trading. The S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.1%.

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said Tuesday that he will meet with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He this week to try to reach a trade deal by the end of the year. President Donald Trump has threatened to impose additional tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese goods if negotiations do not progress. Investors are concerned about the potential economic impact of an escalating trade war between the world's two largest economies.

Here are five things to know before the market opens.

1. The US dollar is appreciating against major currencies. The US dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen, Swiss franc and British pound. The dollar index, which measures the dollar's value against a basket of six other currencies, rose 0.3% to 97.844.

2. Oil prices are rising. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures for November delivery rose 1.6% to $54.16 a barrel. Brent crude oil futures for November delivery rose 1.5% to $61.50.

input: CANBERRA, Australia -- A four-year search of the depths of the Indian Ocean has failed to find Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. But the unprecedented sonar hunt for the missing airliner might be close to solving 19th century mysteries - the locations of
continuation:
some of the world's most famous shipwrecks, including the Titanic and the RMS Lusitania.

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) said on Thursday it had detected a "possible signal" in the area where the plane disappeared in March 2014 with 239 people on board. It was not immediately clear what the signal was or how long it would take to analyze its data.

"This is the first time that we've been able to detect a potential signal from the bottom of the ocean," ATSB chief commissioner Greg Hood told reporters at a news conference in Canberra.

"We are hopeful that this will provide us with an indication as to whether or not there is something down there."

Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said he hoped the new findings would help solve the mystery of what happened to MH370.

"It is very difficult to understand why someone would do such a thing," Mahathir told reporters in Kuala Lumpur. "But I am sure they did it because they were disturbed by something."

He added: "I hope that we can find the truth and bring closure to the families who have lost their loved ones."
translation:
CANBERRA, Australia  A four-year search in the deep waters of the Indian Ocean has failed to locate Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. The world's most famous shipwrecks, including the Titanic and the RMS Lusitania.

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) said on Thursday it had detected a "possible signal" in the area where a plane with 239 people on board disappeared in March 2014. It wasn't immediately clear what the signal was or how long it would take to analyze that data.

"This is the first time we've been able to detect a potential signal from the ocean floor," ATSB chief Greg Hood told reporters at a news conference in Canberra.

Hopefully this will let us know if there is anything out there.

Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said he hoped the new findings would help solve the mystery of what happened to Flight MH370.

"It's very difficult to understand why someone would do something like that," Mahathir told reporters in Kuala Lumpur. "But I'm sure they did it because something was bothering them."

He added: "I hope we can find the truth and bring closure to the families who have lost their loved ones."

input: A police chase that began in Norwalk early this morning ended in Des Moines as the man being chased jumped to his death from a parking ramp. Norwalk Police Chief Eddie Kuhl says it began with a call of a person who was possibly suicidal who
continuation:
had barricaded himself inside an apartment building on the 200 block of North Main Street.
Start the conversation, or Read more at KCCI-TV Des Moines. Sign up for our daily newsletter and get breaking news alerts delivered to your email inbox every afternoon.
Kuhl says officers were able to make contact with the man around 2:30 a.m., but when they tried to arrest him, he took off running. The chase went through several Iowa cities before reaching Des Moines, where the man jumped out of the car and fell to the ground. He was taken into custody without further incident.
The mans name has not yet been released. The cause of death is under investigation by the Polk County Medical Examiners Office.

translation:
A police pursuit that began early this morning in Norwalk ended in Des Moines when the chased man jumped off a parking lot ramp to his death. input:
When a South Carolina man found a Waffle House's only employee asleep, he decided to make the food himself.
Alex Bowen was returning from a night of drinking when he visited the restaurant to satisfy an early-morning food craving.
He waited
continuation:
in line for more than an hour before ordering his usual breakfast  waffles and hash browns.
Bowen told The Post and Courier that he didnt think anything of it at the time, but as he sat down at the table, he noticed one of the employees had fallen asleep on the counter.
I thought she was just sleeping or something, he said. I wasnt even thinking about her being drunk.
The next thing he knew, he heard someone calling him over. He looked up to see a woman who appeared to have been passed out on the floor.
She was laying there with her arms crossed, Bowen said. I was like, Oh my God, what happened? She was still breathing. I asked her if she was okay, and she said she was fine.
Bowen called 911 and began performing CPR until first responders arrived. The woman was taken to a nearby hospital, where she was pronounced dead.
Its a horrible tragedy, Charleston County Coroner Margaret Fisher said.
Fisher said the woman died of blunt force trauma to the head.
translation:
A South Carolina man found the only employee at a Waffle House asleep and decided to cook his own food.
Alex Bowen had just returned from a night of drinking and stopped into the restaurant to satisfy his morning appetite.
He waited in line for more than an hour before ordering his usual breakfast of waffles and pancakes.
Bowen told The Post and Courier that he didn't think anything of it at the time, but when he sat down at his desk he noticed one of the employees dozing off at the counter.
"I thought she was just sleeping or something," he said. It never occurred to him that she was drunk.
The next thing he knew, he heard someone calling him. He looked up and saw a woman lying unconscious on the floor.
According to Bowen, she was lying there with her arms crossed. I thought, "Oh my God, what happened?" She was still breathing. I asked her if she was OK, and she said everything was OK.
Bowen called 911 and began CPR until paramedics arrived. The woman was taken to a nearby hospital, where she was pronounced dead.
"This is a terrible tragedy," said Charleston County Coroner Margaret Fisher. Fisher said the woman died from blunt force trauma to her head.

input:
The Senate is in a standoff regarding bills that would send relief funding to Puerto Rico, which is still recovering from Hurricane Maria.
On Monday (April 1), a measure was defeated in the Senate to provide disaster relief for Puerto Rico. Democrats voted against
continuation:
the bill because it did not include enough money for Puerto Ricos recovery efforts.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) has said that he does not intend to bring the bill back up for a vote until the House of Representatives votes on its version of the relief package.
McConnell told reporters that the Senate will wait and see what happens with the House bill before deciding whether to move forward with their own legislation.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-California) has already announced that she plans to bring her bill to the floor later this week.
Puerto Rico Governor Ricardo Rossell has called for Congress to approve an additional $50 billion to help the island recover from the devastation caused by Hurricane Maria.
Rossell has also asked President Donald Trump to declare a national emergency so that more federal aid can be provided to Puerto Rico.

The Senate is deadlocked over a bill that would direct relief funds to Puerto Rico as it recovers from Hurricane Maria.
The disaster relief package for Puerto Rico failed in the Senate on Monday (April 1). Democrats voted against the bill, saying it did not provide sufficient funding for Puerto Rico's recovery efforts.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said he would not put the bill up for another vote until the House votes on a version of the relief package.
McConnell told reporters that the Senate would wait to see how the House bill progresses before deciding whether to move forward with its own bill.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) has already announced that she plans to introduce legislation later this week.
Puerto Rico Governor Ricardo Rosell asked Congress to approve an additional $50 billion to help the country recover from the damage caused by Hurricane Maria.
Rossell also called on President Donald Trump to declare a national emergency so that more federal aid could be provided to Puerto Rico.

Stanning, 29, struggled with fatigue after regaining her spot in the team following a stint in the Army,
continuation:
while Glover, 31, was forced to withdraw from last years World Championships due to injury.
The pair won gold at London 2012 and Rio 2016 but missed out on selection for Tokyo 2020.
Glover said: Im just so happy to be able to do this. Its been a really tough year. I didnt know if I was going to make it back into the team.

input:
Sharp saw sales drop 12 percent in the nine months to December as competition increased in the LCD panel and television markets, it said Wednesday.
The company saw demand for flat-screen TVs drop in markets outside of Japan and was also pinched by price
continuation:
cuts from Chinese rivals.
Sharps net loss widened to 2.1 billion yen ($18 million) from 1.6 billion yen a year earlier, while its operating profit shrank to 441 million yen from 515 million yen.
Sales fell 11.4 percent to 7.8 trillion yen ($71 billion), with Sharp blaming unfavourable market conditions in China, South Korea and Taiwan.
Sharp shares were down more than 6 percent in early trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange before paring losses to be down 0.7 percent at 9,300 yen.
Sharp is struggling to turn around its business after a series of missteps over the past two years.
It has been forced to cut jobs, close factories and sell off assets in an effort to shore up its finances.
Last month, it said it had secured a $2.3 billion loan from a consortium led by Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group.
But analysts have warned that the company may not be able to raise enough money through debt or equity markets to stay afloat.
In October, Sharp slashed its full-year profit forecast, saying it expected to post a loss
translation:
Sharp said Wednesday that sales fell 12% in the nine months to December due to increased competition in the LCD panel and TV markets.
The company is facing declining demand for flat-screen TVs in markets outside Japan and price cuts from competitors in China.
Sharp's net loss widened to 2.1 billion yen ($18 million) from 1.6 billion yen a year earlier, and operating profit fell to 441 million yen from 515 million yen.
Sharp's sales fell 11.4% to 7.8 trillion yen ($71 billion) due to unfavorable market conditions in China, South Korea and Taiwan.
Sharp shares fell more than 6% in early trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, before erasing losses to end 0.7% lower at 9,300 yen.
Sharp is struggling to rebuild its business after repeated failures over the past two years.
The country was forced to cut jobs, close factories and sell assets to shore up its financial position.
The company announced last month that it had secured a $2.3 billion loan from a consortium led by Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group.
But analysts have warned that the company may not be able to raise enough money to survive through debt or the stock market.
In October, Sharp revised its full-year profit forecast downward, saying it expected to be in the red.

Before there was television, there was radio.
TV took radios shows, sponsors and many of its stars. It took the concept of networks, the 30-minute time slot and theme songs.
It duplicated most of radio
continuation:
s biggest hits, including The Star-Spangled Banner and God Bless America.
And it gave viewers a chance to see what their favorite entertainers were doing when they werent on TV.
In the early days of television, people had to wait for programs to be broadcast in order to watch them. That meant people had to stay up all night if they wanted to catch the latest episode of The Twilight Zone or The Dick Van Dyke Show.
But with radio, you could listen to any program at any time. You didnt have to worry about missing an important show because you were too tired to get out of bed in the middle of the night.
Here are 10 things you probably never knew about the history of radio.
1. The very first radio station in the U.S. was established in New York City on Dec. 12, 1877.
2. The first commercial radio station in the U.S. was owned by the National Association of Broadcasters (NAB) and began broadcasting on Jan. 1, 1927.
3. Radio is still used today in more than 200 countries.

They were once seen as the preserve of the geek, but nowadays personal opinion and diary pages - weblogs or "blogs" - are so powerful that huge corporations are taking an interest.
The sites that started as observational home pages for enthusiasts have become
continuation:
full-fledged publishing platforms with millions of visitors a month.
But what does it all mean? And how can you get in on the ground floor?
We've put together a guide to help you find your way through the world of blogs.
What is a blog?
A blog is a collection of short posts written by people who are interested in a particular topic. It's a place where people can share their thoughts and opinions about whatever they want.
You don't need to be a professional writer to start a blog. You just need to have something interesting to say.
How do you set up a blog?
There are many different ways to go about setting up a blog. The most important thing is to choose a domain name that reflects your business.
If you're selling products online, for example, then you'll probably want to use.com or.co.uk domains. If you're running a service, such as a web hosting company, you may want to use.net or.org.

ATTOCK  The Attock Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) on Sunday said extensive sensitive lists being maintained by different countries is hindering progress and growth of trade within Saarc region.
The last two decades have witnessed a number of attempts
continuation:
to isolate Pakistan from the international community, ACCI President Zahid Chaudhry said while addressing a press conference here at his office.
He said that it was the responsibility of the government to play its due role in promoting peace and stability in the region.
Zahid Chaudhry said that Pakistan had always played an active role in regional peace and security.
We should not allow any country to use our name for their own political gains, he added.
The ACCI president urged the world community to take notice of human rights violations in Indian Illegally Occupied Jammu and Kashmir (IIOJ&K).
He said that the situation in IIOJ&K was deteriorating day-by-day. He said that the Indian occupation forces were using pellet guns, teargas shells and live bullets against peaceful protesters.
Zahid Chaudhry also called upon the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) to take cognizance of the human rights violations in IIOJ&K.
He said that the UNSC should hold an emergency meeting to discuss the situation in IIOJ&K.
He said that Prime Minister Imran Khan had taken up the issue
translation:
Attock The Attock Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) said on Sunday that an extensive list of sensitive information controlled by different countries is hindering trade progress and growth in the Saaruk region.
Addressing a press conference at his office, ACCI Chairman Zahid Chaudhry said that over the past two decades, many attempts have been made to isolate Pakistan from the international community.
He said it was the responsibility of governments to play their due role in ensuring peace and stability in the region.
Zahid Chaudhry said Pakistan has always played an active role in ensuring peace and security in the region.
No country should be allowed to use our name for political purposes, he added.
The ACCI President called on the international community to pay attention to human rights violations in Indian Illegally Occupied Jammu and Kashmir (IIOJ&K).
He said the situation in IIOJ&K is worsening day by day. He said Indian occupation forces used guns, tear gas and live ammunition against peaceful demonstrators.
Zahid Chaudhry also called on the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) to take into account human rights violations in IIOJ&K.
He said the Security Council should hold an emergency meeting to discuss the situation in IIOJ&K.
He said Prime Minister Imran Khan had raised the issue.

Conrad and other Republicans have been pushing for years to cut spending and raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans as part of a balanced budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
