translation:
WASHINGTON (CNNMoney) The White House's initial proposal to avoid the fiscal cliff includes a $200 billion stimulus package. It's a stimulus package that Republican critics have railed against, arguing that the country needs to start cutting its debt.
But even deficit supporters say it's too little, too late.

There's no getting out of this mess, Democratic Senate Budget Chairman Kent Conrad told CNNMoney on Wednesday. We need to do more.

Conrad and other Republicans have long pushed for spending cuts and higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans as part of the U.S. Constitution's Balanced Budget Amendment.

However, President Barack Obama resisted the amendment, saying it would make it impossible for future presidents to address the country's long-term fiscal problems.

The White House's latest proposal, released Tuesday, does not include cuts to welfare programs such as Medicare and Social Security. Instead, he calls for higher taxes on the top 2% of citizens and corporations.

President Obama also wants to raise the retirement age for people making more than $250,000 a year from 65 to 67. He wants to raise the capital gains tax rate from 20% to 25%.

It's unclear how much revenue these measures will generate, but the White House estimates they will increase capital gains.

input: Interior designer Abbe Fenimore knew that adding a kitchen island was one of the most important decisions shed make in remodeling her 1940s-era home in Dallas. A well-designed kitchen island can offer storage space, a work
continuation:
surface, and a place to prepare meals.

Fenimore, who is based in New York City, has designed kitchens for clients ranging from celebrities to Fortune 500 companies. Her clients have included Oprah Winfrey, Gwyneth Paltrow, George Clooney, and Tom Hanks. Im always looking for ways to make my clients lives easier, she says.

Fenimore wanted to create a space that would be inviting, functional, and comfortable for her clients. So when she saw an open kitchen island at a local furniture store, it seemed like the perfect solution. I loved the idea of having everything I needed right there in front of me, she says.

The Kitchen Island

The kitchen island is a versatile piece of furniture that can be used for many different purposes. It can serve as a work surface, a dining table, and even a coffee table. The design of the island also makes it easy to clean up after cooking. Its easy to wipe down with a damp cloth, Fenimore says. And you dont have to worry about spills or food getting on other surfaces.

Fenimore wanted to create a space that was attractive, functional, and comfortable for its customers. So when she saw an outdoor kitchen island at a local furniture store, it seemed like the perfect solution. I liked the idea of having everything I needed right in front of me, she says.

island kitchen

A kitchen island is a versatile piece of furniture that can be used for a variety of purposes. It can also be used as a work table, dining table, or coffee table. The island design makes cleaning up after cooking easy. "Stains can be easily wiped away with a damp cloth," says Fenimore. You don't have to worry about spilled liquids or food getting on other surfaces.

input: Ethiopia says despite its trade relations with Somalias breakaway enclave of Somaliland, it does not support the sovereignty of the self-declared republic. Ethiopian foreign minister Seyoum Mesfin says Somaliland deserves to be
continuation:
recognized as an independent state.

Mesfin made the remarks during a meeting in Addis Ababa on Thursday with Somali President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmaajo.

Somaliland has been under international sanctions since 1991, when the Horn of Africa nation broke away from Somalia following a civil war that killed more than 100,000 people and displaced hundreds of thousands.

Getachew Reda, a spokesman for the president, told The Associated Press that the two leaders discussed the current political situation in the Horn of Africa region but did not give further details. He said they also agreed to work together to resolve the dispute between Eritrea and Ethiopia over the border between the two countries.

Eritrea and Ethiopia have been locked in a bitter dispute over the border since the early 1990s. A peace deal was signed in 2000, but both sides have accused each other of violating the terms of the agreement.

Ethiopia maintains that it does not support the sovereignty of the self-declared republic despite trade ties with the breakaway exclave of Somaliland. Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin said Somaliland deserves to be recognized as an independent state.

Mesfin made the announcement during a meeting with Somali President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmaajo in Addis Ababa on Thursday.

Somaliland has been under international sanctions since 1991, when the Horn of Africa country separated from Somalia following a civil war that killed more than 100,000 people and displaced hundreds of thousands.

Presidential spokesman Getachew Reda told The Associated Press that the two leaders discussed the current political situation in the Horn of Africa region but did not provide further details. He also said they agreed to work together to resolve the dispute between Eritrea and Ethiopia over the border between the two countries.

Eritrea and Ethiopia have been engaged in a fierce border war since the early 1990s. A peace agreement was signed in 2000, but both sides have accused each other of violating the terms of the agreement.

On Wednesday, the Ethiopian Foreign Ministry issued a statement calling on the UN Security Council to pass a resolution allowing Eritrean refugees to return to their homeland. The statement came days after the UNHCR called on Eritreans to return.

Attractive display of merchandise, like these antique bottles, attracts customers to your booth.
Every clothing store owner wants to see heavy traffic on the sales floor, but sales associates often need motivation to persuade the shopper to turn "I'm just looking
continuation:
" into "I want to buy."
The best way to do that is to show them something they've never seen before.
That's why it's so important to make sure you have a variety of products on display.
If you don't, you'll end up with empty shelves and people wandering around aimlessly trying to find what they're looking for.
So how do you create a display that will attract shoppers?
Here are some ideas:
1. Use a variety of colors.
Shoppers love to look at clothes in different shades of blue, red, or green.
But if you only have a few items in each color, they won't be able to tell the difference between them.
To get shoppers' attention, try using more than one color.
For example, you could have a light blue shirt and dark blue pants, or a light blue shirt and dark blue pants.
You can also use two or three different shades of the same color, such as a light blue shirt and dark blue jeans.
2. Have a lot of options.
It's not enough to just have one type of product on display.
Instead, you should have lots of options.
This will help

Friday, the Fourth National Climate Assessment was released. Its a sobering look at the economic and physical effects of climate change in the United States, and where those changes are leading.
At 1,656 pages, the report is massive
continuation:
, but its not hard to get lost in it. Here are some key takeaways:
Climate Change Is Already Happening
Climate change is already affecting our lives in ways we didnt even know were possible.
The report found that extreme weather events like heat waves, droughts, floods, and wildfires have become more frequent, intense, and destructive over the last 50 years. These events cost us billions of dollars each year, and theyre getting worse.
For example, in 2018 alone, the U.S. spent about $7 billion on natural disasters, including hurricanes, wildfires, floods, and tornadoes. And that number is only expected to go up.
We can expect these costs to increase substantially as global temperatures continue to rise, said Michael Mann, a professor of atmospheric science at Penn State University, in an interview with The Washington Post. If we dont act now, were going to be paying for this for decades, if not centuries to come.
In other words, theres no time to waste when it comes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Its a wake-

Mr Clegg had done a Greta Garbo... I vant to be alone!
Anyone seen our Cleggy? Lib Dem MPs sat there looking faintly sorrowful, like children who had just booted their football over the garden fence. This was
continuation:
the moment when they realised that they were going to have to do something about their partys disastrous performance in last nights European Parliament elections.
The Liberal Democrats won only one seat in Scotland and lost all but two of its seats in England and Wales. That is not good news for Mr Clegg and his deputy Nick Clegg. It means that the party will have to work very hard to win back those voters who deserted it at the last election.
But what does this mean for Mr Clegg and Mr Cleggs future as Deputy Prime Minister and leader of the Liberal Democrats? The answer is simple: nothing. They are still safe from any immediate danger of losing their jobs.
In fact, they may even be able to count on the support of some of the other senior members of the Cabinet, such as Foreign Secretary William Hague and Home Secretary David Blunkett.
However, if Mr Clegg and Mr Cleggs party continue to lose votes in the next General Election, then they could well find themselves in a difficult position.
That is because, unlike the Labour Party under Jeremy Corbyn, the Liberal Democrats have never really been able to establish themselves as a mainstream political force in Britain

input: Infertility is one of the most difficult problems a couple can go through, and many people find discussing the issue with friends and family only makes things worse. A new study found that there are differences in the way men and women share information about their fertility
continuation:
struggles.

The study was conducted by researchers at the University of Southern California (USC) and published in the journal Social Psychological and Personality Science.

We wanted to see if we could get some insight into how men and women talk about infertility, said lead author Dr. Sarah Lai, an assistant professor in USCs Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism, in a press release. We were also interested in whether or not it might be possible to use this research to help couples who are struggling to conceive.

The researchers asked more than 1,000 participants to fill out a survey that included questions about how often they discussed fertility issues with friends and family, as well as how much they felt comfortable sharing these topics with others. The results showed that men and women had very different attitudes when it came to discussing fertility issues.

For example, while women were more likely to say that they shared their infertility struggles with close friends and family, men were less likely to do so. Men were also more likely to say that they did not want to discuss their fertility struggles with anyone other than their doctor.

Its really important for couples to know that

This is our last day of discussing Betty Friedan's The Feminine Mystique. Join us at 3pm for a live chat and then follow along on Twitter using the hashtag #newmystique.
 Friedan is very interested in female
continuation:
sexuality, but she doesnt want to talk about it too much because it can be distracting. Instead, she wants to focus on how women are treated by menand what we can do about it.
 In her book, Friedan argues that women have always been oppressed by men, but theyve only recently become aware of their own oppression.
 Friedan believes that women need to take control of their lives, which is why she advocates for abortion rights.
 Friedan says that feminism is not a movement against men; rather, its a movement for women.

In this episode of the New York Times Book Review podcast, author and feminist activist Gloria Steinem sits down with editor-in-chief Margaret Atwood to discuss her latest novel, The Handmaids Tale.

The Handmaids Tale takes place in a dystopian future where the United States has declared war on Gilead, a totalitarian society ruled by an all-male ruling class. The story follows Offred (played by Elisabeth Moss), a young woman who becomes pregnant after being raped by Commander Waterford (Yvonne Strahovski).

 Friedan is very interested in women's sexuality, but she doesn't want to talk about it much because it can be distracting. Instead, she wants to focus on how men treat women and what we can do about it.

 She believes that Friedan should control her own life and that is why she advocates for her right to an abortion.

What Happened in Cockpit of Flight 370?
Former accident investigator Steven Wallace speaks to circumstances if flight path was pre-programmed into the computer.
The pilot and first officer of the missing plane, both of them Malaysian, have come under
continuation:
intense scrutiny since their disappearance on March 8 with 239 passengers and crew on board from Kuala Lumpur bound for Beijing.
In an exclusive interview with Voice of America (VOA), former accident investigator Steven Wallace said that he believes it is possible that the pilots were deliberately diverted to avoid detection by radar.
Wallace, a retired U.S. Air Force colonel, has spent more than 30 years investigating air accidents around the world.
He told VOA: "I think it's very likely that they were programmed to go somewhere other than where they were supposed to be going."
"They could have been programmed to go over the southern Indian Ocean or off the coast of Africa," Wallace added.
Malaysian authorities believe that the Boeing 777-200ER crashed into the sea after running out of fuel in the early hours of March 8 while en route from Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia to Beijing Capital International Airport (BCIA).
Investigators are still trying to piece together what happened to the plane, which disappeared from radar screens at 1:40 a.m. local time (10:40 p.m. GMT) as it flew across the South China Sea toward the Strait of Malacca, one of the
translation:
What happened in the cockpit of Flight 370?
Former aviation accident investigator Stephen Wallace describes a situation where the flight path was pre-programmed into the computer.
The missing plane's pilot and co-pilot, both Malaysian nationals, have been the subject of intense scrutiny since they went missing on March 8. There were 239 passengers and crew on the flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.
Former aviation accident investigator Stephen Wallace said in an exclusive interview with Voice of America (VOA) that he believes the pilot may have intentionally veered off course to avoid radar detection. .
Mr. Wallace is a retired U.S. Air Force colonel who spent more than 30 years investigating plane crashes around the world.
"I think it's very likely that they were programmed to go somewhere other than where they were supposed to go," he told VOA.
"It could be programmed to fly in the southern Indian Ocean or off the coast of Africa," Wallace added.
Malaysian authorities believe that the Boeing 777-200ER plane ran out of fuel and crashed into the sea on its way from Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) to Beijing Capital International Airport (BCIA) in the early hours of March 8.
Investigators are still trying to determine what happened to the plane, which flew across the South China Sea toward the Strait of Malacca at 1:40 a.m. local time (22:40 GMT).

Smoking rates in US have fallen to all-time low, but how did they ever get so high?
(THE CONVERSATION) The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention calls cigarette smoking the leading cause of preventable disease and death
continuation:
in the United States. Smoking kills more than 480,000 Americans each year and is responsible for an estimated $200 billion in health care costs each year.
Cigarette smoking has declined dramatically since its peak in the 1960s and 1970s, when it accounted for about 40% of the U.S. adult population. It now accounts for less than 10% of the U.S. adult population.
But there are still a lot of people who smoke. According to the American Lung Association, more than 6 million adults in the U.S. smoke daily. And that number is expected to rise as more young people start using e-cigarettes.
Why does smoking remain such a big problem in the U.S.? A new study from researchers at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health provides some answers.
How did we get here?
The history of smoking in the U.S. can be traced back to the early 20th century, when tobacco was introduced into the country by immigrants from Eastern Europe. In the 1930s, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) began to crack down on the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products. The FDA banned smoking in public places in
translation:
Smoking rates in the United States are at record lows, but why did they get so high in the first place?
(Conversation) The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lists smoking as the leading cause of preventable illness and death in the United States. Smoking kills more than 480,000 Americans each year and costs approximately $200 billion in annual health care costs.
Cigarette smoking has declined sharply since its peak in the 1960s and 1970s, when it accounted for about 40% of U.S. adults. They currently make up less than 10% of the US adult population.
However, there are still many smokers. According to the American Lung Association, more than 6 million adults in the United States smoke daily. This number is expected to increase as more young people start using e-cigarettes.
Why does smoking remain such a big problem in the United States? A new study by researchers at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health has some answers.
how did we get here?
The history of smoking in the United States dates back to the early 20th century, when tobacco was introduced by immigrants from Eastern Europe. In the 1930s, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) began tightening its control over the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products. FDA banned smoking in public places

input:
Is a custom mouthpiece worth it?
Discussion in 'Standup Technique' started by ForeverFiending, May 4, 2008.
I was going to get a custom mouthgaurd for an upcoming MT fight, but one of my coaches said
continuation:
that I should just buy a new mouthguard and not worry about the custom part.
I'm wondering if this is true or if there are other ways to improve your technique without having to spend a ton of money on a new piece.
My coach also told me that I shouldn't be worried about getting knocked out because I can take a lot of punishment.
Any advice from anyone who has had experience with custom mouthguards?
I've been doing standup for about 3 years now.
I have a pretty good technique, but I still feel like I could use some help.
My biggest problem is that I seem to get knocked out fairly easily.
I don't think it's due to my technique being bad (it isn't).
It's probably more of a mental thing than anything else.
When I first started, I would get knocked out a few times a week.
Now I only get knocked out once or twice a month.
But I still feel like I could do better.
So I'm looking for any tips / suggestions you guys might have.

I have a pretty good technique, but I still feel like I could use

input:
China pledges "notable" emissions cut but some find lack of firm number disappointing.
But the leader of the world's biggest emitter dashed hopes that he would unveil a hard target to kickstart stalled climate talks due to be reconvened in
continuation:
Glasgow later this year, saying it was too early to make such a commitment.
Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, speaking at the UN Climate Change Conference (COP25) in Madrid on Monday, said China would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060.
He did not give an exact figure or say how China would meet those targets, which are seen as crucial to keeping global temperature rises below 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels to avoid the worst impacts of climate change.
The pledge came after President Xi Jinping promised during his first summit with US President Joe Biden last month to do more to combat climate change than previous Chinese leaders had done.
"We will strive to achieve carbon neutrality by the end of the century," Li told the virtual meeting.
"We will also continue to take concrete actions to enhance the efficiency of our energy consumption and promote green growth."
Li also called for the international community to help developing countries adapt to the effects of climate change, including by providing them with financial support and technical assistance.
China is the world's top emitter of greenhouse gases, responsible for about a quarter of all global emissions, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA).

input:
Ex-chief of general staff among more than 100 former officers accused of overthrowing government in 1997.
A former Turkish army chief has gone on trial in Ankara along with more than 100 other suspects for allegedly plotting to overthrow the Turkish government 16 years ago
continuation:
, state-run Anadolu news agency reported on Wednesday.
The case is part of a wider investigation into alleged coup attempts against President Recep Tayyip Erdoan and his inner circle that have been under way since July 2016.
Former Chief of General Staff Necmettin Erbakan, who was sacked by Erdoan last year over allegations of corruption, went on trial on Tuesday alongside 94 others, including retired generals and admirals.
Erdoan accused Erbakan of being involved in a "coup plot" against him when he served as president from 2003 to 2014.
Erbakan has denied any wrongdoing and said the charges were politically motivated.
His trial comes at a time of heightened tensions between Turkey and the United States, its most important ally in the Middle East.
Ankara accuses Washington of supporting Kurdish militants in Syria's northeast, an allegation the US denies. The two countries are also at odds over Ankara's purchase of Russian S-400 missile defence systems.
On Tuesday, the US State Department said it was "deeply concerned" about the trial.
"We continue to strongly support the rule of law and respect for due process," the department said in a statement.
translation:
The former chief of staff is one of more than 100 former officers accused of subversion in 1997.

A former Turkish military commander is on trial in Ankara along with more than 100 other suspects on charges of plotting to overthrow the Turkish government 16 years ago, state news agency Anadolu reported on Wednesday.

The case is part of a broader investigation into an alleged coup attempt against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his top aides that has been ongoing since July 2016.

Former chief of staff Necmettin Erbakan, who was fired by Erdogan last year on corruption charges, appeared in court on Tuesday along with 94 others, including retired generals and admirals.

Erdogan has accused Erbakan of being involved in a "coup plot" against him during his presidency from 2003 to 2014.

Erbakan has denied any wrongdoing and claims the charges are politically motivated.
His trial comes amid rising tensions between Turkey and the United States, its most important ally in the Middle East.
Ankara accuses the U.S. of supporting Kurdish militants in northeast Syria, a charge the U.S. denies. The two countries also have differences over Ankara's purchase of Russian-made S-400 missile defense systems.
The U.S. State Department said on Tuesday it was "deeply concerned" by the trial.
"We remain strong supporters of the rule of law and due process," the department said in a statement.

input:
Jan. 25 - A child is pulled from rubble in Aleppo while Syria's civil war foes held their first face-to-face meeting at the start of talks to end nearly three years of conflict. Mana Rabiee reports.
The Syrian opposition
continuation:
says it will not negotiate with President Bashar Assads regime until he gives up his nuclear weapons program, a demand that has been rejected by Russia as absurd and unrealistic.
The United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution last week calling for an immediate cease-fire and a political transition to end the violence in Syria.
But Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Wednesday that the U.N.-led talks would be an exercise in futility unless there was a change in the Syrian governments attitude toward disarmament.
Lavrov told reporters after talks with his Turkish counterpart Mevlut Cavusoglu in Ankara: We have no illusions about the prospects for success of these negotiations.
He added: If we are going to achieve any results, then we need to get rid of this absurd idea that the regime should give up its nuclear program.
Russia and China have vetoed two previous attempts by the 15-member Security Council to impose sanctions on Syria over its use of chemical weapons.
Copyright  2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, written or redistributed
translation:
January 25 - A child is pulled from the rubble in Aleppo as Syria's civil war rivals hold their first face-to-face talks to begin talks aimed at ending nearly three years of conflict. Mana Rabbi reported this.
Syrian rebels say they will not negotiate until President Bashar al-Assad's government abandons its nuclear weapons program. Russia rejected this request as absurd and unrealistic.
Last week, the United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire and political transition to end the violence in Syria.
However, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Wednesday that UN-led talks will be futile unless there is a change in the Syrian government's stance on disarmament.
"We have no illusions about the prospects for success in these negotiations," Lavrov told reporters after talks with Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu in Ankara.
Additionally, he added, "If we want to achieve any results, the administration needs to get rid of the ridiculous idea that it has to abandon its nuclear program."
Russia and China have vetoed two previous attempts by the 15-nation Security Council to impose sanctions on Syria over its use of chemical weapons.
Copyright 2017 Associated Press. This material may not be published, broadcast, written or redistributed.

input: Looks like Apple wants a slice of the wearable camera action, based on recently awarded patents. The US Patents and Trademarks Office today awarded the iPhone maker a series of 34 patents, including one that details a GoPro-like action camera system.
continuation:
The patent, titled Method and Apparatus for Providing Real-Time Video Recording, was granted to Apple back in January. It describes a system that would allow users to capture video with their iPhones or other mobile devices, and then send it to a computer via Wi-Fi or Bluetooth. That data is then analyzed by an app, which would be able to display the video in real-time, as well as provide information about the users surroundings.

This isnt the first time weve heard of Apple working on something like this. In fact, earlier this year we reported that the Cupertino-based tech giant was working on its own version of the GoPro Hero3+ camera. At the time, a source told 9to5Mac that the companys efforts were aimed at creating a more affordable version of the popular action camera, rather than a full-blown replacement.

In any case, its still unclear whether or not Apple will actually go through with its plans to create its own action camera. Well have to wait and see.

[USPTO via MacRumors]

Image credit:

input:
THOUSAND OAKS, CA (RNN) - Less than two weeks after the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting that killed 11, another mass shooting has taken a dozen lives in California.
A gunman killed 12 people, including a sheriffs
continuation:
deputy, at a country music bar in Thousand Oaks on Wednesday night.
The suspect was identified as Ian David Long, a 56-year-old former Marine who had been fired from his job with the Ventura County Sheriffs Department.
He is accused of opening fire inside the Borderline Bar and Grill in Thousand Oaks at around 10:30 p.m. local time, killing 12 people and wounding several others before turning the gun on himself.
Thousand Oaks is located about 40 miles north of Los Angeles.
The victims have been identified by the Ventura County Medical Examiner-Coroners Office, which said they were between the ages of 18 and 60 years old.
Sheriff Geoff Dean told reporters he believed the shooter acted alone.
"We believe this to be an isolated incident," Dean said. "I don't think there's any threat to the general public."
President Donald Trump called the shooting horrific during a White House news conference Thursday morning.
"Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families. We also want to extend our deepest sympathies to the law enforcement officers and first responders who responded so heroically last night," he said.
Trump said
translation:
THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. (RNN) - Less than two weeks after the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting that killed 11 people, a new mass shooting in California has left more than a dozen people dead.
A gunman killed 12 people, including a sheriff's deputy, at a country music bar in Thousand Oaks on Wednesday night.
The suspect was identified as Ian David Long, 56, a retired Marine with the Ventura County Sheriff's Office.
He is suspected of opening fire at Borderline Bar and Grill in Thousand Oaks around 10:30 p.m. local time, he killed 12 people and injured several more before turning the gun on himself.
Thousand Oaks is located approximately 40 miles north of Los Angeles.
The Ventura County Coroner's Office has identified the victims and said they range in age from 18 to 60.
Sheriff Jeff Dean told reporters he believed the gunman acted alone.
"We believe this is an isolated incident," Dean said. He said: "I don't think there is a threat to the public."
President Donald Trump called the shooting horrific during a White House news conference Thursday morning.
"Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families. "We also want to express our deepest condolences to the law enforcement officers and first responders who so bravely responded last night." he said.

input:
While the large industrial complexes in northern Syria were once reminders of the strong economic ties between Ankara and Damascus, Aleppos businessmen now hold Turkey responsible for the destruction and looting of their factories.
It may not be a bright idea to introduce yourself
continuation:
as the man who saved Aleppo at a time when the city is on the verge of total collapse. But thats exactly what Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoan did in an interview with German magazine Der Spiegel published last week.
Erdoan was asked about the recent developments in Aleppo, which are being described as a humanitarian crisis by UN Secretary-General Antnio Guterres. The Turkish leader claimed that he had done all he could to save Aleppo, but that it was up to the Syrian government to do its part.
I have tried my best to help the people of Aleppo. I gave them everything they needed: food, water, medical supplies, fuel, electricity. And then the Syrian regime came in and destroyed everything, Erdoan said.
The Turkish president went on to say that he had no choice but to take action against Assads forces because they were destroying his countrys economy.
If we dont do something, there will be nothing left for our children and grandchildren. We cannot live like this any longer, Erdoan said.
He also accused the international community of turning a blind eye to the atrocities taking place
translation:
A large industrial park in northern Syria was once a reminder of the strong economic ties between Ankara and Damascus, but businessmen in Aleppo are now blaming Turkey for the destruction and looting of factories.
Pretending to be the man who saved Aleppo when the city is on the brink of complete collapse might not be the best idea. But that's exactly what Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoan said in an interview with the German magazine Der Spiegel published last week.
President Erdoan was asked about recent events in Aleppo, which UN Secretary-General Antnio Guterres called a humanitarian crisis. The Turkish leader said he had done everything possible to save Aleppo, but the Syrian government must play its part.
I did my best to help the people of Aleppo. I gave them everything they needed: food, water, medicine, fuel, electricity. Then the Syrian regime came and destroyed everything, Erdogan said.
The Turkish president went on to say that he has no choice but to take action against Assad's forces as they are destroying his country's economy.
If we do nothing, our children and grandchildren will have nothing left. We can no longer live like this, President Erdoan said.
He also accused the international community of turning a blind eye to the atrocities taking place.

input: Andrew P. Fitzgerald, 50, formerly of Plattsburgh, N.Y., passed away Tuesday, March 5, 2019, at Sarasota Memorial Hospital with his family by his side. He was born in Plattsburgh, N.Y.,
continuation:
the son of the late John and Mary (Baker) Fitzgerald.
He is survived by his loving wife of 25 years, Susan; three sons, Andrew, Michael and Matthew; a step-son, Christopher; a step-daughter, Kristin; two sisters, Linda and Kathy; and many nieces and nephews.
He was predeceased by his parents.
A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday, March 9, at 10 a.m. at St. Joseph Church, Plattsburgh. The Rev. Thomas O'Brien will officiate. Burial will follow in St. Joseph Cemetery. Visitation will be held Friday from 6 to 8 p.m. at the DellaVecchia Funeral Home, Plattsburgh.
Memorial contributions may be made to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105-9959.
To leave an online condolence, please visit www.dellavecchiafh.com.
Arrangements are under the direction of the DellaVecchia Funeral Home & Crematory, Plattsburgh.

Print

input: My son Kris, an Army Ranger, was one of the first killed in action on October 19, 2001, in Operation Rhino, our first incursion into Afghanistan right after 9/11. Kris had been in Ranger School during that attack on American soil
continuation:
, and his death was a shock to us all.

Kriss story is not unique. There are many other young men and women who have paid the ultimate price for their countrys commitment to freedom and democracy around the world.

I want to share with you a few things I learned from my sons service:

1. You never know what will happen when you put your life on the line, but you can be prepared for anything.

2. Its important to take care of your family while youre serving in the military.

3. The sacrifices made by our military families are immeasurable.

4. We owe it to our veterans to give them the support they need so they can continue to serve our nation.

5. Our veterans deserve the respect they have earned over the years.

6. And finally, we should never forget those who gave their lives for our freedoms.

In honor of Veterans Day, I encourage you to read some of the stories of the brave men and women who served in the U.S. Armed Forces, and thank them for their service.

Today, I

My son, Chris, an Army Ranger, was one of the first to be killed in action on October 19, 2001, during Operation Rhino, the first invasion of Afghanistan in the immediate aftermath of 9/11. Chris's story is not unique. There are many other young men and women around the world who have paid the ultimate price for their countries' commitment to freedom and democracy.

I would like to share some things I learned from his son's service.

1. You never know what will happen if you put your life at risk, but you can be prepared for anything.

2. It is important to take care of your family while in the military.

5. Our nation's veterans deserve the respect they have earned over the years.

6. Finally, we must never forget those who gave their lives for freedom.

In honor of Veterans Day, we encourage you to read the stories of the brave men and women who served in the U.S. military and thank them for their service.

input: Alastair Cook has been granted more time to decide his future as Test captain, with England having privately advised that Fridays meeting with the director of cricket, Andrew Strauss, will not be followed by a definitive announcement on the subject.
continuation:
Cook, who is contracted until the end of the 2015 Ashes series, has been under pressure from some quarters to relinquish the captaincy in favour of Joe Root or Eoin Morgan, but the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) are understood to have made it clear that they want him to make a final decision this week.

Strauss is due to meet the players at their training base at Edgbaston on Thursday morning before holding further talks with Cook later in the day. The ECB will then hold a press conference at 11am on Friday to announce whether Cook will continue as skipper.

Englands tour of South Africa begins in Pretoria on Saturday, and the first of three Tests against the Proteas begins in Durban on February 21. The second match takes place at Newlands in Cape Town on March 1, and the third at SuperSport Park in Johannesburg on March 5.

The ICC World Test Championship, which was introduced for the first time last year, has seen Australia retain the title after beating New Zealand 2-1 in a five-match series. India were crowned champions for the second successive year after defeating Sri Lanka 3-2 in a five-match series.
translation:
Alastair Cook has been given more time to decide on his future as Test captain, and England have privately said that Friday's meeting with Director of Cricket Andrew Strauss will not include a final announcement on the matter.

Cook, who is under contract until the end of the 2015 Ashes series, has been under pressure from some quarters to give up the captaincy in favour of Joe Root or Eoin Morgan, and it is believed the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) has done so. It is clear that they want him to make a final decision this week.

Strauss is due to meet the players at Edgbaston training ground on Thursday morning, before holding further talks with Cook later that day. The ECB will then hold a press conference at 11am on Friday to announce whether Cook will continue as captain.

England's tour of South Africa begins in Pretoria on Saturday, with the first of three Tests against the Proteas starting in Durban on February 21. The second match will be played at Newlands in Cape Town on March 1, and the third match at SuperSport Park in Johannesburg on March 5.

In the inaugural ICC World Test Championship last year, Australia defeated New Zealand 2-1 in five straight matches to defend their title. India defeated Sri Lanka 3-2 in five straight matches to win their second consecutive title.

input: (Leah Hogsten | The Salt Lake Tribune) Derek Miller, right, president and CEO of the Salt Lake Chamber, passes a pen to the city's business and civic leaders who gathered Thursday to sign the Utah Compact, initially adopted in 2010.
continuation:
SALT LAKE CITY  Business leaders from around the state gathered at the Utah State Capitol on Thursday to sign the Utah Compact, an agreement they hope will help them attract and retain top talent.

The compact, which was originally signed by Gov. Gary Herbert in 2010, has been amended several times since then, including last year when the Legislature passed a bill that would have made it easier for businesses to leave Utah if they didnt want to abide by certain labor laws.

Were here today to reaffirm our commitment to each other as we move forward, said Salt Lake City Mayor Jackie Biskupski. I think its important to note that this is not just about business. Its about families, its about education, its about health care, its about housing, its about jobs, its about infrastructure, its about quality of life, its about economic development, its about public safety. Its about all of those things.

Biskupski said she hopes the compact will become a model

Arsenal took a big step towards reaching the Europa League semi-finals after a 4-1 rout of CSKA Moscow and Atletico Madrid did the same with a 2-0 home win over Sporting Lisbon on Thursday.
Lazio also stayed on
continuation:
course for a place in next seasons Champions League by beating Fiorentina 1-0 at home thanks to an early goal from Sergej Milinkovic-Savic.
In the other quarter-final second leg matches, Roma beat Shakhtar Donetsk 3-2 on aggregate and Sevilla won 5-4 on away goals after extra time in their last 16 tie against Napoli.
CSKA had taken the lead through Yevhen Konoplyanka but Arsenal levelled when Granit Xhaka headed in Mesut Ozils cross before Alexandre Lacazette put the hosts in front with his first goal for the club.
Alexandre Lacazette celebrates scoring Arsenal's fourth goal against CSKA Moscow (Nick Potts/PA)
Shkodran Mustafi then made it 2-0 when he turned in Kieran Tierneys cross and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang completed the rout with a fine finish.
It was the first time Arsenal have scored more than three goals in a European match this season and they are now two games away from reaching the last four of Europes second-tier club competition for the first time since 2004.

input: That it's such a hidden statistic, however, is an embarrassing reflection of our collective ignorance. Hundreds more people died by suicide in Oregon in 2017 than by traffic crashes, firearms or drug overdose. The suicide rate in Oregon is well above the national average
continuation:
and has been steadily increasing for decades.

The state Department of Human Services reports that nearly 1,000 Oregonians die by suicide each year. That's about three times the number who die from motor vehicle accidents, two times the number who die from firearms, and four times the number who die from drug overdoses.

And yet we don't hear much about these deaths. It's as if they never happened.

We're not alone. According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, suicide is the 10th leading cause of death in the United States and the second leading cause of death among young adults between the ages of 20 and 34.

In 2016, there were an estimated 47,000 suicides in the U.S., according to the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. In Oregon, the number was even higher: 49,000.

Oregon's high suicide rate isn't just a problem for families and friends; it's a public health issue. A recent study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that suicide rates have risen across the country over the past 25 years.

Suicide is one of the most preventable causes of death in the U.S., but

Every year in sports, theres a breakout player or a breakout moment that inspires the masses to dig deeper for their dreams.
Justin Holiday may be the next breakout story.
Now a mainstay in the NBA, Holiday is seeing a
continuation:
meteoric rise to stardom after being drafted by the Philadelphia 76ers in the first round of the 2014 NBA Draft.
The 21-year-old point guard has already been named an All-Star and is averaging career highs in points per game (17.6) and assists per game (5.8).
Holiday was also named to the Eastern Conference All-Rookie Team last season.
Hes had his fair share of ups and downs this season, but hes finally starting to show signs of life.
Here are three things we learned from Holidays performance against the Toronto Raptors on Tuesday:
1. Hes still got it
Its easy to forget just how good Holiday can be when hes not playing at a high level.
Last season, Holiday averaged 16.7 points, 4.3 rebounds and 3.0 assists per game.
But this season, Holiday has seen a drastic improvement.
In his last five games, hes averaging 17.2 points, 5.9 rebounds and 4.4 assists per game while shooting 50 percent from the field and 38 percent from three-point range.
Holiday

continuation:
with its surroundings.

Inside, however, the Pilot is a different story. Its one of the best-looking crossovers on the market, if not the best-looking. Its interior design, which was first unveiled at the 2017 North American International Auto Show (NAIAS) in Detroit, has been refined over the last few years, and now its finally ready for prime time.

Hondas designers have done a great job of making the Pilot look more premium than it actually is. The front grille and headlamps are distinctive, as are the LED daytime running lights and the chrome trim around the windows and door handles. The Pilots tail lamps are also unique, and they give the crossover an aggressive appearance.

On the inside, the Pilots cabin feels like a luxury car. The seats are comfortable and supportive, and the center console has plenty of storage space. The Pilots large touchscreen infotainment system is easy to use, and it features Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility.

Which college degrees are the most and least valuable to Floridians?
The ubiquitous career advice hurled at young people sounds so simple. Make a career of your passions.
For some, its pitch perfect. They know what they love
continuation:
to do. They just need to find a way to make it happen. For others, its easier said than done.
A new report from WalletHub finds that Florida has one of the highest concentrations of bachelors degrees in the U.S. It also ranks among the top 10 states with the lowest average salary for those who have earned a bachelors degree.
WalletHub used data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics to rank all 50 states based on the value of their bachelors degree programs. The rankings were based on factors such as graduation rates, job placement rates, cost of tuition and student debt.
Heres a look at how Florida stacks up against the rest of the country when it comes to which college degrees are most and least valuable to residents:

input: The Vietnamese version of the 2010 census questionnaire used the words dieu tra to describe the population tally  but what the words really conveyed was something like a communist government investigation. On Korean forms, county was translated
continuation:
as municipality or district, and township was translated as subdistrict.

But in Vietnams case, the word dieu tra is not used at all. Instead, it is replaced by an abbreviated form of the same name: Di Tnh Trng. The abbreviation stands for Di Tnh Trng (Vietnam).

It is not clear why the Vietnamese government decided to use this abbreviation rather than the full name of the country, which would be Di Tnh Quc H Ch Minh (Vietnams northernmost province), or Di Tnh Bc Giang (Vietnams southernmost province) or Di Tnh Ph Thy (Vietnams easternmost province).

The second phase will start next week and last about four weeks.
Officials said it's part of a larger effort to improve pedestrian safety.

input: Despite Israels siege of Gaza, and the escalating displacement in the Negev and East Jerusalem, Palestinians have some reason to celebrate. In Washington a food co-op has passed a resolution calling for a boycott of Israeli products, confirming that
continuation:
Palestinian solidarity is alive and well.

The Food Co-op of Greater Washington (FCGW) voted unanimously last week to pass a resolution calling on its members to refrain from purchasing, using, or consuming any product or service produced or marketed by an Israeli entity that violates international law, including the Fourth Geneva Convention.

The vote came after months of deliberation, during which FCGWs board of directors debated whether to take a stand on the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The board ultimately decided to go ahead with the resolution.

We felt it was our moral obligation to make a statement about the human rights violations taking place in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, said FCSW board member and former Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry.

Kerry, who served as US secretary of state under President Barack Obama, has long been one of the most outspoken critics of the Israeli governments policies toward the Palestinians. He told Haaretz earlier this year that he would not rule out running for president in 2016.

Im not going to tell you Ill never run for office again, Kerry said.
translation:
Despite Israel's blockade of the Gaza Strip and growing displacement in the Negev and East Jerusalem, Palestinians have reason to celebrate. In Washington, food cooperatives passed a resolution calling for a boycott of Israeli products, reaffirming that Palestinian solidarity is alive and well.

Last week, the Food Cooperatives of Greater Washington (FCGW) passed a resolution calling on its members to refrain from purchasing, using, or consuming products and services manufactured or sold by Israeli organizations that violate international law, including the Fourth Geneva Convention. It was passed unanimously.

The vote comes after months of debate as FCGW's board debated whether to take a position on Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Congress ultimately decided to pass the resolution.

We believe it is a moral obligation to speak out about human rights abuses occurring in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, said FCSW Director and former Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry.

Kerry, who served as US secretary of state under President Barack Obama, has long been one of the most outspoken critics of the Israeli government's policies toward the Palestinians. Earlier this year, he told Haaretz newspaper that he had not ruled out running for president in 2016.

"He's not going to say he's never going to run for president again," Kelly said.

input:
Amnesty International calls upon Hamas (the Islamic Resistance Movement) to commit unequivocally to abide by international law, respect the rights of all Palestinians across the political spectrum and repudiate its policy of targeting Israeli civilians.
"As it prepares to form the next
continuation:
government in Gaza, Hamas must ensure that it does not allow itself to be used as a proxy for Israel," said Lynn Maalouf, Amnesty International's Middle East and North Africa Research Director. "The Palestinian people are entitled to live in peace and security with their neighbours, but this can only happen if there is an end to the conflict between Israel and Hamas."
Hamas has been accused of carrying out indiscriminate rocket attacks on civilian targets in Israel, including schools, hospitals and mosques. It has also been accused of firing rockets into southern Israel from densely populated areas such as Rafah and Beit Lahiya, which have led to numerous deaths and injuries.
In response to these alleged violations of international humanitarian law, Amnesty International has called on the international community to take action against Hamas and other armed groups operating in the Gaza Strip.
"We urge the international community to impose sanctions on those responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity in the Gaza Strip," added Ms. Maalouf. "This should include the freezing of any assets they may have in countries where human rights abuses are taking place, as well as travel bans and arms embargoes. We also call on the UN Human Rights Council to establish an independent commission of inquiry to
translation:
Amnesty International urges Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement) to clearly abide by international law, respect the rights of all Palestinians regardless of political affiliation, and abandon its policy of targeting Israeli civilians. I'm asking you to make a promise.

continuation:
VADC).

Riverbeds new VADC is based on the same architecture as its previous version, but with some key changes. For one, it now offers support for Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) and Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3), making it easier for customers to move workloads to the cloud. It also has a new feature called Stingray Orchestrator, which lets customers orchestrate multiple instances of the VADC into a single cluster, so that they can scale up or down as needed.

In addition to EBS and S3 support, the new VADC will also offer support for Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), Google Cloud Platform (GCP), Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI), Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), VMware vSphere, and OpenStack, among others.

This is not surprising, since it is much cheaper to hire a lawyer for a trial than it is to pay for an attorney who will represent you in a court of law. It also makes sense if you want to avoid the embarrassment of being found guilty by a jury of your peers, especially if you have been accused of a serious crime such as murder or rape.

The problem with hiring defense lawyers is that they can be very expensive. For example, according to one estimate, it costs more than $1,000 per hour to defend a criminal defendant in Moscow. This figure does not take into account the time spent waiting for the trial to start, or the cost of travel to and from the courthouse. input:
A comeback story was crowned with a happy ending at Wimbledon on Saturday  but it was the revitalised Angelique Kerber rather than Serena Williams who lifted the trophy.
With the Duchesses of Sussex and Cambridge in the Royal Box and Tiger
continuation:
King star Joe Exotic in the stands, the crowd were treated to an electrifying match between two of the sports biggest stars.
Kerber had lost her last three matches at the All England Club before this years tournament, but she won 6-4 7-6 (7/3) in just under two hours to become the first German woman to win the title since Steffi Graf in 1988.
The 27-year-old said: Im very happy. I didnt know if I would be able to play here again. Its a dream come true for me.
It is the second Grand Slam title for Kerber, who also won the US Open in 2018, and she will go up against either Ashleigh Barty or Elina Svitolina in the semi-finals.
Williams has not won a major title since winning the 2017 Australian Open, while Barty has never been past the fourth round at Wimbledon.
But the 36-year-old former world number one showed no signs of rustiness as she fought back from a set down to beat Petra Kvitova 4-6 6-2 6
translation:
The comeback had a happy ending at Wimbledon on Saturday, but it wasn't Serena Williams who won the trophy, but a new Angelique Kerber.
With the Duchess of Sussex and the Duchess of Cambridge in the Royal Box and Tiger King star Joe Exotic in the stands, the audience watched an exciting match between two of the sport's biggest stars.
Kerber had lost her last three matches at the All England Club before this tournament, but won 6-4, 7-6 (7/3) in less than two hours, becoming the first player to do so since Steffi Graf in 2019. He became the first German player to win the title. 1988.
The 27-year-old said: "I'm very happy. I didn't know if I would be able to play here again. For me, this is a dream come true.
This is Kerber's second Grand Slam title, having previously won the US Open in 2018, and will face Ashleigh Barty or Elina Svitolina in the semi-finals.
Williams has not won a major title since winning the 2017 Australian Open, and Barty has never made it past the fourth round at Wimbledon.
But the 36-year-old former world number one showed no signs of fatigue as she battled back from a set down to beat Petra Kvitova 4-6, 6-2, 6.

input:
Radio host Alan Chartock interviewed Gov. Cuomo on Thursday afternoon, just as he has on hundreds of occasions in the past.
It was a remarkable first.
Chartock, the most omnipresent voice on radio airwaves from Westchester to southern
continuation:
New Jersey, had never met the governor before.
The two men spoke for more than an hour about the coronavirus pandemic, its impact on New York and the state's economic future.
"We're all in this together," Cuomo said. "I'm going to do everything I can to make sure we get through this."
Cuomo, who is up for re-election next year, has emerged as one of the most powerful figures in American politics during the coronavirus pandemic.
His leadership has been praised by President Donald Trump, whose approval ratings are at their lowest level since the start of the pandemic.
But his popularity has also come under scrutiny, particularly after it was revealed that the governor's administration failed to properly prepare for the virus' spread in nursing homes.
On Wednesday, The Washington Post reported that the Department of Health and Human Services did not follow proper protocols when it came to nursing home deaths.
More than 6,700 people with COVID-19 were discharged from nursing homes into the general population between March and May, according to data released by the state health department last week.
New York State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli, a Democrat, called the report "shocking

It was a great first event.
Mr. Chartock is one of the most recognizable voices on radio from Westchester to southern New Jersey, but he had never met the governor before.
The two spoke for more than an hour about the coronavirus pandemic, its impact on New York, and the future of the state's economy.
"We're all in this together," Cuomo said. We will do everything in our power to make sure we get through this situation.
Mr. Cuomo, who is seeking re-election next year, has emerged as one of the most influential figures in American politics amid the coronavirus pandemic.
His leadership has been praised by President Donald Trump, whose approval ratings are at their lowest levels since the pandemic began.
But his popularity has also come under scrutiny, especially after revelations that the governor's administration failed to adequately prepare for the spread of the virus in nursing homes.
The Washington Post reported Wednesday that the Department of Health and Human Services failed to follow proper procedures regarding nursing home deaths.
More than 6,700 people infected with the coronavirus were discharged from nursing homes into the general community between March and May, according to data released last week by the state health department.
New York State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli (D) called the report "shocking."

The documentary, 13th, kept with the theme
continuation:

In 1868, the Supreme Court ruled that the 13th Amendment applied to all persons born in the United States, regardless of their race or place of origin. The ruling led to the imprisonment of hundreds of thousands of African-American men, women and children, many of whom were never charged with a crime.

input:
Astounding? Or are you kind of afraid of a robot takeover now?
Gymnasts dreaming of a future Olympic win might find they have some competition  the robot kind.
Waltham-based Boston Dynamics shared a video Thursday of
continuation:
its latest creation, SpotMini, which is designed to assist people with everyday tasks such as picking up objects and carrying them to their destinations.
The company's previous creations include Atlas, a humanoid robot that can run, jump and climb stairs. It was also featured in the film "Jurassic World," where it was used to help protect the park from dinosaurs.
SpotMini is smaller than those robots, but still has enough power to move around on its own.
"We've been working on this for about three years, and we're really excited to finally share it with the world," said co-founder Marc Raibert in a news release. "We hope it will be a useful tool for anyone who wants to help themselves or someone else."
It's not the first time Boston Dynamics has shown off SpotMini. In 2017, the company showed off the robot at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, Nevada. At the time, the robot could pick up items weighing less than 5 pounds and carry them up two flights of stairs.
But SpotMini isn't just a toy. The company plans to use SpotMini in hospitals, assisted living facilities and other places where people may need assistance.

input:
Liverpool have submitted a bid for Real Madrid's Karim Benzema.
Several sources in Spain have suggested that Reds boss Brendan Rodgers submitted a bid in the region of 50m for the French international, who joined Real in 2010, earlier today.
continuation:
The 27-year-old has been linked with a move away from the Bernabeu this summer after failing to agree a new contract at the club.
Rodgers will be keen to bolster his attacking options ahead of next season and is believed to have identified Benzema as a potential replacement for Luis Suarez.
However, it remains to be seen whether or not Los Blancos will be willing to let their star man leave.
Benzema has scored 118 goals in 292 appearances for Real since joining from Ligue 1 giants Paris Saint-Germain seven years ago.

Liverpool have made an offer to sign Real Madrid's Karim Benzema.
Sources in Spain suggest that Reds manager Brendan Rodgers today offered a bid of around $50 million for the French international, who joined Real Madrid in 2010.
The 27-year-old has been linked with a move from the Bernabu this summer after failing to agree a new contract with the club.
Rodgers wants to strengthen his attacking options ahead of next season and is thought to be eyeing Benzema as a possible replacement for Luis Suarez.

Cleveland-Cliffs isn't the company it once was, but Wall Street is still pricing it that way.
For years, iron ore producer Cleveland-Cliffs (NYSE:CLF) has been in the midst of a turnaround plan
continuation:
to turn around its business and return to profitability. It's had some success in doing so, but the stock hasn't done much better. Shares are down more than 60% over the past five years.
Continue Reading Below
But investors have been willing to pay a premium for what they thought would be a turnaround story. The stock trades at a forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of roughly 30 times this year's forecast earnings. That's well above the average P/E for the S&P 500, which currently sits at about 20 times earnings.
Image source: Getty Images.
Investors aren't giving up on Cleveland-Cliffs just yet. In fact, they're buying into the idea that the company can continue to improve its operations and become profitable again.
Why the optimism?
There are several reasons why investors are optimistic about Cleveland-Cliffs' future prospects. First, there's the company's strong balance sheet. As of the end of the second quarter, it had $2.3 billion in cash and short-term investments, along with $1.5 billion in undrawn credit facilities.

Amid choppy markets in correction mode, the secret to making it in the long run is having the patience and fortitude to
continuation:
ride out the ups and downs that come with investing in precious metals. Thats exactly what North American Palladium Corp. (TSXV: PAL)(OTCQB: PALDF) has been doing so far this year.
The Toronto-based company recently announced that it has entered into a non-brokered private placement for gross proceeds of $2.5 million. The funds will be used to fund exploration activities at its 100%-owned El Dorado project in Nevada, as well as for general working capital purposes.
PAL shares are currently trading at $0.15 per share on the TSX Venture Exchange (TSXV), down from a recent high of $0.20. The stock has lost more than 50% of its value over the past 12 months.
Heres why you should consider buying North American Palladium now.
Investing in palladium
Palladium is an industrial metal used in catalytic converters to reduce harmful emissions from diesel and gasoline engines. It also finds use in other applications, such as in electric vehicles.
According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), global demand for palladium is expected to increase by 10% annually through 2040.

input: Former Kent State wrestling coach Ron Gray will be inducted into the National Wrestling Hall of Fame on June 1 in Stillwater, Okla. Gray, who coached the Golden Flashes for 25 seasons, is one of four members who will be inducted
continuation:
this year.

The other three inductees are former University of Minnesota wrestler and two-time Olympic gold medalist John Bones Thompson, former University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill head coach Bob McKillop, and former University of Oklahoma head coach Eddie Gaedel. The induction ceremony will take place at 6:30 p.m. ET on Saturday, June 1, at the Hilton Garden Inn & Suites in Stillwater. Tickets are $50 per person and can be purchased online or by calling (800) 745-3000. All proceeds from ticket sales will go to benefit the American Cancer Society.

In addition to his coaching duties, Gray served as an assistant coach with the U.S. national team during the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. He was a member of the U.S. team that won the bronze medal at the 1989 Pan American Games in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Gray began his coaching career at Ohio Wesleyan University, where he spent five years before moving to Kent State. During his time at Kent State, he led the Golden Flashes to three NCAA Division II national championships (1991, 1992, 1993).

In addition to his coaching duties, Gray served as his assistant coach for the U.S. national team during the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea. He was a member of the U.S. team that won a bronze medal at the 1989 Pan American Games in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Gray began his coaching career at Ohio Wesleyan University and spent his five years there before transferring to Kent State University. While at Kent State University, he led his Golden Flashes to three NCAA Division II national championships (1991, 1992, 1993).

The National Electoral Council announced late Thursday it would
continuation:
hold a second round of voting on June 7 after an initial tally showed President Lenin Moreno with a narrow lead over his main rival, former president Rafael Correa.
Lasso says hes ready to accept the results if they show there was no fraud.
The vote count is being closely watched because it will determine which party controls Ecuadors next government.
Correa has refused to concede defeat and has vowed to challenge the results in court.

input:
Ms Lee, 45, an avid jogger, had been jogging almost every day for the past five years. Recently, her knees started to hurt.
Gradually, walking up and down the stairs became a problem too, so much so that
continuation:
she could no longer do it.
"I was in pain all the time," she told The Straits Times. "I couldn't go out of the house anymore."
She sought help from physiotherapists and orthopaedic surgeons at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU), who diagnosed her with osteoarthritis (OA).
The OA is a degenerative joint disease caused by wear and tear on the cartilage that cushions the bones in the joints.
It can be treated with medication or surgery, depending on the severity of the condition.
In Ms Lee's case, she underwent knee arthroscopy, a minimally invasive surgical procedure that involves cutting through the bone to remove the damaged cartilage.
After three months of treatment, she was able to return to her regular exercise routine.
But she still found herself unable to walk more than a few metres without getting tired.
So last month, she went back to TTSH for a second opinion.
"They told me I have osteoarthritis in my left knee, and they recommended that I undergo a total knee replacement," she said, adding that she
translation:
Lee, 45, is an avid jogger and has been jogging almost every day for the past five years. She recently started having pain in her knees.
Gradually, it became difficult for her to go up and down the stairs, and she was no longer able to do so.
"I was always in pain," she told The Straits Times. "I can't leave the house anymore."
She sought help from physiotherapists and orthopedic surgeons at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU), who diagnosed her with osteoarthritis (OA).
OA is a degenerative joint disease caused by the wear and tear of cartilage, the cushion of bones in joints.
Depending on the severity of the symptoms, it can be treated with medication or surgery.
In Ms. Lee's case, she underwent arthroscopy on her knee. This is a minimally invasive surgery that cuts through the bone and removes the damaged cartilage.
After 3 months of treatment, she was able to return to her regular sports activities.
However, she noticed that she still could not walk more than a few meters without getting tired.
So last month she returned to TTSH for a second opinion.
"They told me I had osteoarthritis in my left knee and recommended I have a total knee replacement," she added.

input:
March 27 - A greater proportion of quota places for women is among the changes successfully proposed by the World Rowing Federation (FISA) to its qualification system ahead of Rio 2016.
The changes, which have now been approved by the International Olympic Committee
continuation:
(IOC), will be implemented from 2017 onwards.
In a statement released on Wednesday, FISA said it was "pleased" with the outcome of the meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, where the organisation's executive board voted unanimously to approve the changes.
They are designed to ensure that more female rowers are able to compete at the highest level, as well as providing an opportunity for those who do not qualify through the world rankings.
The new rules include:
- An increase in the number of quotas allocated to each national federation based on the results of the previous year.
- The introduction of gender-specific quotas for men and women's single sculls and coxless fours.
- The introduction of gender-specific quotas for men's and women's double sculls and coxless fours.
- The introduction of gender-specific quotas for men's and women's eights.
- The introduction of gender-specific quotas for men's and women's eight-person keelboat.
- The introduction of gender-specific quotas for men's and women's lightweight double sculls.
- The introduction of gender-specific quotas for men's and women's lightweight double scull
translation:
27 March - Among the changes proposed by the World Federation of Rowing (FISA) to its qualification system ahead of Rio 2016, the expansion of quotas for women has been a success.
The changes have already been approved by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and will be implemented from 2017.
In a statement released Wednesday, FISA said it was "satisfied" with the outcome of a meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, where its board unanimously approved the changes.
These are designed to enable more female rowers to compete at the highest level, while also providing opportunities for those who do not qualify for the world rankings.
The new rules include:
- Increase the number of slots allocated to each national federation based on the results of the previous year.
- Introduction of gender quotas for singles and coxless fours.
- Introducing gender quotas for men's and women's sculls and rudderless foreground events.
- Introducing separate quotas for boys and girls, with an 8-person system and an 8-person system for women.
- Introduction of male and female quotas for 8-person keelboats.
- Introduced separate quotas for men and women's lightweight sculls.
- Introduced separate quotas for men and women's lightweight sculls.

continuation:

input:
Texas has become the first state in the nation to require law enforcement to obtain a warrant to read people's email, and privacy advocates are hoping the move will help quicken the passage of a similar proposal in Congress.
Texas Gov. Rick Perry signed
continuation:
an executive order on Wednesday that requires police to get a judge's approval before searching through someone's email or text messages.
The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one.
"This is about protecting your right to privacy," Perry said during a signing ceremony at the Texas Department of Public Safety headquarters in Austin. "If you have something to hide, don't send it over the Internet."
The bill was approved by the Legislature earlier this year but stalled in the final days of the legislative session as lawmakers focused on other issues. It now heads to Perry's desk, where he plans to sign it into law.
Privacy advocates say the measure is a step in the right direction, but they're still looking for stronger protections against mass surveillance.
"It's a good start, but I think we can do better," said Jennifer Granholm, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas. "We need to be much more careful about what we're doing with our personal information."
Granholm said she would like to see laws requiring companies to disclose when their customers' data is shared with third-parties. She also wants to see limits placed on government agencies' ability to access emails and texts without a warrant.

"This is a good start, but I think we can do better," said Jennifer Granholm, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas. "We need to be more careful about how we handle personal information."
Granholm said he would like to see legislation requiring companies to disclose when they share customer data with third parties. She also wants government agencies to restrict access to emails and text messages without a warrant.

The renovations completely overhauled the building and will be the standard for the
continuation:
next decade.
We are very proud to have been able to complete this project on time and within budget, said Lt. Col. David Rupp, 491st Civil Engineering Squadron commander. This is a great example of how we can work together as a team to achieve our common goal of providing a safe and comfortable living environment for the men and women who train with us every day.

A new business matchmaking company that describes itself as the "first and only" service that uses algorithmic science to match businesses with with advertising, PR, branding and web-development firms
continuation:

"We're really focused on finding the best matches," said CEO and co-founder David Gewirtz. "It's all about matching the right people with the right opportunities."

input: The big news on any day when President Bush delivers a "major address" regarding Iraq is never what the commander-in-chief says. Bush has been on autopilot for so long now that he does not even bother to say anything new -- even
continuation:
if it's true.

This week, Bush delivered his annual State of the Union address. It was the first time he had spoken in public since Sept. 11, 2001, and he made no mention of the war in Iraq.

Instead, he talked about America's economic recovery from the Great Recession and the need to protect Social Security and Medicare.

Bush said the U.S. economy will grow by 3 percent this year, up from an estimated 2.2 percent growth last year. He also noted that the unemployment rate is at a record low of 4.1 percent.

But Bush didn't talk about the war in Iraq.

In fact, there were very few mentions of Iraq during his speech.

Here are some of the highlights:

On Afghanistan: "We're making progress against al-Qaida and other terrorist groups."

On Iran: "I'm confident we can reach a nuclear agreement with Iran without compromising our national security interests."

On North Korea: "We continue to urge China to use its influence over North Korea to rein in its nuclear weapons program."

On terrorism: "Terrorism is a threat to all of us. We have to work together

President Bush said the U.S. economy will grow 3% this year, lower than last year's forecast of 2.2%. He also pointed out that the unemployment rate is at an all-time low of 4.1%.

But President Bush did not talk about the Iraq War.

On terrorism: "Terrorism is a threat to us all. We must work together.

This years World Cup official ball will be the Telstar 18, a modern interpretation of the 1970 and 1974 adidas ball, Telstar.
The name was coined due to its black and white pentagons that made it easier to spot
continuation:
from a distance. The Telstar 18 has been developed in partnership with Adidas and is being used for the first time at this years tournament in Russia.
The ball features an all-aluminum casing with a polyurethane inner core. It also includes a new Dynamo logo on the back of the ball.
Adidas says the ball is more durable than previous versions thanks to the use of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) and a special material called TPU, or thermoplastic urethane.
We are very pleased to have been able to work closely with our partners at Adidas and provide them with a ball that they can be proud of for many years to come," said FIFA president Gianni Infantino. "I am confident that the Telstar 18 will be a key part of the success of the Russian 2018 World Cup."
FIFA says the ball will be available for pre-order starting next week.

A group of stock traders teamed with two Ukrainian-based computer hackers to make $100 million in illegal profits by gaining access to hundreds of press releases of many leading U.S. companies and trading on the stolen news before it became public.
All
continuation:
told, they made more than $1 billion over a three-year period, according to court documents unsealed this week in Manhattan federal court.
The case is one of the most high-profile cases brought by Special Counsel Robert Muellers investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. It also marks the first time prosecutors have publicly alleged that an organized crime syndicate used social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook to spread disinformation and manipulate public opinion.
Prosecutors allege that from at least 2014 to 2017, members of the DarkSide cybercrime group hacked into computers belonging to companies including JPMorgan Chase & Co., Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc., United Parcel Service Inc., Home Depot Inc., Macys Inc., Verizon Communications Inc., and others. The hackers then posted the stolen information online for free.
In some instances, the hackers gained access to tens of thousands of pages of internal company documents. In others, they were able to obtain millions of dollars worth of trade secrets or other confidential business information.
Some of the stolen material was later published on websites controlled by DarkSide. Others were shared through encrypted messaging services such as Signal, WhatsApp, Telegram, and WeChat.
According to the indictment,

continuation:
