input: ISLAMABAD, Oct 27 (APP): Minister for Finance Senator Muhammad Ishaq Dar Thursday said that due to prudent economic policies of the government, macro economic stability has been achieved and now focus was on the sustainable economic growth for job creation
continuation:
.
He expressed these views while chairing a meeting of National Economic Council (NEC) here at Prime Ministers Office (PMO).
The meeting was attended among others by Federal Minister for Planning, Development and Special Initiatives Asad Umar, Adviser to PM on Commerce Abdul Razak Dawood, Chief Secretary Punjab Chaudhry Nisar Ali Khan, Chief Secretary Sindh Ghulam Murtaza Baloch, Chairman Board of Investment (BoI) Zubair Ahmed Siddiqui and other senior officials.
During the course of the discussion, it was decided that the government would take all possible steps to enhance investment in the country and create employment opportunities.
It was also decided that the BoI should be made more efficient and effective so that it could play an active role in attracting foreign direct investments (FDI) in the country.
In this regard, special attention should be paid to ease of doing business as well as facilitation of FDI in the country.
The finance minister directed the BoI to work out a comprehensive plan to improve the ease of doing business in the country.
He also directed the BoI to devise a mechanism to identify bottlenecks in the FDI
translation:
ISLAMABAD, Oct 27 (APP): Senate Finance Minister Mohammad Ishaq Dar said on Thursday that thanks to the government's sound economic policies, macroeconomic stability has been achieved and now sustainable economic growth for job creation is underway. He said that the focus is on
The Prime Minister expressed these views while presiding over a meeting of the National Economic Council (NEC) at the Prime Minister's Office (PMO) here.
The meeting was attended by Asad Umar, Federal Minister for Planning, Development and Special Initiatives, Abdul Razak Dawood, Special Advisor to the Prime Minister on Trade Affairs, Chief Secretary of Punjab Chaudhry Nisar Ali Khan, and Chief Secretary Sindh Ghulam Murtaza Baloch. , Chief Secretary Sindh Ghulam Murtaza Baloch and others were present. Investment (BoI). Zubair Ahmed Siddiqui and other senior officials.
During the discussions, it was decided that the government would take all steps to increase investment and create employment opportunities in the country.
It was also decided to make the BOI more efficient and effective so that it can play an active role in attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) into the country.
In this regard, special attention should be paid to ease of doing business and the promotion of foreign direct investment in the country.
The finance minister has directed the central bank to come up with a comprehensive plan for ease of doing business in the country.
He also directed the Bank of India to develop a mechanism to identify bottlenecks in foreign direct investment.

input:
ANKARA (Reuters) - For all of Irans fierce verbal response to fresh U.S. threats of tougher sanctions, some senior officials in Tehran believe the door to diplomacy should stay open.
On Monday, U.S. Secretary
continuation:
of State Mike Pompeo said Washington would reimpose sanctions on Iran unless it gave up its nuclear program and stopped supporting militant groups in the Middle East.
Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif responded with a tweet: We are ready for talks. But we will not negotiate over our nuclear program.
The United States withdrew from a 2015 deal between Iran and world powers under which Tehran agreed to curb its uranium enrichment activities in exchange for the lifting of most international sanctions.
Washington has since reimposed sanctions that had been lifted as part of the deal, targeting Irans vital oil industry and financial sector.
But Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, who is seeking re-election next month, has repeatedly called for dialogue to ease tensions.
In an interview with state television aired on Tuesday, Zarif said Iran was willing to talk about other issues too, including regional security.
I think there is a lot of room for negotiation, he said.
If you look at the history of the region, there have been many occasions when countries have come together to solve their problems through negotiations, he said.
So I am optimistic that this can be done again.
translation:
ANKARA (Reuters) - Despite Iran's strong verbal response to renewed U.S. threats to tighten sanctions, some senior officials in Tehran believe the door to diplomacy must remain open.
US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Monday that the US would reimpose sanctions on Iran unless it abandons its nuclear program and stops supporting militant groups in the Middle East.
Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif responded on Twitter: "We are ready to negotiate." But we are not going to negotiate on the nuclear program.
The United States withdrew from a 2015 agreement between Iran and world powers in which Iran agreed to limit its uranium enrichment activities in exchange for the lifting of most international sanctions.
The US government has since reimposed sanctions that were lifted as part of the deal, targeting Iran's key oil industry and financial sector.
However, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, who is seeking re-election next month, has repeatedly called for dialogue to ease tensions.
Foreign Minister Zarif said in an interview with state television on Tuesday that Iran was ready to discuss other issues, including regional security.
I think there's a lot of room for negotiation."
Looking at the history of the region, he said, there are many examples of countries coming together to resolve issues through negotiation.
So I'm optimistic that we can do it again.

I think we did a good job of taking what they were giving us, said head coach John Beilein. We had a lot of guys step up and make big plays. We didnt have our best shooting night, but I thought we played well overall.

Afghanistan's parliament rejected a second nominee for defense minister on Saturday, leaving a vacuum that has already lasted nine months, while government
continuation:
officials say the Taliban have stepped up attacks across the country.
Parliament voted to reject Mohammad Hanif Atmar, who was nominated by President Ashraf Ghani last week, and replace him with Abdul Rahim Wardak, an army general who had been serving as deputy defense minister.
The vote came after Atmar said he would resign from his post, citing "personal reasons," without elaborating.
Atmar was one of three candidates vying for the position, which is considered the most important cabinet post in Afghanistan.
His withdrawal comes just days after U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry visited Kabul, where he held talks with Ghani and other leaders about the future of the war-ravaged country.
Kerry said the United States and its allies were committed to working with all sides to try to find a political solution to the conflict.
"We will not leave Afghanistan until we achieve that goal," he said in a statement.
Ghani, who took office in mid-2014, has promised to end the 18-year-old war and bring peace to the country.
But progress has been slower than expected, partly because of deep mistrust between the Afghan government and the Taliban, which controls or holds sway
translation:
FILE - Afghan security forces guard the scene of a suicide bombing in Kabul on May 19, 2015.
Afghanistan's parliament on Saturday rejected a second nomination for defense minister, extending a nine-month hiatus as government officials say the Taliban are stepping up attacks across the country.
Parliament last week rejected President Ashraf Ghani's nomination of Mohammad Hanif Atmar and voted to replace him with Army General Abdul Rahim Wardak, who served as deputy defense minister.
The vote came after Atmar announced he was resigning, citing "personal reasons" without providing details.
Atmar was one of three candidates vying for the most important post in Afghanistan's cabinet.
His resignation came days after U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry visited Kabul for talks with Ghani and others about the future of the war-torn country.
Kerry said the United States and its allies are ready to work with all sides to find a political solution to the conflict.
"We will not leave Afghanistan until we achieve this goal," he said in his statement.
Ghani, who took office in mid-2014, vowed to end 18 years of war and bring peace to the country.
But progress has been slower than expected, in part due to deep mistrust between the Afghan government and the Taliban who seize or hold power.

This notion

I'm not saying it hasn't, I'm just pointing out that it's not as common as people make it out to be.
I think it's more common than people make it out to be.  There are a lot of QBs in this league who can't get on the field for some reason or another.
That's why I said it's not as common as people make it out to be. It's certainly not unheard of, but it doesn't happen very often.

input: I remember the first interview I did about the gender pay gap, back in the 90s, when women had their very own Equal Opportunities Commission. We talked about pay rates reaching parity in full-time work, then getting dragged down by part-
continuation:
timers and casual workers. It was a long way from where we are now.

But theres a lot of progress to be made. A new report by the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) has found that women still earn less than men at every level of employment, including those who have been working in the same job for 20 years or more.

This is despite the fact that women make up nearly half of the UK workforce.

The IPPR report, published on Wednesday, says: Women continue to be paid less than men at all levels of employment. The gap between male and female earnings has narrowed over the last decade, but it remains wide.

It shows that the average hourly wage for men aged 25 to 34 is 9.20, compared with 8.70 for women. In contrast, the average hourly wage for women aged 25 to 34 is 7.30, compared with 6.40 for men.

There are some bright spots, though. The average hourly wage for men aged 25 to 34 is 10.60, while the average hourly wage for women aged 25 to 34 is 8.50.

These figures
translation:
I remember my first interview about the gender pay gap in the 90s, when women had their own Equal Opportunities Commission. We talked about how once wage rates reach parity with full-time jobs, they drop because of part-time and temporary workers. It was a long way from where we are now.

However, much progress remains to be made. Women continue to earn less than men at all levels of employment, including those who have been in the same job for more than 20 years, according to a new report from the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR).

This is despite women making up almost half of the UK workforce.

The IPPR report, published on Wednesday, said: Women continue to be paid less than men at all levels of employment. Although the income gap between men and women has narrowed over the past decade, it remains large.

According to this, the average hourly wage for men aged 25 to 34 is 9.20 yen, while for women it is 8.70 yen. In contrast, the average hourly wage for women between the ages of 25 and 34 is $7.30, compared to $6.40 for men.

However, there are some bright spots. The average hourly wage for men between the ages of 25 and 34 is 10.60 yen, and the average hourly wage for women between the ages of 25 and 34 is 8.50 yen.

these numbers

input: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Ra Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (NASDAQ:RARX) today announced that the design of its Phase 2 clinical trial of RA101495 SC for the treatment of generalized my
continuation:
asthenia gravis (GMG) has been accepted by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The trial will be conducted as a single-arm, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety and tolerability of RA101495 SC in patients with GMG.

We are pleased to have received FDA approval for our Phase 2 clinical trial of RA101495 SC for the treatment of generalized myasthenia gravis (GMG), said David A. Cohen, Ph.D., Chief Executive Officer of Ra Pharmaceuticals. We look forward to starting this study in the first quarter of 2013. This is an important milestone for RA101495 SC, which we believe has the potential to become a new treatment option for patients suffering from GMG.

About Generalized Myasthenia Gravis

Generalized myasthenia gravis is a rare neuromuscular disease characterized by progressive muscle weakness and fatigue. It affects approximately 1 in 10,000 people worldwide and is the most common form of muscular dystrophy. In the United States, it is the second leading cause of disability after spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).

No. 5 Stanford (24-5, 10-2 Pac-12) completed a three-game sweep of Washington (15-15, 5-10 Pac-12) with a 6-1 victory on Sunday.
Looking to avenge
continuation:
last years loss in Seattle, the Cardinal jumped out to an early 2-0 lead and never looked back en route to their second straight win over the Huskies.
Stanford opened the scoring in the first inning on a solo home run from junior centerfielder Kole Calhoun, his team-leading 23rd of the season.
The Cardinal added two more runs in the third inning to extend their lead to 4-0. Sophomore shortstop Alex Yastrzemski led off with a single and moved to second on a wild pitch. After senior right fielder Max Stassi was hit by a pitch to load the bases, Calhoun drove a 1-0 pitch over the left field fence for his 12th home run of the season.
In the fourth inning, sophomore right-hander Eric Lauer (7-3) struck out seven batters and allowed just four hits in six innings pitched. He also walked one and did not allow a baserunner until the top of the sixth inning.

There is a hearing today on whether presidents should be required to make their tax returns public.
Rep. Richard Neal, D-Mass., then incoming chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, addressed an audience, Nov. 27, during a gathering
continuation:
at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia. (AP Photo/Matt Slocum)
WASHINGTON  President Donald Trumps refusal to release his tax returns has prompted calls from Democrats for Congress to pass legislation requiring that he do so.
But theres little chance that will happen anytime soon.
Lawmakers have been trying unsuccessfully for more than two years to get the Internal Revenue Service to turn over Trumps tax returns to the House Ways and Means Committee, which is chaired by Rep. Richard Neal of Massachusetts, the top Democrat on the panel.
Neal is expected to introduce legislation this week that would require presidential candidates to release their tax returns before the November 2020 election. The bill, if it becomes law, would apply to any future candidate who wants to run for president.
Its unclear how much support the measure has in the Republican-controlled House or Senate. And even if it passes both chambers, its not clear whether Trump would sign it into law.
Here are some questions and answers about the issue:
___
WHAT IS THE REASON TRUMP HAS NOT RELEASED HIS TAX RETURNS?
Trump has refused to release his tax returns because they are under audit.

input:
San Francisco Giants pitcher Madison Bumgarner poses for photographers during photo day at spring training Wednesday, Feb. 20, 2013, in Scottsdale, Ariz.
Gregor Blanco #7 poses for a portrait during San Francisco Giants Photo
continuation:
Day at Scottsdale Stadium on Wednesday, February 20, 2013. (Photo by Mark J. Rebilas/Bay Area News Group)

SAN FRANCISCO - The San Francisco Giants have signed free agent right-hander Madison Bumgarner to a one-year contract worth $12 million, a person familiar with the negotiations told The Associated Press on Thursday.

The person spoke on condition of anonymity because the agreement had not been announced.

Bumgarner is coming off an injury-plagued season that saw him miss more than two months after having Tommy John surgery on his right elbow. He went 2-4 with a 5.40 ERA in 10 starts and 15 relief appearances last year.

"He's going to be a big part of our pitching staff," general manager Bobby Evans said. "We're very excited about him."

Evans declined to say how much money Bumgarner would earn this year, but he said the deal was done before the start of Spring Training.

"I can't tell you exactly what we paid him, but it was a lot less than what other teams were willing to pay," he said.

input: TAPACHULA, Mexico (AP)  Thousands of Central American migrants resumed an arduous trek toward the U.S. border Monday, with members bristling at suggestions there could be terrorists among them and saying the caravan is being used for
continuation:
political gain by President Donald Trump.

We dont know if they are terrorists or not, but what we know is that they want to enter the United States, said a Guatemalan migrant who gave his name only as Rafael because he feared reprisals against his family back home in Guatemala.

Trump has threatened to cut off aid to Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador unless they do more to stop migrants from leaving their homelands to seek asylum in the U.S.

ADVERTISEMENT

On Sunday night, thousands of Hondurans, Guatemalans and Salvadorans began making their way through southern Mexico on foot after crossing the Suchiate River into Chiapas state from Guatemala.

Mexican security forces have been deployed along the route to prevent migrants from entering the country illegally. The Mexican government says it has no plans to send its own troops to the border.

But some migrants said they were concerned about the possibility of violence.

Im very scared, Ive never seen anything like this in my life. Were going to get killed, Rafael said.

Guatemalan
translation:
TAPACHULA, MEXICO (AP) - Thousands of Central American migrants resumed the arduous journey to the U.S. border on Monday, but their members, furious over suggestions they may contain terrorists, abandoned their caravan. claimed it was being used for political gain by President Donald Trump.

"I don't know if they are terrorists or not, but I know they want to come to the United States," said the Guatemalan immigrant, who gave his name only as Rafael for fear of retaliation against his family back home in Guatemala.

President Trump has threatened to cut off aid to Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador unless they do more to stop migrants from leaving their home countries to seek asylum in the United States.

advertisement

On Sunday night, thousands of Hondurans, Guatemalans and Salvadorans began their journey on foot through southern Mexico, crossing the Suchiate River from Guatemala into the state of Chiapas.

Mexican security forces were deployed along the route to prevent migrants from entering the country illegally. The Mexican government has said it has no plans to send its troops to the border.

But some migrants said they were concerned about the possibility of violence.

It's very scary, I've never seen anything like this in my life. They will kill us, said Rafael.

Guatemalan

input:
Valejah Savon Johnson's argument with Robert Mayes resulted in Mayes clinging to the hood of Johnson's speeding pickup truck, according to affidavit.
LAFAYETTE Twenty-one-year-old Valejah Savon Johnson
continuation:
is facing a felony charge after police say she was caught on video driving recklessly and causing a crash that injured another motorist.
The incident occurred at about 3:45 p.m. Sunday when Lafayette police officers were called to the intersection of West Third Street and East Seventh Avenue for a reported traffic accident.
Officers arrived to find two vehicles had collided head-on. The driver of the other vehicle was taken to a local hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.
According to court documents, Johnson fled the scene but was later arrested by Lafayette police. She was booked into the Terrebonne Parish Detention Center on charges of aggravated vehicular homicide, reckless operation of a vehicle, failure to yield right of way, driving under suspension and possession of drug paraphernalia. Her bail has been set at $150,000.
Johnson is scheduled to appear in court Tuesday morning.

Johnson fled the scene but was later arrested by Lafayette police, according to court documents. "Now I can't wait to show everyone just how much I love the art form

"I've always had a passion for tattoos, but I never thought I could do it.

input: UPPER EAST SIDE  The Second Avenue subway blast that sprayed debris high into the air above 72nd street was sparked by an underground explosion the force of which hit a steel plate covering the work site at street level, the MTA revealed Wednesday.
continuation:
MTA officials said they were still trying to figure out exactly what caused Tuesdays explosion, which sent a plume of black smoke billowing into the sky and injured more than two dozen people.

We dont know for sure, but we suspect it may have been some kind of mechanical failure, MTA Chairman Pat Foye told reporters. Were going to do everything we can to make sure this doesnt happen again.

The blast occurred just before 6 p.m. near the intersection of Second Avenue and 72nd Street in the Upper East Side.

Foye said he had spoken with Mayor Bill de Blasio about the incident.

I want to thank the mayor for his quick response and his efforts to get to the scene as quickly as possible, Foye said. We are working closely with our police and fire department partners to determine the cause of the explosion.

He added: This is a very sad day for the city of New York. We will not forget those who lost their lives or suffered serious injuries. Our thoughts and prayers are with their families
translation:
UPPER EAST SIDE The Second Avenue subway explosion that sent debris flying into the air above 72nd Street was caused by an underground explosion whose force struck steel plates covering the work area at street level, the MTA said. It was announced on Wednesday.

MTA officials said they were still determining the exact cause of Tuesday's explosion, which sent black smoke into the sky and injured more than 20 people.

"We don't know for sure, but we suspect it was some kind of mechanical failure," MTA Chairman Pat Foy told reporters. We will do everything in our power to prevent this from happening again.

The explosion occurred shortly before 6 p.m. near the intersection of His 2nd Avenue and His 72nd Street on the Upper East Side.

Foy said he spoke with Mayor Bill de Blasio about the incident.

"I want to thank the mayor for his quick response and his efforts to get to the scene as quickly as possible," Foy said. We are working closely with police and fire services to determine the cause of the explosion.

He added: "Today is a very sad day for New York City." We will never forget those who died and those who were seriously injured. Our thoughts and prayers are with their families.

input:
GREENSBURG, Ind. An Indiana man is facing a murder charge after allegedly admitting to killing his girlfriend.
Jason Eaton, 43, walked into the Greensburg Police Department on Tuesday with a woman and asked to talk to an officer. He
continuation:
told officers that he had killed his girlfriend, who was later identified as 33-year-old Jessica Luellen.
Eaton was taken into custody without incident.
Luellens body was found in a wooded area near the intersection of State Road 441 and East Main Street just before 7 p.m. Monday. Her death was ruled a homicide by strangulation.
The investigation is ongoing.
Anyone with information about this case is asked to call the Greensburg Police Department at (812) 543-3100 or Crime Stoppers of Central Indiana at (317) 262-TIPS (8477). Tipsters can remain anonymous and could be eligible for a reward of up to $1,000 if their tip leads to an arrest.
This story has been updated with additional information from Greenbrier police.

Katy Perry will hit the MTV Video Music Awards stage later this month to perform her newly leaked single Roar.
Perry hasnt performed on the VMAs since 2009, but her new single is getting amazing feedback from fans.
continuation:
The song has already racked up more than 1.5 million views on YouTube in just a few days.
Visit Insiders homepage for more stories.
Katy Perry is set to make her long-awaited return to the MTV Video Music Awards stage later this month.
The pop star will perform her new single Roar at the annual awards show, which airs live August 27 at 8 p.m. ET/PT on MTV. The performance will be Perrys first appearance at the VMAs since 2009, when she took home the award for Best New Artist.
Since then, Perry has released several singles and music videos that have been met with critical acclaim. Her most recent album, Witness, was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) for sales of over 2 million copies in the US alone. She also scored two Grammy Award nominations last year: Best Pop Vocal Album and Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals for her collaboration with Justin Bieber on Never Worn White.
Her latest single, Roar, is currently garnering rave reviews from fans who are calling it one of the best songs of 2020 so far.

Just in time for Paris Fashion Week, the Italian design house Emilio Cavallini has apparently hit a nerve with its new unisex pantyhose designed for men, which has been dubbed "mantyhose."
At a price
continuation:
point of $69.99 (about 50), these high-waisted pantyhose come in three different colors: black, white and red.
The brand's founder, Emilio Cavallini, told The New York Times that he wanted to create a product that would appeal to both men and women.
"I think it is very important to have a product that can be used by both sexes," he said.
Cavallini, who was born in Italy but moved to the United States when he was 10 years old, said his inspiration came from his own experiences growing up as a gay man in the 1980s and '90s.
"It was not easy for me to find my place in the world," he said. "I felt like I didn't fit in anywhere."
He added, "I had no idea what I wanted to do or where I wanted to go. And then one day I went into a store and I saw a pair of pantyhose that were made for women. I thought, 'What am I doing here? What am I doing with my life?'"
Cavallini decided to launch his own line of pantyhose after being inspired by the

input:
PULGA  In December 2012, a fierce winter storm toppled five steel towers that support the same PG&E transmission line that malfunctioned minutes before the Camp Fire roared to life.
Six years later, the 115,000-volt Caribou
continuation:
-Palermo Line is still in disrepair.
PG&E has spent more than $2 billion on repairs and upgrades since then, but the companys board of directors recently approved a new plan to spend another $3.5 billion over the next 10 years.
The proposal, which was unanimously approved by PG&E shareholders at its annual meeting this week, calls for the company to spend an additional $4.6 billion on the project.
We need to do everything we can to protect our customers from catastrophic wildfires like the one we saw last year, said PG&E CEO Bill Johnson during his opening remarks at the shareholder meeting. Thats why we are investing billions of dollars in wildfire prevention and preparedness, as well as improving our ability to safely restore power when its needed.
PG&E has already spent about $2.7 billion on the project, according to a recent filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The company expects to spend an additional $1.5 billion to $1.8 billion over the next three years.
Its going to be a long haul,

input: Aside from LGs crazily stunning OLED Canyon, the biggest smack-you-round-the-face televisual spectacle of the 2018 CES comes courtesy of Samsungs The Wall.
continuation:
Samsungs The Wall is a giant LED wall that will be installed in New Yorks Times Square this summer. Itll be able to display anything you can think of, and its going to cost around $1 billion.

This isnt the first time weve seen something like this. Back in 2013, Samsung showed off a similar concept at its Unpacked event, but this one has a few more bells and whistles.

For starters, itll be capable of displaying 360-degree videos. This means that you can watch your favourite TV show or movie from any angle you want.

Itll also have built-in Wi-Fi, so you can stream content from your phone or tablet without having to leave the room.

Of course, theres no word on exactly how many people are going to be able to get their hands on this thing, or when itll actually go up for sale.

Were not entirely sure what Samsungs trying to do with this thing, but its definitely an interesting idea. Let us know your thoughts in the comments

Samsung The Wall is a giant LED wall that will be installed in New York City's Times Square this summer. It will be able to display anything you can think of and will cost about $1 billion.

This isn't the first time I've seen something like this. In 2013, Samsung showed off a similar concept at his Unpacked event, but with some additional features.

First, you will be able to view 360-degree videos. This means you can watch your favorite TV shows and movies from every angle.

It also has built-in Wi-Fi, so you can stream content from your phone or tablet without leaving your room.

Of course, it remains to be seen how many people will be able to get their hands on this item and when it will actually go on sale.

We're not entirely sure what Samsung is planning to do with this, but it's definitely an interesting idea. Let us know what you think in the comments.

input:
You made the Forbes Africa 30 Under 30 2018 list. Would you consider that your greatest career accomplishment?
I must say I feel honoured to be listed as one of Forbes 30 Under 30. However, I believe its a call
continuation:
to action for all young people who are passionate about their work and want to make an impact on the world around them.
How did you get involved in entrepreneurship?
My journey into entrepreneurship began when I was just 13 years old. My parents encouraged me to start my own business because they saw how much I enjoyed working with my hands and making things happen. It was then that I decided to pursue a degree in Business Administration at Stellenbosch University (SU).
What do you think is the biggest challenge facing entrepreneurs today?
Entrepreneurship has always been challenging, but its become even more so in the last few years. Entrepreneurship requires a lot of hard work, dedication, and perseverance. You need to have a strong belief in what youre doing and not give up. If you dont put in the time and effort, you wont succeed.
What advice would you give to someone starting out in entrepreneurship?
Its important to have a clear vision of what you want to achieve. When you know exactly what you want to achieve, you can focus your efforts and energy on achieving that goal instead of worrying about everything else that could go wrong.
translation:
You have been included in the Forbes 2018 Africa 30 Under 30 list. Do you consider this the biggest accomplishment of your career?
I have to say I'm honored to be included in the Forbes 30 Under 30 list. But I believe this is a call to action for all young people who are passionate about their work and want to make an impact on the world around them.
How did you start your business?
My entrepreneurial journey began when I was just 13 years old. My parents encouraged me to start my own business when they saw how much I enjoyed working with my hands and getting results. That's when I decided to pursue a degree in Business Administration at Stellenbosch University (SU).
What do you think is the biggest challenge facing entrepreneurs today?
Entrepreneurship has always been difficult, but it has become even more difficult in recent years. Entrepreneurship requires a lot of work, dedication, and patience. You need to have strong belief in what you are doing and never give up. If you don't put in the time and effort, you won't succeed.
What advice would you give to someone starting out as an entrepreneur?
It's important to be clear about what you want to achieve. When you know exactly what you want to achieve, you can focus your efforts and energy on achieving that goal instead of worrying about everything else that could go wrong.

input:
Polands ruling conservative government has moved to reinstate supreme court judges it forcibly retired, acting on an injunction issued by Europes highest court.
On Wednesday the Law and Justice (PiS) party submitted the relevant legislation on
continuation:
judicial reform to the lower house of parliament, which is due to vote on it next week.
The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in Strasbourg ruled in October that Poland had violated the right to a fair trial by forcing the Supreme Court judges to retire without giving them a chance to defend their cases.
The ECHR ordered Poland to reinstate all the judges who had been forced to retire, but the PiS government refused to do so.
In a statement published on its website, the justice ministry said the bill would strengthen the independence of the judiciary and guarantee the rule of law.
It added: We are confident that this bill will be approved by the lower house of parliament as soon as possible.
The move comes amid growing concern about the independence of the Polish judiciary after the countrys Constitutional Tribunal ruled last month that the constitution should be amended to allow President Andrzej Duda to run for re-election in 2023.
Duda is currently barred from seeking a third consecutive term in office because of term limits.
Critics say the tribunals ruling could pave the way for the president to appoint his own successor, potentially undermining the
translation:
Poland's ruling conservative government has moved to reinstate a Supreme Court judge who was forcibly removed from office following an injunction from the European Supreme Court.
The Law and Justice (PiS) party submitted a judicial reform bill to the House of Commons on Wednesday, with a vote expected next week.
The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) in Strasbourg ruled in October that Poland had violated the right to a fair trial by forcing a Supreme Court judge to resign without giving him a chance to defend himself.
The ECHR ordered Poland to reinstate all judges who were forced to resign, but the PiS government refused.
The Ministry of Justice said in a statement on its website that the bill will strengthen the independence of the judiciary and guarantee the rule of law.
"I am confident that this bill will be approved by the House of Representatives as soon as possible," he added.
The move comes amid growing concerns about the independence of Poland's judiciary after Poland's Constitutional Court ruled last month that the constitution should be amended to allow President Andrzej Duda to stand for re-election in 2023. .
Duda is currently barred from running for a third consecutive term due to term limits.
Critics say the court's decision could pave the way for the president to name a successor, potentially undermining his administration.

input: In the most Well, duh news youll read this week, Moto2 rider Romano Fenati got dumped by his current team and, most likely, the team he planned to run for in 2019 after grabbing another
continuation:
top-10 finish at last weekends Aragon Grand Prix.

Fenati was one of only two riders to score points in the first four races of the season, but has since dropped down to 14th in the championship standings. He had a crash in qualifying on Saturday that left him with a broken wrist, which forced him to miss Sundays race.

The Italian will be replaced by fellow Italian Luca Marini, who currently sits in 15th place in the championship standings. It remains to be seen how much of an impact the switch will have on the 22-year-old, but its safe to say hes not happy about it.

Im very disappointed because I really wanted to fight for the podium, Fenati said in a press release. Id like to thank my team for giving me the opportunity to ride for them. Id also like to thank the fans for their support.

Ive been working hard for the past three years to get to this point and now I want to keep going. I hope to be back racing soon.
translation:
Most of the news you read this week is about Moto2 rider Romano Fenati being dropped from his current team, and possibly the team he was set to ride for in 2019, after finishing in the top 10 again at the Aragon Grand Prix. last weekend.

Fenati was one of only two drivers to score points in the first four races of the season, but has since fallen to 14th in the championship standings. On Saturday, he was involved in a crash during qualifying and broke his wrist, causing him to miss Sunday's race.

The Italian will be replaced by his compatriot Luca Marini, who is currently ranked 15th in the championship standings. It remains to be seen how this move will affect the 22-year-old, but it's safe to say he's not happy about it.

"I'm very disappointed because I really wanted to fight for the podium," Fenati said in a press release. I would like to thank the team for giving me the opportunity to compete. I would also like to thank my fans for their support.

I've been working hard for the past three years, and I want to continue doing so. I hope to be back racing soon.

Security always comes down to securing applications.
The whole point of firewalls is to hide internally deployed network applicationsassumed to have exploitable vulnerabilities somewherefrom the outside world.
The main weakness of firewalls is that they are
continuation:
only as good as their weakest link, and this can be a problem if you dont know exactly where that weak link is.
This is why it is important for security teams to understand the attack surface of their applications, so they can take steps to protect them.
But how do you do this?
To find out, I spoke with two experts in application vulnerability management (AVM) about the best way to do this.
First, lets take a look at some of the most common ways attackers try to get into your network.
1. Remote Code Execution
Remote code execution (RCE) occurs when an attacker has physical access to your network.
In other words, a hacker can gain remote access to your network by simply connecting to your network from another computer or device on the internet.
Its easy to think of RCE as something that happens to other peoples computers, but its actually much more widespread than that.
In fact, according to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), nearly half of all cyberattacks occur through RCE.
2. Exploitation of Vulnerabilities

input:
A public policy group says states should not rush into leasing existing road assets to the private sector.
In a report released Tuesday, March 24, the Philadelphia-based Pew Center on the States urged states considering public-private partnerships for infrastructure to exercise caution
continuation:
.
The report comes as state and local governments are struggling to balance their budgets amid the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic, which has shut down much of the U.S. economy.
Pew said it is concerned that some states may be rushing to privatize roads and bridges without fully understanding the risks involved in doing so.
"It's important to remember that these projects will take years to complete, and they will likely require significant investment over the next decade," the report said. "States must carefully weigh the potential benefits of PPPs against the long-term costs."
Public-private partnerships have been used in many parts of the world, including in the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand and Canada. In the U.S., the federal government owns more than 90% of the nation's highways, according to the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO).
In Pennsylvania, Gov. Tom Wolf signed an executive order last month directing the state Department of Transportation to work with PennDOT and other state agencies to develop a plan to lease or sell state-owned roadways to private companies. The order also directed the department to seek proposals from private companies to build, operate

continuation:
Diego was defeated last week.

The California Family Council, which has spent more than $1 million on the campaign, said Tuesday that it will no longer support Measure C, which would have prohibited doctors from performing circumcisions without parental consent.

Were disappointed, but we dont think its going to go anywhere, the groups executive director, Michael Rabinowitz, said in a telephone interview. This is not about religion. Its about protecting childrens health.

Mr. Rabinowitz said he did not know what motivated the change of heart. He declined to say how much money the council had spent on the campaign.

In a statement, Mr. Rabinowitz called the measure unnecessary and harmful.

Circumcision should be a personal decision between parents and their child, he said. Its not a medical procedure, and its not necessary for boys to grow up to be healthy men.

A spokesman for the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors said Tuesday that the board does not plan
translation:
LOS ANGELES - A leading proponent of an effort to ban circumcision from the Santa Monica ballot is withdrawing the proposed bill, claiming it has been misrepresented as an attempt to attack religious freedom. A similar bill in San Diego failed last week.

The Family Council of California, which has spent more than $1 million on the campaign, announced Tuesday that it will no longer support Measure C, which would prohibit doctors from performing circumcisions without parental consent.

"It's unfortunate, but I don't think there's anything we can do about it," the group's chief executive, Michael Rabinowitz, said in a telephone interview. This is not about religion. We are talking about protecting the health of children.

Rabinowitz said he did not know what prompted the change of heart. He declined to say how much money the City Council spent on the campaign.

Mr. Rabinovich said in his statement that the measure was unnecessary and harmful.

He said circumcision should be a personal decision between parents and children. This is not a medical procedure and does not require the boy to grow up to be a healthy man.

A spokesperson for the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors said Tuesday that the board does not have a plan.

input: The Promise: Using the Apple device's built-in accelerometers, the Dynolicious application measures vehicle acceleration (0-60 mph, 1/4-mile trap speed and elapsed time, etc), and cornering and braking grip. With that
continuation:
information, the app can be used to simulate driving a real car.

The Reality: The app is not as accurate as you might think. For one thing, it doesn't take into account wind resistance or steering angle. It also doesn't account for the fact that most cars are equipped with electronic stability control (ESC) and traction control (TC). In other words, the Dynolicious app is more of a "feel" simulator than anything else.

Still, if you're looking for a fun way to learn about how your car handles on the road, this is a good place to start. If you want to get a better idea of what it's like to drive a real car, check out our list of the best driving simulators for iOS.

Dynolicious ($2.99) | App Store

translation:
Promise: The Dynolicious app uses your Apple device's built-in accelerometer to measure vehicle acceleration (0-90 mph, quarter-mile speed, elapsed time, etc.) and cornering and braking grip. . Using this information, you can use the app to simulate driving a real car.

Reality: This app is not as accurate as you think. First, it doesn't take into account wind resistance or steering angle. It also doesn't take into account the fact that most cars are equipped with electronic stability control (ESC) and traction control (TC). In other words, the Dynolicious app is more of an "emotion" simulator than anything else.

However, if you're looking for a fun way to learn how your car behaves on the road, this is a good place to start. If you want a deeper understanding of what it's like to drive a real car, check out our list of the best driving simulators for iOS.

Dinoricius ($2.99) | App Store

input: ORLANDO -- Leading Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson believes that federal and state official overreacted in trying to save Terri Schiavo, a Florida woman who died in 2005 as her husband and family battled over whether to keep her alive despite her
continuation:
severe brain damage.

Carson made the comments during an interview with The Christian Broadcasting Network's "The 700 Club" on Friday.

Schiavo was placed on a ventilator when she was 18 months old after her parents took her off life support because they feared she would die without food or water. Her feeding tube was removed at age 24.

Her husband, George, had argued for years that he should have been allowed to make the final decision about keeping his wife alive. He died of a heart attack two years later.

Carson told host Pat Robertson: "I don't know what happened there. I'm not a lawyer, but it seems to me that if you're going to take someone off life support, you should be able to do that. You shouldn't have to go through all this legal stuff."

Robertson responded by saying, "You're not a lawyer?"

"No, I'm not," Carson said. "I'm just a regular guy."

He added: "There's no law that says you can't take your spouse off life support."

Carson also criticized President Barack Obama's health care law, saying it is "a disaster
translation:
ORLANDO -- Leading Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson tried to save Terry Schiavo, a Florida woman who died in 2005 as her husband and family fought to save her life despite severe brain damage. believes federal and state authorities overreacted.

Carson made the comments Friday in an interview with Christian Broadcasting Network's "The 700 Club."

Schiavo was placed on a ventilator when she was 18 months old after her parents removed her from life support, fearing she would die without food and water. . When she was 24 years old, she had her feeding tube removed.

Her husband, George, had long maintained that he should have had the final say on whether to keep his wife alive. Two years later he died of a heart attack.

Carson told host Pat Robertson: I'm not a lawyer, but I think if you're going to take someone off life support, you should be able to do that. There should be no need to go through all of these legal procedures. 

Robertson replied, "Aren't you a lawyer?"

"No, that's not true," Carson said. "I'm a normal guy."

It added: "There is no law prohibiting removing a spouse from life support."

Carson also criticized President Barack Obama's health care law, calling it a "disaster."

continuation:
that kind of success, but Shopify has managed to do it by focusing on its core business and investing heavily in product development and marketing.

That strategy paid off in spades last quarter, as Shopify saw revenue grow more than 100% year over year. The company also reported an adjusted earnings per share of $0.08, which was up from $0.03 in the same period a year ago. That beat analysts' expectations by a wide margin, and it's the first time Shopify has beaten estimates in three consecutive quarters.

Shopify has long been one of the most cash-generative companies in the world. In fact, it's one of the few public companies with a negative net cash position.

Shopify ended the third quarter with $3.2 billion in cash and marketable

It's not easy to replicate such success, but Shopify has been able to do so by focusing on its core business and investing heavily in product development and marketing.

Shopify has been one of the most profitable companies in the world for many years. In fact, the company is one of the few publicly traded companies with a negative net cash position.

Shopify ended the third quarter with $3.2 billion in cash and liquid assets.

Hamid Ismailovs EBRD Literature Prize-winning Uzbek novel puts Central Asian literature in focus.
On December 31, 1937, 20th-century Uzbekistans most popular novelist, Abdulla Qodir
continuation:
zhanov, was arrested by the Soviet secret police and sentenced to 15 years in a labor camp for subversion of the socialist system.
The following year, he published his first book, a collection of short stories entitled A Tale of Two Cities, which is still widely regarded as one of the countrys greatest works of fiction.
In the years that followed, he wrote several more novels, including The Night Watchman (1942) and The Last Days of the Great Patriotic War (1944), both of which have been translated into dozens of languages.
Abdulla Qodirzhanov died at the age of 80 on February 1, 2020. He was awarded the prestigious Hamid Ismailov Prize for Literature in 2018. The prize is given annually to an author from Central Asia who has written a work of outstanding literary merit.
Qodirzhanovs Tale of Two Cities is set in Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan. It tells the story of two young menone of whom is a member of the Communist Party and the other a member of the
translation:
Hamid Ismailov's Uzbek novels, winner of the EBRD Literary Prize, pay particular attention to Central Asian literature.
On December 31, 1937, Uzbekistan's most popular writer of the 20th century, Abdulla Kodyrzhanov, was arrested by the Soviet secret police and sentenced to 15 years in a forced labor camp on charges of undermining the socialist system. He was sentenced.
The following year, he published his first book, a collection of short stories called A Tale of Two Cities, which is still considered one of the country's best works of fiction.
He then wrote several more novels, including The Night Watch (1942) and The Last Days of the Great Patriotic War (1944), both of which were translated into dozens of languages.
Abdulla Kodirzhanov passed away on February 1, 2020 at the age of 80. In 2018, he received the prestigious Hamid Ismailov Literary Award. This award is awarded annually to a Central Asian writer who has written a work of outstanding literary merit.
A Tale of Two Cities, directed by Kodyrzhanov, is set in Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan. This is a story about two young people. One is a member of the Communist Party and the other is a party member.

input: THE economic plan being chartered during the ongoing 2017-2018 budget debate aims to stabilise the countrys finances, Deputy Prime Minister K Peter Turnquest said yesterday, as he underscored the continued need to reduce discretionary spending
continuation:
.

Turnquest was responding to a question from Opposition Leader Kamla Persad-Bissessar on whether there would be any cuts in government spending under his administration.

He said that while it is important to maintain fiscal prudence, it is also important to ensure that government expenditure does not exceed its revenue generation capacity.

We have to look at our discretionary spending and make sure that we are not overspending or underspending, he said.

Turnquest was responding to a question posed by Persad-Bissessar, who had asked if the government would consider cutting some of the $2.3 billion allocated for the National Insurance Scheme (NIS) and other social welfare programmes.

Persad-Bissessar pointed out that this years budget has allocated $1.7 billion more than what was spent last year.

Turnquest said that the government will have to look at how it can continue to provide social services.

I am very concerned about the NIS because I think it is one of the most important social programmes that we have in this country. We cannot afford to let it go down the drain

Deputy Prime Minister Peter Turnquest said yesterday that the economic plan approved during the ongoing 2017-18 budget deliberations was aimed at stabilizing the country's finances, with continued cuts to discretionary spending. emphasized the need.

Mr Turnquest was responding to a question from opposition leader Kamla Persad-Bissessar on whether there would be cuts in government spending under the government.

He said it was important to be fiscally prudent, but it was also important to ensure that government spending did not exceed its revenue-generating capacity.

"We need to review our discretionary spending and see if we are overspending or underspending," he said.

Mr. Turnquest responded to a question from Mr. Persado-Bissessar, who asked whether the government would consider cutting some of the $2.3 billion allocated to the National Insurance System (NIS) and other social security programs. answered.

Persado-Bissessar noted that this year's budget allocated $1.7 billion more than last year's spending.

Mr Turnquest said the government needed to think about how it could continue to provide social services.

I think he is very concerned about NIS. Because we believe that NIS is one of the most important social programs our country has. We can't let this go to waste.

A GP clinic in Edinburgh which is changing to a telephone assessment system three days a week has warned its 6,000 patients they could be turned away.
The changes at the Links Medical Centre come into force on Wednesday, May 1.
A statement
continuation:
from NHS Lothian said: We have been working closely with our partners at the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) and we are confident that these changes will provide an improved service for both patients and staff.
Patients who do not wish to use the telephone service can still contact us by calling 0131 456 2222 or emailing enquiries@linksmedicalcentre.nhs.lothian.gov.uk.
However, some patients have expressed concern about the change.
One patient told the Evening News: "I'm very concerned about this. I've been seeing my GP for over 30 years and it's always been done face-to-face.
"It's a bit of a worry."
Another added: "I don't think it's a good idea to switch to telemedicine because there's no guarantee you'll get through to someone."
NHS Lothian chief executive officer David Macdonald said: "We know that many people rely on their GP practice as a first point of call when they need medical advice or treatment.

LOWER PAXTON TOWNSHIP, DAUPHIN COUNTY, Pa. - Police are reminding people of the importance of reporting crimes to police and not just posting about them on social media.
If you're a social media user,
continuation:
police say it's important to be aware of what your posts can do to others.
The Lower Penn Township Police Department is asking for the public's help in identifying a man who robbed a convenience store at gunpoint earlier this month.
Police said the incident happened around 4:30 p.m. on July 7 at the Circle K located at 515 N. Main St.
The suspect entered the store and demanded money from the clerk. He then fled the scene with an undisclosed amount of cash.
The suspect was described as a black male between the ages of 20 and 25 years old, standing approximately 6 feet tall and weighing approximately 180 pounds. He has short black hair and brown eyes.
Anyone with information is asked to call police at (717) 569-4100 or submit an anonymous tip online at www.penncountycrimestoppers.com or by texting "PACC" plus your message to CRIMES (274637). Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a reward up to $1,000.

Now that flood waters have begun to recede, Texas victims of Tropical Storm Harvey face another challenge: eviction notices. Even worse, some people are still on the hook for rent on apartments they cant live in.
Sheri Ilo
continuation:
, who lives in a Houston-area apartment with her husband and two young children, says shes owed more than $5,000 in back rent from her landlord.
Im not going to pay it, she told CNN affiliate KTRK. I just dont know what Im going to do. I dont know if were going to be able to make our mortgage payments.
Harvey, which made landfall as a Category 4 hurricane on August 25, has killed at least 68 people and caused an estimated $125 billion in damage. The storm is expected to bring up to 10 inches of rain to parts of the state over the next few days, according to the National Weather Service (NWS).
The NWS issued a flash flood watch for Harris County until 6 p.m. local time Sunday, warning residents to prepare for heavy rains and possible flooding in low-lying areas.
Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner has declared a state of emergency for the city, freeing up resources to help those affected by the storm. He said he was working with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to coordinate relief efforts

Now that the floodwaters have begun to recede, victims of Tropical Storm Harvey in Texas are facing another problem: eviction notices. Even worse, some people want to rent an apartment they can't live in.
Sheri Iro, who lives in a Houston-area apartment with her husband and two young children, says she owes her landlord more than $5,000 in rent.
"I'm not going to pay," she told CNN affiliate KTRK. I don't know what to do. She doesn't know if she can pay the mortgage.

Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner declared a state of emergency in the city, freeing up resources to help those affected by the hurricane. He said he was working with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to coordinate relief efforts.

input:
The island lifestyle may have unknown benefits, as Hawaii residents are the only ones in the country with an average life expectancy of 81 years.
Experts recommend that adults get at least seven hours of sleep per night, but 44.7% of Hawaiians
continuation:
dont get enough, according to a 2016 report by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
A new study published in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine suggests that getting eight hours of sleep each night could help protect against heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and other chronic diseases.
Researchers from Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston analyzed data from more than 5,000 men and women who took part in the Health Professionals Follow-Up Study. The participants were asked about their sleep habits, including how often they fell asleep or woke up during the night, and how long it took them to get back into bed after waking up.
They also answered questions about whether they smoked, drank alcohol, or had high blood pressure, among other health conditions.
After adjusting for age, race, education level, body mass index (BMI), and other factors, researchers found that people who got eight hours of sleep each night were less likely to be diagnosed with heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and other chronic diseases.
Our findings suggest that a healthy sleep pattern can reduce the risk of developing cardiovascular disease, said senior author Dr. David L. Hamermesh,

An NYPD administrative judge and its firearms review panel criticized the conduct of three police officers involved in the 2012 shooting death of a Bronx 18-year-old, records obtained by the Daily News show.
The judge's decision involving Officer Richard Haste, who
continuation:
was charged with second-degree manslaughter last year for his role in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, is the first time that the panel has publicly addressed the case.
Haste had been on desk duty when he fatally shot Diallo during a traffic stop on Dec. 21, 2012.
In a letter to Chief of Department Terence Monahan, Judge Robert Kugler wrote: "I am troubled by the manner in which this matter has been handled."
Kugler also questioned whether Haste should have been allowed to return to active duty after being suspended without pay for two months following his arrest.
"It would be difficult to find a more egregious example of an officer violating departmental rules and regulations than this incident," Kugler said.
Monahan did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Haste's lawyer, Joseph DePascale, declined to comment.
DePascale told the Daily News earlier this month that he plans to appeal the administrative judge's decision.
"We are confident that we will prevail at the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court," he said.

input: MEDELLIN, Colombia  Chiles Palestino qualified for the third round of the Copa Libertadores on Tuesday after beating Colombian side Independiente Medellin on penalties to win the second leg of the second round at
continuation:
the Estadio Nacional.

The game ended 1-1 after 90 minutes and went into extra time, which was decided by a penalty shootout following a 0-0 draw after 120 minutes.

Chile took the lead in the 11th minute when Mauro Zarate scored his first goal for the Chilean national team from the penalty spot.

Colombia equalized three minutes later through Juan Cuadrado, but Pablo Piatti put Chile back in front just before halftime with a header from a corner kick.

In the second half, Chile had several chances to score more goals, but they were unable to find the back of the net.

Medellin goalkeeper Carlos Lampe made some good saves in the second half to keep the scoreline level, but it was not enough to advance to the next round.

Chile will now face Argentina in the third round of the tournament. The match will be played at the Monumental de Nueva Inglaterra in Buenos Aires, Argentina on Wednesday, January 10 at 7:30 p.m. ET.

Follow @JPW_NBCSports

(Photo Credit: Getty Images North America)

continuation:
their hands dirty.

One such group is the Cloud Computing Alliance (CCA), which was founded in January 2009 by several companies including Amazon Web Services (AWS), Rackspace and Microsoft. It aims to "bring together the worlds leading cloud service providers so they can share best practices and learn from each other," according to its mission statement.

The CCA is not a government agency, but rather an industry association. Its members include AWS, Rackspace, IBM, Cisco Systems, EMC, HPE, Juniper Networks, Novell, Oracle, Sun Microsystems, Symantec, VMware and VMWare, among others.

"We've been working closely with the CCA for some time, and we look forward to continuing to work with them."

input:
We take the new TRENDnet TEW-809UB AC1900 wireless USB adapter for a spin. Should it be on your shopping list? Let's find out.
For the longest time, AC1900 adapters were regulated to the PCIe interface due
continuation:
to their high bandwidth and low power consumption. However, as we've seen with the recent release of the Intel Core i7-8700K and AMD Ryzen 7 2700X processors, this isn't always the case.
With that in mind, TRENDnet has released an AC1900 wireless USB adapter that can be used with both Intel and AMD chipsets. It also supports 802.11ac Wi-Fi and Bluetooth 5.0.
TRENDnet TEW-809UB: What you need to know
The TEW-809UB is a dual-band (2.4GHz/5GHz) 802.11ac Wi-Fi/Bluetooth 5.0 device that comes with a USB Type-C port. This allows you to connect up to two devices at the same time via USB 3.1 Gen 2 Type-C ports.
There are two USB Type-A ports, one of which is dedicated to charging while the other is for data transfer. You'll find a microSD card slot on the back as well, so you can expand the storage capacity if needed. The TEW-809UB is compatible with Windows 10, Mac OS X, Android, iOS, and Linux operating systems.
translation:
Testing the new TRENDnet TEW-809UB AC1900 wireless USB adapter. Should you add this to your shopping list? Let's find out.
AC1900 adapters have long been adopted for PCIe interfaces due to their high throughput and low power consumption. However, this is not always the case, as we saw with the recent releases of the Intel Core i7-8700K and AMD Ryzen 7 2700X processors.
With this in mind, TRENDnet has released the AC1900 wireless USB adapter for use with Intel and AMD chipsets. Also supports Wi-Fi 802.11ac and Bluetooth 5.0.
TRENDnet TEW-809UB: What you need to know
TEW-809UB is a dual-band (2.4GHz/5GHz) 802.11ac Wi-Fi/Bluetooth 5.0 device with USB Type-C port. This allows you to connect up to two devices simultaneously via the USB 3.1 Gen 2 Type-C port.
There are two USB Type-A ports, one for charging and one for data transfer. There's also a microSD card slot on the back, allowing you to expand your storage if needed. TEW-809UB is compatible with Windows 10, Mac OS X, Android, iOS, and Linux operating systems.

input: File photograph by George Sakkestad. Saratoga High School junior Iris Lu spends some time studying in the schools library last Fall. Saratoga High School ranked 4th-best in California on Niche.com
continuation:
s list of the best high schools in the United States.

Saratoga High School ranked 4th-best in California on Niche.coms list of the best high schools in the United States.

Niche, a website that ranks schools based on criteria such as test scores, graduation rates and extracurricular activities, released its list of the top 1,000 public high schools in the country this week. The rankings are based on data from the U.S. News & World Reports 2013-14 Best High Schools Rankings, which were released earlier this month.

In addition to being named one of the best high schools in the nation, Saratoga was also recognized for having the highest average ACT score of any school in the state.

I think its really cool, said senior Iris Lu, who is majoring in business administration with an emphasis in marketing. Its definitely a big accomplishment. Im very proud of my school. Weve been working hard all year to get where we are right now. It means a lot to me.

input:
Chattanooga instituted a similar program in 2006. That city has about 6,400 employees compared to Lexington's 6,000.
The director of risk management there told the council the program is saving the city about $5 million a year, making
continuation:
it one of the most cost-effective insurance programs in the country.
"We've been very pleased with the results," he said. "I think we're on the right track."
Councilman Jim Shuler, D-4th Ward, was the only council member to vote against the measure. He cited concerns that the city would have to pay more for workers' compensation coverage if the program were to be expanded.
Shuler also questioned whether the city would be able to maintain its current level of coverage if the program were to expand.
"What I'm worried about is what happens when you get to a point where you can't cover all your claims," he said. "You're going to have a lot of people who are going to lose their jobs because they're not covered."
City Manager Mark Bragg said the city would need to look at other options if it decided to go ahead with expanding the program.
"It's important to remember that this is a pilot project and we don't know exactly how it will work out," he said. "We want to make sure we're doing everything we can to keep our costs as low as possible while still being able to provide good benefits to our employees."
translation:
Chattanooga introduced a similar program in 2006. The city has about 6,400 employees, while Lexington has 6,000 employees.
The emergency management director told the City Council that the program saves the city about $5 million a year, making it one of the most cost-effective insurance programs in the country.
We are very happy with the results, he said. "I think we're on the right path."
Councilman Jim Shuler (D-4th District) was the only council member to vote against the bill. He expressed concern that the city would have to pay more for workers' compensation coverage if the program was expanded.
Schuler also questioned whether the city would be able to maintain its current level of coverage if the program were to expand.
My concern is what happens when we get to the point where we cant cover all the claims, he said. "There's going to be a lot of people out of work because they don't have insurance."
City Manager Mark Bragg said if the city decides to continue expanding the program, it will need to consider other options.
"It's important to remember that this is a pilot project and we don't know exactly how it will work," he said. We want to make sure we do everything we can to keep costs as low as possible while providing adequate benefits to our employees.

Already making use of USB 3.1 on your PC? Take a look at Vantec's latest NexStar external storage device for SSDs and small HDDs.
As the flood gates open for USB 3.1 devices, the storage market
continuation:
is starting to get flooded with products that support this new standard. While there are plenty of options available from companies like Western Digital, Seagate and Toshiba, what about those who have already invested in an external hard drive or solid-state drive (SSD) but don't want to replace it with a new one just yet?
If you're looking for an external storage device that can be used with both USB 2.0 and 3.0 ports, then you'll definitely want to check out Vantec's NexStar line of drives. The company recently announced its newest addition to its NexStar lineup: the NexStar 5500 External Solid State Drive (SSD), which supports USB 3.1 speeds up to 10Gbps. This means that users will be able to take advantage of the full potential of their existing SSDs without having to replace them.
"We've been working closely with our customers to ensure they have the best experience possible when it comes to USB 3.1," said Vantec's vice president of product marketing, Chris Kresser. "With the introduction of the NexStar 5500, we're giving users the ability to enjoy faster transfer speeds than ever before."
NexStar 5500

input:
How David Bowie helped my autistic son become himself.
When my son Benj was a small boy of 4 and 5 with virtually no original language and no ability or desire to play in conventional ways, he and I connected through music. I
continuation:
m not sure how it happened, but one day we were sitting on the couch watching TV together when I suddenly realized that he had a song stuck in his head  Space Oddity by The Who. It was the first time Id ever heard him sing anything other than gibberish.
I asked him if he knew what the song was about, and he looked at me blankly for a few seconds. Then he started singing the words, and I could see the lightbulb go off in his head. Oh, yeah! he said. Its about space!
Benj has always been fascinated by space. He loved Star Wars as a kid, and hes always been fascinated by the idea of going to another planet and exploring its mysteries. He loves science fiction movies like Star Trek, and hes always wanted to be an astronaut.
But he didnt have any interest in playing with toys or building things. He just wanted to sit quietly and listen to the radio.
Thats when I decided to try something different. I bought him a set of headphones and told him he could listen to whatever
translation:
How David Bowie helped his autistic son grow up to be himself.
When my son Benji was a little boy, he was 4 or he was 5, he spoke very little native language and was unable or unwilling to play in the traditional way, but he and I connected through music. I don't know how it happened, but one day we were sitting on the couch watching TV and suddenly he had a song in his head called Space Oddity by The Who. I noticed. It was the first time I ever heard him sing something other than gibberish.
I asked him if he knew what the song was about and he stared blankly at me for a few seconds. Then when he started singing those lyrics, I saw a light bulb go on in his head. oh yeah! He said. We're talking about space!
Benji has always been fascinated by space. He has loved Star Wars since he was a child and was always fascinated by the idea of going to another planet and exploring its mysteries. He loves his science fiction movies, such as Star Trek, and he has always wanted to be an astronaut.
However, he had no interest in playing with toys or building anything. He just wanted to sit quietly and listen to the radio.
Then he decided to try something different. I bought him headphones and told him he could listen to whatever he wanted.

input:
The most popular teething rings contain hormone-disrupting chemicals, a new study warns.
Endocrine-disrupting chemicals are banned from use in products for children.
However, no studies have ever tested plastic teethers for
continuation:
their potential to disrupt the endocrine system.
A team of researchers at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) has now discovered that these chemical compounds can be absorbed through the skin and enter the body via the gastrointestinal tract.
They say this could lead to long-term health problems, such as increased risk of breast cancer.
Scroll down for video
A team of researchers at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) has now discovered that these chemical compounds can be absorbed through the skin and enter the body via the gastrointestinal tract (stock image)
WHAT ARE ENDOMORPHINES? Endorphins are naturally occurring hormones produced by the brain and released into the bloodstream when an individual feels pleasure or pain. They are also known as 'feel-good' hormones because they help us feel good about ourselves and our lives. Endorphins play a key role in the regulation of many bodily functions, including mood, appetite, sleep, memory and learning. Endorphin levels are high during pregnancy and early childhood, but begin to decline rapidly after birth. Source: National Institute on Drug Abuse Advertisement
The study, published in the journal Environmental Health Perspectives, was led by UCSD School of Medicine
translation:
The most popular pacifiers contain hormone-disrupting chemicals, a new study warns.
Endocrine disrupting chemicals are prohibited in children's products.
However, no studies have tested plastic pacifiers for their potential to disrupt the endocrine system.
A team of researchers at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) found that these compounds can be absorbed through the skin and enter the body through the gastrointestinal tract.
They say it can cause long-term health problems, including an increased risk of breast cancer.
Scroll down to watch the video
A team of researchers from the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) found that these compounds can be absorbed through the skin and enter the body through the gastrointestinal tract (File image).
What are endomorphins? Endorphins are natural hormones produced by the brain that are released into the bloodstream when a person experiences pleasure or pain. These are also called "feel good" hormones because they help us feel good about ourselves and our lives. Endorphins play an important role in regulating many bodily functions, including mood, appetite, sleep, memory, and learning. Endorphin levels are high during pregnancy and infancy, but begin to decline rapidly after birth. Source: National Institute on Drug Abuse and Advertising
The study, published in the journal Environment Health Perspectives, was conducted by the UCSD School of Medicine.

input: Winchendon is a small country town in northern Massachusetts, right on the border with New Hampshire. The local rustic landscapes lends to outdoor activities such as hiking, cycling, boating, fishing, swimming and other adventures at Lakes Monomonac
continuation:
and Monomond.

The town has a population of approximately 2,000 people. It was founded in 1636 by William Winchcombe, an English settler who came to the area looking for land to farm. Winchcombes son, also named William, took over the family business after his fathers death.

Today, Winchcombe Farms is one of the largest dairy farms in the United States, producing more than 100 million gallons of milk per year. The company also produces cheese, butter, ice cream, and yogurt.

In addition to its agricultural operations, Winchcombe Farms offers a wide range of recreational activities, including horseback riding, canoeing, kayaking, biking, golf, tennis, and swimming.

There are several wineries within walking distance of the Winchcombe Farm. One of the best places to enjoy wine tasting is at the Winchcombe Vineyard. This winery is located just a few minutes away from the Winchcombe Farm. You can find out more information about this winery on their website: http://www.winchcombevineyards.com/

input: The Chancellor has taken to the TV studios once ahead of what was intended to be the UKs final week inside the European Union. He needed up commenting on reports in several of this mornings papers that the Cabinet was preparing to oust
continuation:
Theresa May as Prime Minister and replace her with a new leader who would try to negotiate a better Brexit deal.

He said: I think it is very important that we are clear-eyed about the challenges facing our country over the next few weeks, but I also think it is important that we do not allow ourselves to get distracted by those distractions.

Mr Hammond added: We need to make sure that we are focused on the task at hand, which is to deliver a strong economic recovery from the effects of the global financial crisis.

His comments come just hours after The Times reported that Mrs May had been told by senior ministers that she could face a vote of no confidence if she does not agree to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement with Brussels.

Downing Street declined to comment on the story when contacted by the Press Association.

In his interview with Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday, Mr Hammond said he did not want to pre-empt the outcome of any vote of no confidence.

I dont think its appropriate for me to speculate on what might happen in the House of Commons. We will have to wait and see
translation:
The prime minister visited a television studio ahead of what was expected to be Britain's last week in the European Union. He was required to comment on reports in several morning newspapers that the Cabinet Office was preparing to oust Theresa May as prime minister and replace her with a new leader who would try to negotiate a better Brexit deal. there were.

"I think it's really important that we have a clear picture of the challenges facing our country over the coming weeks, but I also think it's important that we don't get distracted by these distractions," he said. Ta.

Mr Hammond added: "We need to ensure we remain focused on the immediate challenge of ensuring a strong economic recovery from the effects of the global financial crisis."

His comments came just hours after The Times reported that the Prime Minister had told Theresa May she could face a vote of no confidence if she did not agree to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement with Brussels.

Downing Street declined to comment on the matter when contacted by the Press Association.

Mr Hammond said in an interview with Sky News' Sophie Ridge on Sunday that he would not prejudge the outcome of the no-confidence vote.

I don't think it would be appropriate for me to speculate about what will happen in the House. I'll have to wait and see.
