This is the last of a series of essays on Adam Curtiss essay series All Watched Over by Machines of Loving Grace, which you can watch for free here. I previously wrote about the series here and here.
One of Curtis
continuation:
s central themes in this series is that we are all being watched over by an omnipotent, omniscient, omnibenevolent machine that has no interest in our happiness or well-being, but only in its own self-preservation. This machine, he writes, does not exist to make us happy; it exists to make sure that we dont kill each other.
Curtis goes on to describe how we are constantly being monitored by these machines through the use of surveillance cameras, facial recognition software, and other technologies. He argues that these technologies have become so ubiquitous that they have become part of our everyday lives.
In his latest book, The End of History and the Last Man: How the Digital Revolution Permanently Changes the Way We Live and Work, Curtis explores the implications of this new technology for society as a whole. In particular, he looks at the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) and how it will change the way we interact with one another in the future.
Here are some highlights from Curtiss discussion of AI.
Weve been watching each other since the dawn of time.

The Swedish Academy, which awards the prize, has decided not to award this years prize to the couple because they are no longer alive.
Their daughter Louise was conceived through in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) when she was just three months old.
Her mother, Lesley Brown, and her father, John Brown, died within weeks of each other in 2012.

They married in 1979 and divorced in 1992.

input: The medical device space is a slow-moving behemoth bogged down by regulation and in need of disruptive ideas and design innovation. In recent years, we've seen a number of interesting ideas emerge in the space from designing handwashing to the ways that
continuation:
wearable devices can help patients manage chronic conditions like diabetes or high blood pressure.

But there's still plenty of room for improvement when it comes to making health care more affordable and accessible. A new report from McKinsey & Company looks at some of the biggest challenges facing the sector and offers some suggestions on how to tackle them.

The report, titled "Healthcare Innovation: The Next Frontier," focuses on five key areas where the industry needs to focus its efforts:

Improving patient experience

Increasing access to care

Reducing costs

Eliminating waste

Improving patient outcomes

"Innovation is not just about coming up with new products and services; it's also about changing the way people think about healthcare," said McKinsey Global Institute managing partner John Vellardita in a statement. "We are witnessing a paradigm shift in the healthcare industry, as consumers increasingly demand better value for their dollars."

McKinsey found that the average American spends nearly $3,000 per year on healthcare, which is far higher than any other developed country in the world. As a result, the U.S. healthcare system has become one of the most expensive in the world.

The online registration for the merit based undergraduate courses in University of Delhi has concluded today after it was extended for one day.
New Delhi: The online registration for the merit based undergraduate courses in University of Delhi has concluded today after it was extended for one
continuation:
day. Candidates who have registered themselves can check their admission status by logging into the official website of the varsity at http://www.universityofdelhi.ac.in/index.php?option=com_k2&view=itemlist&task=user&id=8&Itemid=3.
Candidates are advised to keep a check on the universitys official website for more information regarding the admission process.
Earlier this month, the varsity had announced that it will be conducting entrance examinations for admission to its undergraduate courses from September 15 to October 5.
The exams will be held in offline mode and candidates will be given an option to appear for the exam in computer-based test (CBT) mode as well, if they wish to do so.

From Pennsylvania to Phuket, Iceland to Indonesia, the options are proliferating.
Eating in Paris once meant meat, cream and cheese. But not anymore. Just ask Portland resident Jennifer Willett, who visited Paris in September for a week
continuation:
-long vacation with her husband and two young daughters.
I had never been to Europe before, so I was very excited about it, she says. We were staying at a hotel on the Seine, which is right across the street from the Eiffel Tower, and we walked over there every day. We went to the Louvre, the Muse dOrsay and the Arc de Triomphe. It was such an amazing trip.
But when they arrived back in Portland, Willett found herself craving something different. She wanted to try some of the food shed seen while traveling.
I was looking for a new restaurant that wasnt too expensive, but also didnt have a lot of stuff on the menu that you couldnt find in the U.S. or other countries, she says.
Willett decided to go to one of her favorite restaurants in the city: La Boulangerie du Montmartre.
I love their croissants and their baguettes, Willett says. Its just a really nice place to eat

Future historians will probably refer to the first quarter of the 21st century as the Bike Age. Bikes are everywhere  and theres no escaping them.
No one denies that theyre a good idea in terms of reducing pollution
continuation:
, improving air quality, and making cities more livable. But is it enough?
A new report from the American Public Transportation Association (APTA) says that bike-share programs have been shown to reduce car trips by an average of 2.5 miles per person per day. Thats a pretty big improvement, but APTA also points out that the number of bikes on the road is still far too low to make a real dent in traffic congestion.
The report was based on a survey of 1,000 Americans who use public transportation or bike to work. The respondents were split evenly between those who own cars and those who dont.
Of course, this isnt the first time weve heard reports like this. A few years back, a study from the University of California, Davis found that bike-sharing programs reduced car trips by about 3.7 miles per day. And a recent study from the National Bureau of Economic Research found that bike-sharing programs reduced car trips by about 4.6 miles per day.
But the new APTA report is the first to look at the effects of bike-sharing programs on peoples daily commutes. It found that bike-

Chevrolet unveiled its new SS sedan, which it will race in NASCAR, at Daytona International Speedway on Saturday.
Chevrolet may have pulled out of NASCAR had the sanctioning body not agreed to redesign race cars and make them more relevant to
continuation:
todays drivers.
The car is based on the Camaro ZL1 1LE, but with a few changes. For one, it now has an all-wheel-drive system that replaces the rear-wheel-drive system used in previous versions of the car. It also has a different front splitter and a larger rear diffuser, as well as a revised rear spoiler.
Other than that, the car looks exactly the same. The only difference between the two is the paint job, which is black instead of red.
Chevrolet said the car will be available for pre-order this summer.

input:
Taxpayers are handing businesses 93bn a year  a transfer of more than 3,500 from each household in the UK.
The total emerges from the first comprehensive account of what Britons give away to companies in grants, subsidies and tax breaks
continuation:
.
It is based on data from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC), the Government's revenue agency, which says it has been able to calculate the value of such transfers by taking into account the value of the goods and services they provide.
The figures show that in 2018-19, the average taxpayer handed over an extra 1,000 to their local business or charity.
This was on top of the 1,300 they gave to the NHS and other public sector organisations.
In contrast, the average taxpayer paid no income tax at all in 2018-19, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS).
The ONS said this reflected the fact that many people did not have enough money to pay any tax at all.
However, there were signs that the trend was changing last year.
In 2017-18, the ONS found that the number of people paying no income tax had fallen to its lowest level since 2010-11.
The ONS said the fall was partly due to a rise in self-assessment tax returns, as well as changes to the tax reliefs available to pensioners.
But it added: "We do not expect these trends to continue indefinitely."
A Treasury spokesman

This is based on data from the government's revenue agency, HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC), which says it was able to calculate the value of such transfers by taking into account the value of the goods and services provided. .

The ONS said part of the decline was due to an increase in self-assessed tax payments and changes to the tax relief available to pensioners.
But he added: "We do not expect these trends to continue forever."

The bill, which now moves to the Senate, was introduced by Rep. Steve King, an Iowa Republican who has been one of the most vocal critics of NPR in Congress.
"NPR is no longer a neutral news source," he said during floor debate. "It's a propaganda arm of the Democratic Party. It's a left-wing media outlet."

AN award-winning taxidermist from North Yorkshire is bringing a long-lost bird back from extinction  at least in model form.
The creations of Carl Church will be the centre of the Great Dodo Exhibition at Kendal Museum from July 4
continuation:
to 8.
Carl, who has been working on the project for more than two years, said: Im very excited about this exhibition. Its something Ive always wanted to do and now that its finally happening I cant wait to share it with everyone.
This is the first time Ive ever had a chance to work with an endangered species, so Im really looking forward to seeing how they turn out.
Dodos are one of the worlds most iconic birds, but their numbers have dropped dramatically over the last century due to hunting, habitat loss and climate change.
They were listed as vulnerable under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in 2015.
In 2016, the UK government announced plans to protect the dodo by banning the importation of wild dodos into the country.
However, the ban was later overturned by the European Court of Human Rights, which ruled that CITES did not provide sufficient protection for the dodo.
Carls work will be displayed alongside some of his best-known models

An Arizona man on Monday sued the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, saying church officials allegedly protected a sexually abusive priest who he said molested him at his Northeast Philadelphia parish and caused him years of psychiatric problems.
Identified by his attorneys only as a
continuation:
John Doe in the lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Philadelphia, the plaintiff is seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages for emotional distress, medical expenses, lost wages and pain and suffering.
A spokesman for the archdiocese declined to comment on pending litigation.
The lawsuit alleges that the Rev. Thomas J. OMalley, now deceased, abused John Doe when he was a child in the late 1960s and early 1970s at St. Mary Magdalen Church, where OMalley served as pastor from 1969 until his retirement in 1992. The suit says the abuse took place at the churchs rectory, which was located across the street from the church.
OMalley, who died in 2005, was a member of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Allentown, Pa., at the time of the alleged abuse. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1965, according to court documents.
In a statement released Monday, Archbishop Charles Chaput of Allentown condemned the alleged abuse.
I am deeply saddened to learn of the allegations against Father OMalley, Chaput said. My heart goes out to this young man

input:
Can Grizzlies get city's trust back like Memphis basketball, football?
Memphis football and basketball have regained the city's trust. Can Grizzlies do the same?
Memphis athletic director Tom Bowen stood along the sideline at Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium taking in
continuation:
his teams game against North Carolina State on Saturday.
He didnt need to look far to see what was happening around him.
The stands were filled with red-clad NCSU fans, many of whom were decked out in the schools blue and gold colors.
They cheered every time their team scored a touchdown. They chanted Grizzlies! Grizzlies! when Ja Morant hit a three-pointer for the first points of the second half.
And they booed every time the Wolfpack made a field goal.
It was a scene that had never been seen before.
I think its a testament to how much our fan base has grown over the past few years, Bowen said. Weve got a lot of young people who are really passionate about this program and want to be part of it. And I think were seeing some of that come to fruition.
Its a sentiment shared by Grizzlies coach Taylor Jenkins, who said hes noticed a change in the atmosphere around FedExForum since he took over the team last season.
I

And every time the Wolfpack made a field goal, there were boos.

input: In this screen grab from a Sept. 21, 2018, video provided to The Associated Press by Earthjustice, an environmental advocacy group, a turtle is plucked from gray muck along the Cape Fear River near the L.V. Sutton Plant near
continuation:
Fayetteville, N.C. (Earthjustice via AP)

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. (AP)  A North Carolina environmental group is suing the state Department of Environment and Natural Resources for not doing enough to protect endangered sea turtles nesting on the banks of the Cape Fear River.

The lawsuit was filed Tuesday in Wake County Superior Court against DEQ Commissioner Mike Causey and other agency officials. It says the department has failed to take adequate measures to protect the endangered Kemps ridley sea turtles that nest along the rivers banks.

Kemps ridley sea turtles are listed as threatened under the U.S. Endangered Species Act.

DEQ spokesman Chris Whitmire said the agency has been actively working with stakeholders to address issues related to sea turtle conservation but declined further comment.

The lawsuit asks the court to force DEQ to take additional steps to protect the sea turtles.

input: LONDON  Vodafone says any move by Britain to bar equipment made by China's Huawei from all parts of new 5G networks would cost it hundreds of millions of pounds and very significantly slow down the deployment of the new
continuation:
technology.

The telecoms giant said in a statement on Thursday that it was "deeply concerned" by reports that the U.K. government is considering banning Huawei from its 5G networks, which are expected to be rolled out across the country over the next few years.

Huawei has repeatedly denied allegations that its equipment could be used for spying by China's government or security services. The company also says it complies with all applicable laws and regulations wherever it operates.

Vodafone, which is part-owned by Hong Kong-based CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd., said that if the ban were to take effect, it would cost the company between $300 million and $500 million per year, depending on how long it took to replace existing equipment.

We believe this decision will have a significant negative impact on our ability to invest in 5G infrastructure, Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao told reporters on a conference call.

London-based Vodafone said it would cost hundreds of millions of pounds to implement the new technology if Britain moves to ban the use of equipment made by China's Huawei in any part of its new 5G network. He said there would be significant delays.

The telecoms giant said in a statement on Thursday that it was "deeply concerned" by reports that the UK government was considering banning Huawei from its 5G network, which is expected to be rolled out nationwide over the next few years.  he said.

Huawei has repeatedly denied accusations that its equipment could be used for espionage by the Chinese government and security services. The company also says it complies with all applicable laws and regulations wherever it operates.

Vodafone, which is partly owned by Hong Kong-based CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd., said the ban, if it takes effect, would cost between $300 million and $500 million a year, depending on how long the replacement takes. Existing equipment.

"We believe this decision will have a material negative impact on our ability to invest in 5G infrastructure," Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao told reporters on a conference call.

He added: "If we don't have access to the latest technology, we won't be able to deploy 5G as quickly as we would like." We are unable to provide special benefits.

input: When the Elsas and Supermen trick-or-treat their way to our doorsteps next week, some will be toting an orange box with the word UNICEF on it. Since 1950, four years after the organization was founded
continuation:
in New York City, the United Nations Childrens Fund (UNICEF) has helped millions of children in more than 190 countries around the world.

This year marks the 50th anniversary of UNICEFs founding, which is why we thought it would be a good time to look back at how far the organization has come since its humble beginnings.

In the early days, UNICEF relied heavily on donations from individuals and organizations like the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, the Ford Foundation, and the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. These foundations were instrumental in helping the organization grow into what it is today.

Today, UNICEF receives more than $3 billion in annual funding from governments, corporations, foundations, and individual donors. This money helps fund programs such as polio eradication, immunization campaigns, and water and sanitation projects, among many others.

UNICEF also works closely with the U.S. Department of State to ensure that all children have access to quality education and health care. In fact, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) provides nearly half of UNICEFs total budget.

As you can see,

Trump has scheduled fundraisers on April 10 in Houston and San Antonio, according to those sources. Asked
continuation:
about the presidents plans, White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said Tuesday that the president will be making a number of stops across the country in the coming weeks.
The events are expected to draw hundreds of donors, many of whom have already contributed to Trumps 2020 reelection campaign.
Trumps planned visits come as he faces criticism over his response to the coronavirus pandemic, which has killed more than 100,000 Americans and thrown millions out of work.
He is also facing an impeachment inquiry into whether he abused his office by pressuring Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading Democratic presidential candidate, and his son Hunter, who served on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.
Trump has denied any wrongdoing and says he did nothing wrong. He has sought to shift the focus away from his administrations handling of the virus crisis and onto Democrats, claiming without evidence that they are trying to undo his election victory.
In March, Trump canceled a trip to Florida after the state banned gatherings of more than 250 people. He also postponed a rally in Tulsa, Okla., that was set to take place on June 20. The event was later resched

input:
It's been a hellish year for music. Rick Parfitt died the day before (December 24). So many legends have passed away this year  from David Bowie to Prince to Leonard Cohen to Glenn Frey.
When I was in school,
continuation:
it seemed like every week there was a new death of a rock star. Nowadays, it seems like we're getting one every other week. It's hard to keep track of all the people who've left us.
I'm not sure how long it will take me to catch up on all these deaths, but here are some of my favourites:
Rick Parfitt
The singer-songwriter and bassist, best known for his work with The Smiths, has died at the age of 61.
Parfitt had been battling cancer for several years. He is survived by his wife and children.
David Bowie
The legendary musician and actor died on January 10 after a battle with cancer. He was 69.
Bowie was a trailblazer in the music industry, and he paved the way for so many artists to come after him.
Glenn Frey
Frey, a founding member of the Eagles, was found dead in his Los Angeles home on February 1 at the age of 67.
His cause of death has yet to be determined.
Leonard Cohen
Cohen, whose songs included "Hallelujah" and "You Want It Darker," died on April 7 at the age

It's been an incredible year for music. Rick Parfitt passed away yesterday (December 24th). So many legends have passed away this year, from David Bowie to Prince to Leonard Cohen to Glenn Frey.
When I was in school, it seemed like every week there was a new rock star death. It seems like it now arrives once every two weeks. It's hard to keep track of everyone who has left us.
I'm not sure how long it will take me to catch up on all these deaths, but here are some of my favorites.
rick parfitt
The singer, songwriter and bassist best known for his work with the Smiths has died at the age of 61.
Parfitt battled cancer for several years. He is survived by his wife and children.
david bowie
The legendary musician and actor passed away on January 10th after a battle with cancer. He was 69 years old.
Bowie was a pioneer in the music industry, paving the way for many artists who followed him.
Glenn Frey
Frey, a founding member of the Eagles, was found dead in his home in Los Angeles on February 1 at the age of 67.
The cause of his death has not yet been determined.
leonard coen
Cohen, who wrote songs such as ``Hallelujah'' and ``You Want It Darker,'' died on April 7 at the age of 30.

The Seattle area has a new biotechnology company -- and this one is going to try attacking cancer by examining antibodies instead of tumors.
Johnny Stine, founder and chief scientist of the new Spaltudaq Corp., said the approach, if it
continuation:
pans out, could be used for other diseases as well.
"We're looking at a broad range of diseases," he said. "It's not just cancer."
Spaltudaq's technology is based on the fact that cancer cells are made up of two different types of proteins: Tumor Necrosis Factor Alpha (TNF-alpha) and interleukin-1 beta (IL-1-beta).
Both proteins have been shown to play an important role in tumor development and metastasis.
But they can also cause inflammation, which can lead to tissue damage and even death.
In a study published last month in the journal Science Translational Medicine, researchers from the University of California, San Francisco, found that TNF-alpha and IL-1-beta were able to bind to a protein called CCR5.
CCR5 is a receptor on the surface of many immune cells that helps them recognize and destroy foreign invaders such as bacteria and viruses.
When CCR5 binds to TNF-alpha or IL-1-beta, the cell releases its own inflammatory cytokines, including interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), which causes the immune system to overreact

Johnny Stein, founder and chief scientific officer of the new company Spartudac, said if the approach is successful, it could be used to treat other diseases.
We study a wide range of diseases, he said. "It's not just cancer."
Spaltudaq's technology is based on the fact that cancer cells are composed of two different types of proteins: tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha) and interleukin 1 beta (IL-1-beta). .
Both proteins have been shown to play important roles in tumor development and metastasis.
However, it can also cause inflammation, which can lead to tissue damage and death.

CCR5 is a receptor on the surface of many immune cells that helps recognize and destroy foreign invaders such as bacteria and viruses.
When CCR5 binds to TNF- or IL-1-, cells release their own inflammatory cytokines, such as interferon gamma (IFN-gamma), causing an overreaction of the immune system.

input: Asked where they had their most memorable campus experiences, Dartmouth students polled back when I was an undergraduate most frequently identified the Hopkins Center for the Arts. It is certainly the site I would have identified if asked. I still recall, to take just one example
continuation:
, a performance of The Tempest in which the entire audience stood up and applauded at the end of the play.

But what about the other arts centers on campus? How often do you go to see plays or concerts there? And how many of them are worth seeing?

To find out, I went to Dartmouths student newspaper, The Dartmouth Daily News, last week to talk with some of the people who work in the various departments that make up the arts center. (I did not interview any faculty members.)

Heres what I learned:

Dartmouths theater department has produced more than 100 shows since it opened its doors in 2001.

Of those shows, more than half were produced by outside companies.

More than 80 percent of the shows that have been produced by outside companies have been world premieres.

Dartmouths theater department produces more than 50 shows each year.

Dartmouths theater department has produced more than 20 musicals.

Dartmouths theater department has produced more than 10 plays that have won awards from the National Endowment for the Arts.

D

input: Signs have gone up naming a section of a Los Angeles-area freeway as the President Barack H. Obama Highway, seen from Pasadena, Calif., Thursday, Dec. 20, 2018. The signs posted Thursday on State Route 134 apply to a stretch
continuation:
of the highway that runs along the border between Orange and Los Angeles counties. (AP Photo/Ringo H.W. Chiu)

LOS ANGELES (AP)  A stretch of a Southern California freeway has been renamed in honor of former President Barack Obama, who was born in Chicago but spent much of his adult life in Hawaii.

The signs posted Thursday on State Route 134 apply to a stretch of the highway that runs along the border between Orange and Los Angeles counties.

Obama was born in Honolulu on Aug. 4, 1961. He graduated from Occidental College with a bachelors degree in political science before going on to Harvard Law School where he earned his Juris Doctor. He served as a law clerk for U.S. Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.

ADVERTISEMENT

Obama went into public service after leaving the White House in January 2017. He is now a professor at Columbia Universitys Mailman School of Public Health.

___

Associated Press writer John Antczak contributed to this report.

___

Follow Weber at https://twitter.com/WeberCM. His work can be found at http://bigstory.ap.org/

Why Did Hilary Duff Pay Millionaire Ex-Husband Mike Comrie $2.5 Million in Their Divorce?
continuation:
EXCLUSIVE
Hilary Duff and ex-husband Mike Comrie are still on good terms -- despite the fact that he's a multimillionaire who just paid her $2.5 million in spousal support.
Sources close to the former couple tell TMZ... they've been friends for years, but Hilary didn't know Mike was worth that much at the time of their divorce.
We're told she only found out about Mike's wealth when she went through his financials after filing for divorce.
Our sources say Hilary was shocked when she saw how much money she'd be getting from her ex.
As we reported, Hilary filed for divorce last month citing irreconcilable differences.
In court documents obtained by TMZ, Hilary claims Mike is "unable or unwilling" to pay child support, alimony and other legal fees. She also wants him to pay her attorney fees.
Hilary says she has no plans to move back to L.A. with her new boyfriend Matthew Koma.
She's currently living in New York City with her son Luca, 5, and daughter Banks, 3.
We reached out to Mike's reps for comment but have not heard back

Eden Hazard was facing an extended ban for kicking out at a ball boy after the Football Association charged him over his sending-off in Chelsea's Capital One Cup exit at Swansea.
Belgian playmaker Hazard was already set to serve an automatic three
continuation:
-match suspension, having been sent off in the 2-1 defeat at Stamford Bridge on Wednesday night.
The 27-year-old will now be suspended for Saturday's Premier League clash against Stoke City and next week's Champions League last-16 second leg at Atletico Madrid.
Hazard, who has scored five goals this season, received a straight red card for elbowing Swansea defender Ki Sung-yueng in the face during the first half of the 0-0 draw at the Liberty Stadium.
Swansea manager Carlos Carvalhal said: "I don't know what happened. I didn't see it.
"We are disappointed because we played very well and deserved to win the game.
"It is a big loss for us. We had a lot of chances to score but they were good saves from Thibaut Courtois."
Chelsea manager Antonio Conte told Sky Sports: "I think the referee made the right decision.
"In my opinion, he saw the incident clearly. He saw the contact between the player and the player's arm.
"I am not going to say anything more than that. I think the referee did a good job."
Conte also refused to criticise

input: NAFTA's environmental watchdog voted unanimously not to investigate oil sands tailings ponds pollution, despite recommendations from staff to launch a probe. It's the third time a NAFTA probe has been blocked by the Canadian government, pending a decision on Canada's controversial
continuation:
Keystone XL pipeline.

The National Energy Board (NEB) said in a report released Thursday that it couldn't find enough evidence to support an investigation into the potential impact of oilsands tailings ponds on the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River systems.

"It is clear that the NEB does not have sufficient information to make a determination as to whether there would be any adverse impacts to the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River system," the NEB said in its report.

Story continues below advertisement

But Environment Minister Leona Aglukkaq told reporters at a news conference she was disappointed with the NEB's decision.

"We are going to take this matter very seriously and we are going to work with our partners across the country to make sure that we do everything we can to ensure that these issues are addressed," Ms. Aglukkaq said. "I think it's important for Canadians to know that we're taking this very seriously."

Ms. Aglukkaq's office did not immediately respond to a request for further comment.

The NEB had recommended that the board open a formal investigation into the issue after receiving more than 1,000 public comments on
translation:
NAFTA's environmental watchdog voted unanimously to abandon an investigation into oil sands tailings contamination, despite staff recommendations to open an investigation. This is the third time a NAFTA study has been blocked by the Canadian government pending a decision on Canada's controversial Keystone XL pipeline.

The National Energy Board (NEB) said in a report released Thursday that it did not find sufficient evidence to support a study of the potential impacts of oil sands tailings ponds on the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River systems.

It is clear that the NEB does not have sufficient information to determine whether there will be adverse effects on the Great Lakes system and the St. Lawrence River, the NEB report said.

Story continues below ad

However, Environment Minister Leona Aglucak said at a press conference that she was disappointed with the NEB's decision.

We take this issue very seriously and will work with our partners across the country to do everything we can to address these issues, Agluqaq said. "I think it's important that Canadians know that we take this issue very seriously."

Mr. Agrukhak's office did not immediately respond to a request for further comment.

The NEB recommended that the board launch a formal investigation into the issue after receiving more than 1,000 public comments on the issue.

India might be celebrating the centenary of cinema this year,
continuation:
but it has been a long time since we have had a new film from the country that is worth talking about. While there have been a number of films that have come out over the last few years, none of them have been as good as Dinshaw Billimoria's Heer Ranjha (1929).
Directed by Dilip Kumar, Heer Ranjha was one of the first Hindi films to feature an all-star cast. It also marked the debut of actor Sulochana in Bollywood.
The film stars Raj Kapoor, Madhubala, Meena Kumari, Saira Banu, Lata Mangeshkar, Shammi Kapoor, Nargis Fakhri, Anil Dhawan, Prakash Mehrotra and Kishore Kumar.
It tells the story of a woman who falls in love with a man she meets at a train station. The two get married and live happily ever after. However, things take a turn for the worse when her husband leaves her for another woman. The film ends on a cliffhanger, leaving audiences wondering what will happen next.
Here are five reasons why you should watch Heer Ranjha.
1

A RADICAL shake-up, including a new school in Basingstoke, may be necessary to combat poor exam results, the deputy leader of the borough council believes.
Councillor Ranil Jayawardena says too many children in
continuation:
the borough are failing their GCSEs and A-levels, which is why he wants to see an overhaul of the education system.
He said: We need to look at what were doing in terms of the curriculum, how were preparing our young people for the future.
Cllr Jayawardena, who also serves as cabinet member for health and social care, was speaking after figures revealed that more than half (56 per cent) of students in Basingstoke and Deane failed their exams this year.
The figure is up from 47 per cent in 2015/16 and 44 per cent in 2014/15.
It comes amid growing concern about the state of the countrys schools.
Last month, Ofsted chief inspector Amanda Spielman said she was deeply concerned by the number of pupils who were falling behind in their studies.
In her annual report, Ms Spielman said the situation had worsened over the past two years.
She added: Pupils progress has not kept pace with the rising cost of living or the increasing pressure on family finances.
This is particularly worrying because it suggests that

The council's deputy leader has said radical reforms, including the opening of a new school in Basingstoke, may be needed to combat poor exam performance.
Councilor Ranil Jayawardene said he wanted an overhaul of the education system because too many children in the borough were failing their GCSEs and A-levels.
He said: "We need to look at what we are doing in terms of the curriculum and how we are preparing young people for the future."
Jayawardene, who is also cabinet member for health and social care, spoke after figures emerged showing more than half (56%) of students in Basingstoke and Deane failed this year's exams.
This figure increased from 47% in 2015/16 and 44% in 2014/15.
The announcement comes amid growing concerns about the current state of schools in this country.
Last month Ofsted's chief inspector Amanda Spielman said she was deeply concerned about the number of pupils who were falling behind academically.
In her annual report, Spielman said the situation had worsened over the past two years.
She added: "Pupil outcomes have not kept pace with rising costs of living and increasing pressure on household budgets."
This is especially problematic.

input:
WASHINGTON  Republican David Yancey won a drawing to break a tie in the disputed 94th District race in Newport News Thursday however his opponent is expected to challenge the decision, possibly seeking yet another recount.
Control of the House of Delegates is
continuation:
up for grabs in Novembers midterm elections. Republicans currently hold a one-seat majority in the House and Democrats need to flip 24 seats to gain control of the chamber.
Yancey, an attorney and former Navy SEAL, defeated Democrat Danica Roem by just over 1,000 votes out of nearly 2.5 million cast in the district that includes Hampton Roads and parts of Virginia Beach and Norfolk.
Roem, who was the first openly transgender person elected to the U.S. House of Representatives, had challenged Yanceys victory on the grounds that he did not obtain enough valid signatures from registered voters to qualify for the ballot.
In a statement Thursday night, Yancey said I am confident we will be able to resolve this matter quickly and move forward with our mission of serving all Virginians.
Roems campaign issued a statement saying we are reviewing the courts order and considering next steps. We remain committed to ensuring every eligible voter has the opportunity to have their voice heard through the democratic process.
The Associated Press contributed to this report.
Like WTOP on Facebook and follow @WTOP on Twitter to engage in conversation
translation:
Washington Republican David Yancey won the toss and broke a tie in the controversial 94th District election in Newport News on Thursday, but his opponent contested the decision and likely called for a recount. expected to be sought.
It is possible that the party will win a majority in the House of Representatives in the midterm elections in November. Republicans currently hold a majority in the House, and Democrats would need to flip 24 seats to take control of the chamber.
Yancey, an attorney and former Navy SEAL, defeated Democrat Danica Rome by just over 1,000 votes out of about 2.5 million votes cast in a district that includes Hampton Roads and parts of Virginia Beach and Norfolk. Ta.
Roy, the first openly transgender person to be elected to the U.S. House of Representatives, has filed a lawsuit against Yancey for not having enough valid signatures from registered voters to be eligible to vote. The victory was contested.
Yancey said in a statement Thursday night that he is confident he can quickly resolve this issue and advance his mission to serve all Virginians.
Roems' campaign issued a statement saying it was reviewing the court order and considering its next steps. We remain committed to ensuring that all voters have the opportunity to be heard through the democratic process.
The Associated Press contributed to this report.

input: WASHINGTON  The professions expected to show one of the biggest job growth rates in 2017 and the largest growth in sheer number of jobs will be trade skills, according to a year-end report from CareerBuilder and labor market data provider Emsi.
continuation:
Trade is going to be a big driver for employment growth over the next several years, said Chris Rupkey, chief economist at MUFG Union Bank in New York. Its a sector thats growing faster than just about anything else.

The report, which was released on Wednesday, also showed that employers are looking to hire more people with education beyond high school or college.

Were starting to see an uptick in hiring of people with some sort of post-secondary training, said Michael Bernick, senior vice president of human resources at Home Depot Inc., who noted that the company plans to increase its workforce by 20 percent over the next three years.

Home Depots move comes as other retailers, including Target Corp., Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Costco Wholesale Corp., have been expanding their workforces through higher pay and benefits.

In 2016, the U.S. unemployment rate ticked up to 4.7 percent, the highest in nearly five years. The Federal Reserve has kept interest rates near zero since late 2008, and many economists expect them to remain there for the foreseeable future.

input:
Cecil Brunsons life in the air  and the guile he showed in the Vietnam War  will be honored Saturday at the Tennessee Aviation Hall of Fame.
Growing up in Memphis, Lt. Col. Cecil Brunson only
continuation:
knew one thing about flying: He wanted to be a pilot. So when he graduated from high school, he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps.
Brunson was just 19 years old when he flew his first combat mission during the Vietnam War.
I remember it like it was yesterday, Brunson said. We were bombing an area where there was a lot of enemy activity. It was very hot that day and we had to fly low to avoid being shot down.
He would go on to fly more than 1,000 missions in the skies over Southeast Asia before returning to Memphis.
In 1968, Brunson was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for his actions during the Tet Offensive. He was also awarded the Bronze Star Medal with Valor Device and the Purple Heart for injuries sustained in action.
After serving in the military, Brunson went on to earn a Bachelor of Science degree in aeronautical engineering from Memphis State University in 1972. He then earned a masters degree in business administration from the University of Tennessee-Knoxville in 1978.
Brunson started his career as an aircraft mechanic with the U.S. Air Force before joining the
translation:
Cecil Brunson's Air Force career and cunning exploits during the Vietnam War will be honored Saturday at the Tennessee Aviation Hall of Fame.
Growing up in Memphis, Lt. Col. Cecil Branson knew one thing about his flight. He said that he wanted to be a pilot. So when he graduated from high school, he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps.
Branson was only 19 years old when he flew his first combat mission during the Vietnam War.
"I remember it like it was yesterday," Branson said. We bombed areas of active enemy activity. It was so hot that day that we had to fly low to avoid being shot down.
He flew more than 1,000 of his missions over Southeast Asia before returning to Memphis.
In 1968, Branson was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for his actions during the Tet Offensive. He was also awarded the Bronze Star Medal with a Valor Device and a Purple Heart for injuries sustained in combat.
After serving in the Army, Branson earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Aeronautical Engineering from Memphis State University in 1972. He then earned his MBA from the University of Tennessee, Knoxville in 1978.
Branson began his career as an aircraft mechanic in the United States Air Force and later joined the United States Air Force.

input:
Thirty-four states  half with Republican governor  have seized upon the massive infusion of Medicaid expansion revenue.
Imagine an 18 wheeler pulling up to one of the five Mississippi River bridges and dumping 45 crates 4 feet tall and of $100 bills
continuation:
a total value of more than $1 million  on the pavement. Thats exactly what is happening across the country as state governments scramble to pay for expanded Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare.
The result: The federal government has paid out more than $2 billion in reimbursement payments to states so far this year, according to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
Thats a lot of money, but it pales in comparison to the $3.6 billion that the feds are expected to hand out over the next three years. In all, HHS expects to disburse more than $10 billion in reimbursements to states through 2016.
In fact, HHS officials say they expect the number of Medicaid enrollees to increase by more than 50% between now and 2016.
But how much will that cost taxpayers? A recent analysis from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that the total cost of expanding Medicaid could be as high as $200 billion over the next decade, depending on how many people are added to the rolls.
Thats a lot of money, but it pales in comparison to the $
translation:
Thirty-four states with half of their Republican governors are reaping huge amounts of revenue from Medicaid expansion.
Imagine an 18-wheeler pulling up to one of the five bridges spanning the Mississippi River and dumping 45 four-foot-tall boxes and more than $1 million worth of $100 bills onto the sidewalk. That's what's happening across the country as state governments struggle to pay for expanded Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare).
As a result, the federal government has paid out more than $2 billion in compensation to states this year, according to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
That's a lot of money, but it pales in comparison to the $3.6 billion the federal government is expected to provide over the next three years. HHS plans to pay out more than $10 billion in total reimbursements to states by 2016.
In fact, HHS officials say they expect the number of Medicaid enrollees to increase by more than 50% from now until 2016.
But how much will it cost taxpayers? A recent analysis by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that the total cost of Medicaid expansion could reach $200 billion over the next decade, depending on the number of people added to the rolls.
That's a lot of money, but it pales in comparison to dollars.

Pedro Gonzalez faces up to 48 years in prison for allegedly attempting to beat Dita Richterova to death.
Friends have set up a GoFundMe page for Dita Richterova, who was severely beaten during an attack at the Brush
continuation:
y Creek Apartments on Saturday night.
According to court documents obtained by ABC News, Pedro Gonzalez has pleaded not guilty to attempted first-degree murder and assault with intent to commit a felony.
Gonzalez is being held without bond.
The incident occurred just before 11:30 p.m., when officers responded to a report of a fight between two men in the parking lot of the apartment complex.
When police arrived, they found Dita lying on the ground with multiple lacerations to her head and face.
She was taken to a local hospital, where she was pronounced dead.
Police said that Gonzalez and another man were seen running away from the scene after the attack.
Gonzalez is scheduled to be arraigned on Monday.
